1 Selects and completely identifies another work of art from South, East, and Southeast Asia (300 B.C.E.–1980 C.E.), West and Central Asia (500 B.C.E.–1980 C.E.), or the Pacific (700–1980 C.E.) that also presents or creates a relationship between humans and the natural world.

When identifying the work, the student should try to include all of the following identifiers: title or designation, name of the artist and/or culture of origin, date of creation, and materials. The student will earn credit for the identification if at least two accurate identifiers are provided, but the student will not be penalized if any additional identifiers provided are inaccurate. If a work from the list provided is selected, the student must include at least two accurate identifiers beyond those that are given.

FT548827_rubric_category_0.s:
0–9 Possible Points

9–8 points
Response demonstrates thorough knowledge and understanding of the question.
The student fully identifies two appropriate representations of deities or holy personages. The student makes use of specific visual evidence to provide a coherent analysis of each representation in relation to both the religious beliefs and the religious practices of its culture. The response may include minor errors that do not affect the analysis.

A score of 8 may be earned when the response is slightly unbalanced or includes several minor errors.

7–6 points
Response demonstrates sufficient knowledge and understanding of the question.
The student fully identifies two appropriate visual representations of deities or holy personages. The student analyzes relationships to both religious beliefs and practices; however, the analysis demonstrates a deeper understanding of one than of the other.

A score of 6 may be earned in cases when the essay is noticeably unbalanced, contains errors that affect the analysis, or both.

5 points
Response demonstrates some knowledge and understanding of the question.
The student identifies two appropriate visual representations of deities or holy personages. The response demonstrates an understanding of beliefs, practices or both, but the discussion is more descriptive than analytical, addresses only one relationship, or includes significant errors.
OR
The student identifies only one appropriate representation, but the analysis demonstrates thorough knowledge and understanding in relation to both beliefs and practices.

Note: This is the highest score an essay can earn if the student identifies and analyzes only one appropriate choice fully and correctly.

4–3 points
Response demonstrates limited knowledge and understanding of the question.
The student identifies two appropriate visual representations of deities or holy personages. The identification may be incomplete or contain errors. The response addresses beliefs, practices or both, but the analysis is brief, unbalanced or both.
OR
The student identifies only one appropriate representation, but the analysis is otherwise at the level of a response that would earn a score of 5–6.

A score of 3 may be earned when the analysis is minimal and contains significant errors.

2–1 points
Response demonstrates little knowledge or understanding of the question.

If a work from the list is selected, the student must include at least two accurate identifiers beyond those that are given.

FT561786_rubric_category_0.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes ONE practical function for which the Forum of Trajan was built.

Scoring Notes

A public meeting space where civic buildings, sacred temples, and commemorative monuments were erected.

The forum accommodated the formulation and implementation of law and justice.

The forum was a place where political bodies met and ceremonial rituals were carried out.

While the forum accommodated commercial interactions, it was more than exclusively a marketplace.

Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes ONE symbolic function for which the Forum of Trajan was built.

Scoring Notes

The Forum of Trajan functioned symbolically as propaganda, to glorify the emperor Trajan and his achievements in leading two successful military campaigns against the Dacians.

It served the symbolic purpose of honoring the emperor, even to the extent of fashioning his deification.

Roman imperial fora reinforced the social hierarchy that elites enjoyed under prosperous rule, providing spaces that demonstrated Roman loyalty to ancestral practices and traditions.

The forum also bolstered social cohesion within the diverse populations of a growing empire.

Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes ONE symbolic function for which the Forum of Trajan was built.

Scoring Notes

The Forum of Trajan functioned symbolically as propaganda, to glorify the emperor Trajan and his achievements in leading two successful military campaigns against the Dacians.

It served the symbolic purpose of honoring the emperor, even to the extent of fashioning his deification.

Roman imperial fora reinforced the social hierarchy that elites enjoyed under prosperous rule, providing spaces that demonstrated Roman loyalty to ancestral practices and traditions.

The forum also bolstered social cohesion within the diverse populations of a growing empire.

FT561786_rubric_category_2.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately uses specific evidence to explain how the Forum of Trajan was designed to accommodate ONE practical function.

Scoring Notes

Imperial fora provided large open spaces that contrasted with crowded Roman streets, allowing for the congregation of large crowds to meet, converse, and observe ceremonial rituals.

The focus of the Forum of Trajan was a large basilica, or law court, famous for its extensive interior space. Immense rounded extensions (apses) provided dramatic backdrops for judges during court proceedings. The Basilica Ulpia may have functioned as an imperial audience chamber.

Two libraries behind the basilica housed the emperor’s collection of manuscripts. The libraries functioned as a repository of ideas and accounts that both honored and contributed to historical legacies.

t included a complex of multileveled shops and administrative offices, known as the Trajan Markets.

FT561786_rubric_category_3.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately uses specific evidence to explain how the Forum of Trajan was designed to accommodate ONE symbolic function.

Scoring Notes

Visitors originally entered the vast space through a triumphal arch that served as a reminder that the forum was built to commemorate Trajan’s two victories against the Dacians.

The extensive size and opulent appearance of the forum was made possible by the spoils of these Dacian campaigns, symbolizing Trajan’s generosity.

The enormous main plaza accommodated the forum’s propagandistic function by exhibiting a larger-than-life bronze statue of the emperor on horseback in its exact center. In between the columns of the porticoes on the sides were statues used to glorify Rome’s military might under Trajan’s leadership.

The temple behind the basilica was completed after the emperor’s death. In accordance with tradition, the structure accommodated the symbolic function of deifying the emperor.

FT561786_rubric_category_4.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately explains the role the Column of Trajan played in the overall design of the Forum of Trajan.

Scoring Notes

Its placement between two libraries allowed for the column to be viewed from multiple vantage points.

The importance of the height of the column can be found in the inscription at the base, interpreted as marking original the height of the adjacent excavated hill.

Roman citizens could, presumably, climb the interior spiral staircase to view the grandeur of the forum from a great height. In this way the column functioned within the design as a belvedere.

The column’s siting, axially positioned at the north end of the forum opposite the entrance, rises above the basilica and can be seen from any place in the forum.

After Trajan’s death, the Senate decided to use the base of the column as a mausoleum sanctifying the spot as the final resting place of the cremated remains of Trajan and his wife.

FT561787_rubric_category_0.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Correctly attributes the work shown to its specific African culture by identifying the corresponding work from the required course content that is from the same specific African culture.

When identifying the work from the required course content, students must include the culture of origin and one additional accurate identifier: title or designation, date of creation, or materials. Students will not be penalized if any additional identifiers provided beyond the two required are inaccurate.

Scoring Notes:

To earn credit, students must identify the culture (Baule peoples, Côte d’Ivoire, or West Africa) + one additional accurate identifier taken from the following list:

Title: Portrait mask (Mblo) of Moya Yanso

Artist: Owie Kimou

Date: Early 20th century C.E. (20th century is NOT acceptable)

Materials: wood, brass, and pigment (paint) (wood is acceptable)

FT561787_rubric_category_1.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately justifies the attribution by describing ONE formal similarity between the two works.

Scoring Notes

Masks carved in the Mblo style are idealized portraits that feature:

High foreheads

Arched brows

Heavy-lidded, downcast eyes

Narrow, elongated triangular nose

Small open geometric mouth

Stylized, elongated faces

Ornamental extensions that rise above the head

Raised areas to indicate facial scarification

Textural and linear treatment of the hair

FT561787_rubric_category_3.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately infers the probable content of the work shown based on the content of the corresponding work in the required course content.

Scoring Notes

Mblo masks represent a specific honored individual, often but not always a female.

The Mblo mask in the required course content depicts the dancer Moya Yanso.

While it is not known who the work shown represents, its identification as a Mblo mask indicates that it is an idealized portrait of a respected known individual.

The presence of a beard does not necessarily identify the mask as male. However, the relative degree of naturalism might indicate a male identity.

FT561787_rubric_category_4.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately explains how works such as these were intended to be experienced in their original context.

Scoring Notes

Mblo masks were worn and danced during events of civic importance as part of secular entertainment.

The masks were danced by men related to the honoree, typically a spouse or a son. The masks were accompanied by the honoree or a representative chosen by the person depicted. For example, the mask of Moya Yanso was danced first by her husband and then by her sons, and accompanied by Moya Yanso.

When not in use, Mblo masks were kept hidden. When the masks appeared, it was at the conclusion of a series of masked dances, and their appearance was considered to be the highlight of the ceremony.

Mblo masks were kept hidden to heighten the drama of their appearance and to increase the audience’s sense of appreciation. The act of obscuring the Mblo mask — of not seeing it — was a fundamental aspect of how the mask was intended to be experienced in its original context.

When Mblo masks were danced in public they were part of a larger ensemble of textiles and cloth that served to limit the visibility of the mask. The duration of these performances tended to be short, and then the performer made a quick and dramatic exit, with the intent of leaving the audience wanting more.

For the audience the performance of Mblo masks was intended to reaffirm community-held ideals of human beauty and artistic accomplishment.

FT561789_rubric_category_0.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes ONE visual characteristic of Ingres’s representation of the female nude.

Scoring Notes

The female nude is represented with restrained eroticism, elegance, and sensual appeal. She is:

reclining on a divan, with her back turned toward the viewer

propped up on one arm, while the other arm reaches down the length of her body

crossing her legs, with one hand holding a fan, brushing her lower leg

looking over her shoulder at the viewer with a calm, neutral expression

unclothed except for a turban and jewelry

idealized rather than natural or realistic

elongated and sinuous, bathed in an even light

The emphasis is on overall visual balance and compositional harmony, despite the anatomical distortions of the figure’s proportions.

FT561789_rubric_category_2.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately uses specific visual evidence to explain how La Grande Odalisque demonstrates established traditions in the representation of the female nude.

Scoring Notes

The sensual female nude is a common subject matter in Western art, especially since the Renaissance revived and adapted the tradition from classical antiquity.

Ingres’s painting recalls precedents by Giorgione, Velazquez, and Titian. The reclining pose and direct gaze specifically recall Titian’s Venus of Urbino, as does the figure’s placement on a bed in a private space.

In both composition and technique, the painting follows principles of Neoclassicism from Ingres's study with Jacques-Louis David and at the French Royal Academy. These principles include:

Overall compositional balance and harmony and a stable visual foundation

Clear linearity in defining forms

Emphasis on skills of draughtsmanship

Precise naturalism and meticulous detail in rendering form

Invisible brushwork that creates a smooth surface of the painting

FT561789_rubric_category_3.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately uses specific visual evidence to explain how La Grande Odalisque demonstrates changes from established traditions in the representation of the female nude.

Scoring Notes

Ingres rejected Neoclassical subject matter in favor of Romantic themes, abandoning the classical mythology of Venus for an imaginary, exotic culture.

Ingres emphasized the figure’s mysterious, foreign appeal in the general presentation and supporting details, such as the turban, the fan, and the hookah, making the female nude herself an article of luxury and desire.

Ingres used anatomical distortions to create a sense of elegance and sinuousness at the expense of a classically idealized figure typical of academic and Neoclassical nudes.

The positioning of the figure’s back toward the viewer is a change from classical and Italian Renaissance types.

FT561789_rubric_category_4.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately uses specific contextual evidence to explain why Ingres deviated from established traditions in his representation of the female nude

Scoring Notes

Ingres was trying to capitalize on an interest in the exotic. The painting was created during a time of increasing fascination with the “Orient” due to French colonial and military expansion into West Asia and North Africa.

Ingres collected objects and artifacts and also copied travelers’ accounts, including descriptions of harems.

As an Orientalist fantasy, the work presents these cultures as sensual, static, and undeveloped, supporting political moral imperatives for imperialism as well as providing viewers safe moral distance to enjoy the blatant eroticism of Ingres’s representation of the female nude.

The distortions and sharp bright colors also reveal the artist’s interest in Mannerism

Accurately uses specific contextual evidence to explain why Ingres deviated from established traditions in his representation of the female nude

Scoring Notes

Ingres was trying to capitalize on an interest in the exotic. The painting was created during a time of increasing fascination with the “Orient” due to French colonial and military expansion into West Asia and North Africa.

Ingres collected objects and artifacts and also copied travelers’ accounts, including descriptions of harems.

As an Orientalist fantasy, the work presents these cultures as sensual, static, and undeveloped, supporting political moral imperatives for imperialism as well as providing viewers safe moral distance to enjoy the blatant eroticism of Ingres’s representation of the female nude.

The distortions and sharp bright colors also reveal the artist’s interest in Mannerism

FT561790_rubric_category_0.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes the form of Darkytown Rebellion.

Scoring Notes

An immersive installation with a 37-foot-wide tableau that uses over a dozen largescale, black silhouettes applied to two adjacent white gallery walls with wax.

Use of colored light projection to create an abstract landscape, interspersing bright colors with dark shadows.

The figures emphasize contours, which vary in form from profiles to three-quarter views to full frontal poses.

FT561790_rubric_category_1.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately describes the content of Darkytown Rebellion.

Scoring Notes

A disturbing, purposefully ambiguous scene: perhaps a slave revolt or an uprising just after the Civil War.

Silhouetted characters appear to march across a surrealistic landscape as they participate in, or are victims of, acts of perversity and violence.

To create the content Walker used imagery from slave narratives, minstrel shows, and advertising (for example, the Aunt Jemima logo). Many of the specific figures as well as the title were taken from a late 19th-century landscape painting Darkytown. Responding to the painting’s offensive title, as well as to the broader theme of visual stereotyping, Walker reimagined the painting’s figures engaged in a fictitious act of rebellion, some carrying flags in a scene that is a mixture of triumph and horror.

FT561790_rubric_category_2.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately explains how Walker used the form to elicit a response from her audience.

Scoring Notes

Walker manipulates form to create spatial ambiguity and a sense of disorientation. She distorts the figures partly through scale, sometimes mixing visual characteristics of children and adults.

Many figures’ forms are recognizable African American stereotypes. To decipher the narrative, viewers must use limited visual markers, which makes them engage with the language of racial stereotyping. This exercise in looking is intended to make viewers feel ill at ease because the use of such markers implicates them and makes them complicit in perpetuating visual stereotypes.

Additionally, viewers’ shadows join the silhouettes on the gallery walls, including viewers in the work through their forms. This creates a changing cast of characters that animate the scene. Walker intended this experience to encourage viewers to study their own forms and the contoured forms of the viewers near them for similar racial markers, and thereby consider both the continued existence of such stereotyping while also revealing the fluidity of identity.

FT561790_rubric_category_3.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately explains how Walker used the content to elicit a response from her audience.

Scoring Notes

Walker uses violent and disturbing content to push her audience to question what they are seeing and why. She makes the content purposefully unclear.

She deliberately blurs the lines between the historical realities of racial oppression with the viewers’ own exploration. She wants viewers to question the images’ authenticity, playing off stereotypes of the genteel, romanticized American South while simultaneously upending such notions.

Walker uses the narrative of rebellion to point to the harsh realities of African American life both before and after the American Civil War. She demonstrates that we see and understand this period through distorted histories and imagery: dramatic images that she uses to shock viewers into a visceral, emotional response.

FT561790_rubric_category_4.s:
Scoring Criteria (1 point)

Accurately explains how Walker drew a connection between historical and contemporary issues in Darkytown Rebellion.

Scoring Notes

By fusing a historical art form (silhouettes) with a contemporary artistic practice (installation), Walker forges a connection between time periods through the interplay of media, content, and form.

By asking contemporary viewers to acknowledge their recognition and reliance on historical racial stereotypes, Walker demonstrates the persistence of such imagery in contemporary American visual culture.

Additionally, the color projections that recall psychedelic light shows reference the 1960s, the decade most closely identified with the American Civil Rights movement and Black Power. This mid-20th-century era is further connected to Walker’s work through the word “rebellion” in her title.

VH074282_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH074282_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Seagram Building
Response accurately describes one visual characteristic of the Seagram Building
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The structure is 38 stories (515 feet) tall.

· Its glass and bronze exterior embraces a streamlined, functional aesthetic that is typical of the International Style and modern corporate architecture.

· The structure incorporates a glass curtain wall that bears no structural weight, reduces construction costs, and allows natural light to penetrate deeper within the building.

· The Seagram Building is set back from the street and opens up to a large plaza with two fountains.

· Panes of gray topaz glass cover the structure, providing floor-to-ceiling windows for the office spaces as well as sun and heat protection.

· Venetian blinds function as window coverings.

· Bronze mullion-like I-beams run the length of the building and emphasize the structure’s intense verticality.

o.d: Response accurately describes two visual characteristics of the Seagram Building

· The Seagram Building is set back from the street and opens up to a large plaza with two fountains.

· Venetian blinds function as window coverings.

· Bronze mullion-like I-beams run the length of the building and emphasize the structure’s intense verticality.

VH074282_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH074282_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of the Seagram Building references earlier architectural traditions.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of the Seagram Building references earlier architectural traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The tripartite structure of the Seagram building that is oriented on functional aspects stands in the tradition of early American skyscraper architecture and follows Louis Sullivan’s architectural principle of “form ever follows function.”

· The use of the glass facade on the load-bearing framework allows a view of the structure’s interior workings, which follows principles of the European International Style of architecture (or Bauhaus architecture).

· The glass facade of the Seagram building creates an impression of transparency by not visually amplifying the corners of the building, showing the influence of the design principles of early works of the International Style of architecture (or Bauhaus architecture).

· The building’s symmetry and disciplined aesthetic reflect Van der Rohe’s love for Greek architecture.

· The three-partite structure of the building suggests the form of a classical column.

· The use of bronze for the decorative I-beam structures running across the front facade references ancient Greek sculpture.

· The use of travertine marble references Roman structures of the classical period.

VH074282_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH074282_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of the Seagram Building departs from earlier architectural traditions.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of the Seagram Building departs from earlier architectural traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· As the first curtain wall building in Manhattan, the structure flaunts its glass and metal exterior and forgoes the heavy stone and brick used in ornamental facades of previous decades.

· The bronze metal skin that is seen in the facade is nonstructural, but it is used to express the idea of the structural frame that is underneath.

· An innovative use of empty space in front of the building distances it from the street to create an open, urban plaza that functions as a gracious pedestrian space.

· The Seagram Building, with its use of modern materials and its setback from the city grid, became a prototype for future office buildings designed by Johnson and van der Rohe as well as a model for many buildings erected in its surroundings.

VH074282_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain the meaning or significance of continuity and/or change between works of art (or a group of related works of art) within a related artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH074282_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain why the architects chose to depart from earlier architectural traditions in their creation of this work.
Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain why the architects chose to depart from earlier architectural traditions in their creation of this work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Van der Rohe was a proponent of the International Style of architecture developed first in Western Europe as a rejection of nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century ornamentation.

· An architectural movement built on collective ideas that moved beyond national borders, the International Style architects worked together to develop a purer form of architecture, seeking an architectural style that was less ostentatious, more economical, and a celebration of modern life instead of a revival of the past.

· International Style architects focused heavily on the latest and greatest building materials. Steel, concrete, and glass were all being mass-produced by the early twentieth century, and new scientific breakthroughs made them more durable and cheaper than ever before.

· The Seagram Building articulates its structure externally, demonstrating the International Style’s functional aesthetic.

· The Seagram Building helped usher in a new era of simple, straightforward skyscraper buildings in New York.

· When it was completed in 1958, the sleek, modern Seagram Building was an avant-garde statement that embodied its architects’ tenets “less is more” and “God is in the details.”

VH631500_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

VH631500_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe the subject matter of a work of art
VH631500_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the subject matter of the Great Altar of Zeus and Athena at Pergamon.
Response does accurately describe the subject matter of the Great Altar of Zeus and Athena at Pergamon.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· The frieze on the altar depicts the mythological battle of Olympian gods against the Giants for supremacy, the Gigantomachy.

· This choice of subject alludes to the victory of the Pergamenes, under leadership of Attalos I, over the Gauls.

· The gods represent the Pergamenes and the Giants are associated with the Gauls.

VH631500_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe the subject matter of a work of art
VH631500_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the subject matter of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the subject matter of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Column of Trajan

· The column frieze portrays Trajan’s two successful campaigns against the Dacians.

· The 1st Dacian conflict is depicted in the lower portion and the 2nd Dacian conflict is depicted towards the top of the column.

· Only ¼ of the scenes, 18 of 155, include battles. The remainder depict activities associated with military campaigns such as fortification construction, negotiations, religious sacrifices, and Trajan performing his duties.

· The column highlights the Romans’ discipline, religiosity, and technology as essential for defeating the Dacians.

Palette of King Narmer

· King Narmer, ruler of Upper Egypt, defeats leader and armies of Lower Egypt, unifying the region.

· Refers in a generalized way to unification of region, rather than specific historic moment.

· Refers to sacred battles of the sun god in relation Ancient Egyptian concepts of order and chaos in the cosmos as well as the king’s importance within the solar cycle. The king wears crown of Lower Egypt (Red) associated with battles of the sun god before dawn. He wears the crown of Upper Egypt (White) associated with bright light of mid-day as well as the moon and stars

VH631500_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning
VH631500_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity OR difference in how the imagery depicts the battle or conflict.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity OR difference in how the imagery depicts the battle or conflict.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Column of Trajan

Similarities:

· Both works are carved in relief accentuating the dynamic qualities of the battle.

· Both works were executed in marble and placed at an important public/political/religious site to heighten the propagandistic effect of the work.

· Both works present the victors as superior and in positions of power while the enemies are depicted in defeat and, while worthy opponents, their inferiority is emphasized.

Differences:

· The Great Altar uses a continuous frieze with life-size figures to depict the conflict. The Column of Trajan wraps the frieze around the column with small-scale depictions of multiple episodes from the campaign.

· The Great Altar presents a mythological battle as a metaphor for a historical conflict reinforcing divine associations and power. The Column of Trajan depicts historical military conquest with great detail highlighting Trajan’s prowess as leader in many roles.

· The Great Altar employs intense emotionalism of gesture, facial expression, and pose to stress the intensity of the battle and victory. The Column of Trajan employs copious detail and scenes other than battle providing a comprehensive view of the campaign.

· The Great Altar is an architectural structure and the continuous frieze allowed for an unobstructed view of the battle scene. The column was located within an architectural complex. The base would have been visible, but the battle reliefs were likely difficult to discern because of distance and obstructed views.

Palette of King Narmer

Similarities:

· Both works depict victors as upright, boldly executing enemies who are represented as inferior and/or in a pose of submission.

· Both works are carved in relief, the figures project forward from the background plane.

· The figures in both works employ idealized proportions and musculature to highlight heroic strength and/or formidable power of the victors and the worthiness of their opponents.

Differences:

· The Great Altar uses a continuous frieze with life-size figures to depict the conflict. The Palette of King Narmer is portable with small-scale depictions to depict the conflicts.

· The frieze from the Great Altar uses high relief to emphasize the drama of the battle. The Palette of Narmer employs low relief to highlight conceptual presentation of the subject.

· The continuous frieze on the Great Altar employs dramatic composition, contorted poses, emotional intensity, and projection into the viewer’s space. The Palette includes multiple registers as well as the combination of profile and composite views to ensure clarity of representation.

· The Great Altar is an architectural structure and the continuous frieze allowed for an unobstructed view of the battle scene. The Palette is a portable object, for ritual use in the temple, and would have been seen by a limited number of people.

VH631500_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art
VH631500_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain one similarity or difference in how the imagery of battles or conflicts in both works reinforces concepts of power or leadership.
Response does accurately explain one similarity in how the imagery of battles or conflicts in both works reinforces concepts of power or leadership.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Column of Trajan

· The public visibility for and location of both monuments emphasize to viewers the power and control of victors over those who have been conquered.

· Both reference aspects of the divine for leadership. Altar = its mythological battle as metaphor for earthly political conflict. Column = the emperor a divinely-approved ruler, essential to Roman security and prosperity.

· The victories depicted suggest stability and continued dominance of leaders in power
Palette of King Narmer

· Both connect victories of with divine power, human leaders aligned with the gods.

· Both connect victories with political stability, human leaders aligned with political power.

VH631500_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim
VH631500_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the Great Altar of Zeus and Athena at Pergamon in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the Great Altar of Zeus and Athena at Pergamon in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The altar was likely built on behalf of Eumenes II as a dedication to Zeus and Athena. Reinforces Pergamene power with reason and superiority, aligns the Gauls defeat with chaos and inferiority.

· Creation of the altar evokes the grandeur of the refurbishing of the Athenian Acropolis following the Persian Wars.

· The altar was built on a hill overlooking the city, the gods representing the Pergamene kings who wielded their semi-divine power over a diverse community, providing a constant reminder of their strength and stability.

VH631500_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim
VH631500_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.

Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the

explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Column of Trajan

· Trajan sponsored the forum and the people and Senate dedicated the column in his honor. The site, construction, dedication, as well as the riches utilized in the complex glorified Emperor Trajan, commemorated his military exploits, as well as the Roman Empire and the people.

· The column is part of a long standing Roman tradition of triumphant monuments permanently recording the strength, power, and importance of the Empire. Monuments such as the column are created in association with parades and celebrations that mark the victory, the column stands as a permanent reminder of the Emperor’s, Empire’s, and people’s victory.

Palette of King Narmer

· Narmer is depicted barefoot, with an attendant carrying his sandals, and additional imagery associated with the king, such as the gods Horus-falcon and Hathor-bull, reinforce the king’s divinity

· Unification of Upper and Lower Egypt associated with the establishing of dynastic rule for kings and, later, pharaohs. Motif repeated several times, Narmer’s execution of foe, Narmer depicting in crowns of Upper and Lower Egypt, Horus with the papyrus, entwined necks of mythological creatures.

· The Palette makes reference to the Egyptian concepts of cosmic order in which the king is a divine figure. The depiction of the king wearing different crowns demonstrates to his connectedness to the sun god and the daily solar cycle.

· Palettes originated in domestic use, but others were created for use in temple rituals that served the gods. Object is portable (25” high), perhaps used for grinding pigments/makeup for temple statues. At a later date, this work was ritually buried.

VH902903_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe form, style, materials, technique, or content.
VH902903_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one technique used in the creation of the Greek vase.
Response accurately describes one technique used in the creation of the Greek vase.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The vase was formed using a potter’s wheel to create a symmetrical object with walls of even thickness.

· Charcoal lines were drawn to create the designs. These would burn off later during firing.

· The vase is painted with slip with a soft brush to create varied lines and large black shapes.

· The vase was fired in a three-step firing process to create what is known as the red-figure technique.

· Figures are placed on different levels, showing a shift away from defined registers.

o.af:

· Figures are placed in a continuous band around the vase, suggesting a panoramic view.

· Rather than placing all of the figures on a single ground line, they are being shown on several levels to suggest that some are further away than others in space. The placement contributes to a sense of an unfolding narrative.

· Figures often overlap, suggesting a field of depth.

· Lines painted within the forms exhibit great detail, demonstrating the artist’s knowledge of human anatomy.

· The application of slip around and within the figures allows for graceful contours that suggest movement and varied poses, all the better to present different events in the narrative.

· The narrative is framed by ornamental decorative patterns above and below the scene.

Response does accurately explain how the techniques are typical of Greek vase painting during the fifth century B.C.E.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The red-figure technique, through its emphasis on positive and negative space, was typically employed by Greek artists during this period to create dramatic contrast in narrative scenes.

· The shape of the krater, with its broad body and base, wide mouth, and volute-shaped handles, is also characteristic of the period.

· The varied poses and irregular placements of the figures typify an interest in experimenting with the human form and positioning in space.

· Ornamental decorative patterns, such as the meander pattern, are typical of narrative vase painting during this period.

VH905787_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
o.af:
Examples of possible claims might include the following:

Great Pyramids (Menkaura, Khafre, Khufu)

· The Great Pyramids of Giza demonstrate the central belief of ancient Egyptian culture that existence does not end at death but continues in the afterlife.

· The Great Pyramids of Giza demonstrate the central belief of ancient Egyptian culture in the eternal nature of the pharaoh’s authority and rulership, which extends beyond death.

· The Great Pyramids of Giza were shaped to reinforce the deceased pharaoh’s eternal royalty, divinity, and power through a combination of sculpture and architecture.

Mortuary temple of Hatshepsut

· The mortuary temple of Hatshepsut demonstrates the central belief of ancient Egyptian culture that existence does not end at death but continues in the afterlife.

· The mortuary temple of Hatshepsut demonstrates the central belief of ancient Egyptian culture in the eternal nature of the pharaoh’s authority and rulership, which extends beyond death.

· The mortuary temple of Hatshepsut was designed to reinforce the deceased pharaoh’s eternal royalty, divinity, and power through a combination of sculpture and architecture.

VH905787_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C EVIDENCE: EVIDENCE: VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH905787_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
Response accomplishes one part of this task.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Great Pyramids (Menkaura, Khafre, Khufu)

· The complex functioned as a necropolis created exclusively for ceremonies and rituals for three deceased pharaohs.

· Focal points of the complex are the three Great Pyramids, each of which was built to serve as the tomb for an Egyptian pharaoh after his death and contains an interior tomb chamber connected to multiple long, narrow passageways.

· The three Great Pyramids are monumental in size and constructed from locally quarried stone.

· The pyramids were built over a square base with four triangular sides that were originally smooth and finished with polished limestone.

· Each pyramid’s sides are oriented to the cardinal directions.

· Each pyramid is connected to a mortuary temple and is linked by a causeway to a valley temple on the banks of the Nile River, with the valley temple acting as the site of funerary rituals and commemorative ceremonies in honor of the deceased rulers.

· All structures that are part of the royal funerary complex contained sculptures depicting the pharaoh and the gods.

· Khafre’s pyramid is attached to the Great Sphinx, which is believed to be a portrait of the pharaoh in royal costume with the body of a crouching lion.

Mortuary temple of Hatshepsut

· The mortuary temple is part of a necropolis created exclusively for deceased pharaohs Hatshepsut, Thutmose III, and Mentuhotep II.

· The mortuary temple is located one mile from Hatshepsut’s tomb in the Valley of the Kings. The temple is larger than her tomb.

· The primary structure is embedded into the slope of the hillside or the natural landscape.

· The temple is laid out on an axial plan, with a central causeway originally lined with sculptures. The causeway extends from the Nile River to the temple located on the upper terrace.

· The temple structures are made of stone walls with flat roofs supported by colonnades.

· Interior spaces and chapels are hypostyle halls.

· The temple has three terraces connected by long, straight, central stepped ramps.

· The temple contains a small rock-cut chamber.

· The terraces and courtyards were originally planted with gardens.

· The complex originally included sculptures depicting the pharaoh and the gods.

· The mortuary temple was meant to be a permanent fixture that demonstrated beliefs about the nature of eternal life that existed after death.

o.d: Response accomplishes both parts of this task.

Great Pyramids (Menkaura, Khafre, Khufu)

· The complex functioned as a necropolis created exclusively for ceremonies and rituals for three deceased pharaohs.

Mortuary temple of Hatshepsut

· The mortuary temple is located one mile from Hatshepsut’s tomb in the Valley of the Kings. The temple is larger than her tomb.

VH905787_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Great Pyramids (Menkaura, Khafre, Khufu)

· The layout and design of structures and causeways symbolize the pharaoh’s divinity and his journey to the afterlife.

· Ancient Egyptians believed that the soul lives on after death, and they developed rituals and processes such as mummification to preserve the body of the deceased for the afterlife. When a pharaoh died, his body was prepared in the palace and transported to the valley temple, carried up the causeway to the funerary temple, and entombed inside the burial chamber of the pyramid, where it would be well protected.

· At the funerary temple, priests provided the soul of the pharaoh with food and worshipped the king after his death.

· The shape and orientation of the pyramids were meant to emphasize the symbolic connection between the deceased pharaohs and the sun god Re (also acceptable: Ra) and the pharaoh’s journey to the afterlife. For example, the pyramids are symbols of the sun as well as of the sun god Re.

· The sides of each pyramid converge at the center, orienting the building upward toward the sun/sky.

· The sloped sides of the pyramids represent or symbolize the rays of the sun, which are described in pyramid texts as a ladder over which the deceased pharaoh ascends to the heavens to join the sun god Re.

· The orientation of the site and structures follows the path of the sun, which represents the transformation of the deceased pharaoh from mortal to god or demigod.

· The pyramids are places of rebirth for the pharaohs, just as the sun is “reborn” each morning following the night.

· The funerary temples are oriented towards the rising sun, further emphasizing the connection between the pharaoh and the sun god.

Mortuary temple of Hatshepsut

· The complex was the site of funerary rituals and commemorative ceremonies that reinforced symbolic connections between the deceased pharaoh and the gods, especially the sun god Re (also called Ra) and Horus.

· The layout and design of structures and causeways are meant to symbolize the soul’s journey to the afterlife.

· Funerary rituals and commemoration ceremonies processed along a central axis that extended through and beyond the walls of the complex, which created physical and symbolic connections between the land of the living and the land of the dead.

· Once a year, the statue of the god Amun-Re was taken from the temple at Thebes and transported across the river to the mortuary temple of Hatshepsut, in a ritual that was meant to recreate and renew the journey or transition from life to death.

· The causeway of the temple displayed portraits of Hatshepsut as a sphinx and in a kneeling pose presenting offerings to Amun-Re, which reinforced her divine status and immortality.

· The larger scale of the mortuary temple emphasizes ritual practice and commemoration over entombment.

· The contrast of the rough natural landscape and the sharp geometry of the temple symbolizes the eternal stability of Hatshepsut’s reign beyond her death.

VH905787_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, developing any of the following:

Great Pyramids (Menkaura, Khafre, Khufu)

· The form of the pyramid bears a connection to the ancient benben stone, which served as an emblem of the sun god Re, whose rays were believed to be used by the deceased to ascend, as if on a ladder, to the heavens.

· The form is also connected with the ancient tradition of mastabas, which were an earlier form of tombs in the region.

· Traditionally, among the grave goods kept in the pyramids would have been a copy of the ancient Egyptian Book of the Dead to guide the deceased on the journey to the afterlife. This text explains specific ancient Egyptian cultural beliefs about death and mortality that are exemplified on a grander scale by the pyramids.

Mortuary temple of Hatshepsut

· Having a monumental mortuary temple that reinforced the deceased pharaoh’s eternal royalty, divinity, and power may have been particularly pertinent for Hatshepsut in her unique role as a female pharaoh.

· After Hatshepsut’s death, her son Thutmose III ordered that portraits of Hatshepsut be destroyed, making her immense funerary temple all the more important as an enduring memorial to her reign.

· The actions of Hatshepsut’s son to erase evidence of her reign suggests that Egyptian beliefs about death and mortality may have been more nuanced and complex, possibly subject to change depending on the perspectives of subsequent rulers.

· The detachment of Hatshepsut’s temple from her tomb and the larger scale of the temple compared with the tomb are an inversion of the conventions of Old Kingdom funerary architecture and represent innovation.

VH911003_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
o.af:
Examples of possible claims might include the following:

Athenian agora

· The design of the agora encouraged citizens to discuss ideas and to participate in the government of their city.

· The open spaces included in the design of the agora promoted the exchange of ideas, which led to the development of Athenian democracy.

· The agora was designed to provide a space for the citizens of Athens to discuss business, government, and the philosophical issues of the day and thereby reinforced ideas of a participatory government that led to the development of Athenian democracy.

Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)

· The Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) was designed as an expression of the power and reach of the Roman Empire.

· The Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) was designed as an expression of the power of the Roman Empire and of the role its citizens played within that power apparatus.

· The Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) was designed as an expression of the stability and order established by the government of the Roman Empire and the resulting prosperity and advancements from which its citizens benefited.

Forum of Trajan

· The design of the Forum of Trajan glorifies the strength and power of the Roman Empire.

· The design of the Forum of Trajan glorifies the power of the Roman Empire and the superiority of Roman civilization.

· The design of the Forum of Trajan celebrates the status of the Roman emperor Trajan as caretaker of the citizens of Rome and protector of peace and order in the Roman Empire.

· The design of the Forum of Trajan glorifies the achievements of the Roman emperor Trajan in order to demonstrate his legitimacy as a ruler while also celebrating the greatness of the Roman Empire and Roman civilization.

· Although Roman emperors held a lot of power, they were also considered servants of the empire and the Roman people. Glorifying Trajan’s military accomplishments in the service of the empire demonstrated the emperor’s divine favor and underscored his legitimacy as leader of the Roman state.

VH911003_rubric_category_2.ti: Part C: EVIDENCE - VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH911003_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Athenian agora

· The agora was a large, open gathering space located below the Acropolis in the center of Athens where Athenian citizens came to trade ideas as well as goods.

· The agora was surrounded by several buildings that promoted public discourse. Among them the following:

· Stoas, a Greek building type that was often used to frame Greek agoras, buildings with covered walkways

· The council chamber (bouleuterion), which was the meeting place of the 500-member Athenian boule or citizen council, a covered, rectilinear building with stepped seating arranged around a lower-lying area designed for the speakers

· A tholos, a building type with a circular ground plan, where the 50-member executive council met

Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)

· The Colosseum was built by the Flavian emperors for the Roman people as an arena for entertainment.

· The Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) was a massive, oval, freestanding amphitheater capable of seating at least 50,000 spectators, making it the largest amphitheater in the ancient Mediterranean.

· The vast size and efficient design of the Colosseum was made possible through Roman technological innovations in concrete that allowed them to engineer structures on a much larger scale than previously possible.

· The exterior rises in four levels, each with a different architectural order (Tuscan, Ionic, Corinthian) that corresponds with interior seating levels.

· There are seventy-six entryways for ordinary spectators plus four additional ones for the emperor and other elites to direct large masses of visitors.

· Design of the seating area provided optimal visibility of the event in the arena for all spectators regardless of their position in the ranks.

· The substructure includes tunnels and chambers that could house animals, combatants, and performers as well as elaborate stage mechanisms that facilitated theatrical appearances of animals and people in the arena.

Forum of Trajan

· The forum was located next to the earlier fora of Julius Caesar and Augustus.

· The complex of the forum included the following:

· A large gateway at the entrance to the forum that resembled a triumphal arch

· A main plaza, flanked by covered colonnades, whose sculptural program included statues of captive Dacians, a large equestrian statue of emperor Trajan, and military standards

· The Basilica Ulpia, which closed off the north end of the plaza and served as a law court and other civic functions

· Two libraries behind the basilica, which housed manuscripts in Greek and Latin and flanked a small courtyard that contained the column of Trajan

· The column of Trajan was decorated with a narrative frieze illustrating Emperor Trajan’s successful military campaigns against the Dacians

· A temple or shrine to the deified emperor Trajan

o.d: Response provides two specific examples of visual and/or contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Athenian agora

· The agora was a large, open gathering space located below the acropolis in the center of Athens where Athenian citizens came to trade ideas as well as goods.

· The agora was surrounded by several buildings that promoted public discourse. Among them the following:

· Stoas, a Greek building type that was often used to frame Greek agoras, buildings with covered walkways

· The council chamber (bouleuterion), which was the meeting place of the 500-member Athenian boule or citizen council, a covered, rectilinear building with stepped seating arranged around a lower-lying area designed for the speakers

· A tholos, a building type with a circular ground plan, where the 50-member executive council met

Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)

· The Colosseum was built by the Flavian emperors for the Roman people as an arena for entertainment.

· The Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) was a massive, oval, freestanding amphitheater capable of seating at least 50,000 spectators, making it the largest amphitheater in the ancient Mediterranean.

· The vast size and efficient design of the Colosseum was made possible through Roman technological innovations in concrete that allowed them to engineer structures on a much larger scale than previously possible.

· The exterior rises in four levels, each with a different architectural order (Tuscan, Ionic, Corinthian) that corresponds with interior seating levels.

· There are seventy-six entryways for ordinary spectators plus four additional ones for the emperor and other elites to direct large masses of visitors.

· Design of the seating area provided optimal visibility of the event in the arena for all spectators regardless of their position in the ranks.

· The substructure includes tunnels and chambers that could house animals, combatants, and performers as well as elaborate stage mechanisms that facilitated theatrical appearances of animals and people in the arena.

Forum of Trajan

· The forum was located next to the earlier fora of Julius Caesar and Augustus.

· The complex of the forum included the following:

· A large gateway at the entrance to the forum that resembled a triumphal arch

· A main plaza, flanked by covered colonnades, whose sculptural program included statues of captive Dacians, a large equestrian statue of emperor Trajan, and military standards

· The Basilica Ulpia, which closed off the north end of the plaza and served as a law court and other civic functions

· Two libraries behind the basilica, which housed manuscripts in Greek and Latin and flanked a small courtyard that contained the column of Trajan

· The column of Trajan was decorated with a narrative frieze illustrating Emperor Trajan’s successful military campaigns against the Dacians

· A temple or shrine to the deified emperor Trajan

VH911003_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Athenian agora

· The literal meaning of the word agora is “gathering place” or “assembly,” and it served as the focal point of public life in ancient Athens.

· The physical placement of the agora below the sacred acropolis emphasizes that the agora’s main concern was earthly rather than spiritual.

· The agora was a place where eligible Athenian citizens voted over public affairs; pottery shards have been excavated from the site that were inscribed with information related to public leaders.

· The agora was a meeting place for important governing bodies of Athens, such as the Athenian citizen council (boule), which represented the citizens of Athens in decisions about public affairs and the executive council.

· The shaded walkways of the stoas provided space for meetings of friends and the exchange of ideas and were frequented by philosophers, such as Socrates.

Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)

· The vast size of the Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater) is meant to symbolize the vastness and power of the Roman Empire, which at its height controlled large parts of southern Europe and the Mediterranean region.

· The orderly and efficient design allowed for optimal crowd control and the comfort of the spectators.

· The design of the aesthetically pleasing exterior also signaled the wealth, power, and order of the Roman civilization and its government: in other words, the significance of the people of Rome.

· Social distinctions were emphasized through an architectural organization that separated the classes so that the most important citizens were placed closest to the arena (such as the emperor, priests, and citizens who held high offices), whereas the higher areas were reserved for those deemed less important (such as women, slaves, and foreigners), thereby reinforcing Roman ideas of social order.

· In building such a splendid structure as a gift for the people of the city of Rome and providing free, elaborate entertainment for all inhabitants of Rome, the Flavian emperors demonstrated that they were the friends and caretakers of the Roman populace as a whole.

Forum of Trajan

· The sculptural imagery found throughout the forum emphasizes Roman militarism and communicates Trajan’s military success against the Dacians.

· The massive basilica exalts the emperor by bearing his family name and placing him at the center of the justice meted out by the court of law located within.

· The inclusion of libraries expresses that Trajan is a man of learning in addition to being a successful military leader.

· Pervasive use of imported marble and gilded statues gives a sense of elegance to the forum, suggesting Trajan’s elevated status.

· Placement of the forum next to the fora of earlier emperors places Trajan’s success and accomplishments on an imperial continuum.

· The inclusion of a temple or shrine to the deified Trajan after his death shows the status of the emperor in the Roman state and the importance that was given to a “good” emperor.

VH911003_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, developing any of the following:

Athenian agora

· The ancient Athenian understanding of democracy was different from our modern understanding: although the agora reinforced ideals of participatory government, only a small percentage of the ancient Athenian population (e.g., male citizens) had the right to participate in the democratic process.

· Although the agora also contained a few temples (such as the Hephaisteion, which stood on a hill on the west side of the agora), its function was centered on secular matters of the city-state.

· Although the agora was originally a marketplace, buildings for administrative and government use were gradually added over time, as the political system of the city-state of Athens developed and changed (for example, actual Athenian democracy was relatively short-lived, but the agora was used over many centuries as a center for civic life).

Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)

· The often-bloody entertainments that took place in the Colosseum (Flavian Amphitheater)—and which included exotic animals as well as theatrically staged executions of convicted criminals—may have demonstrated the power of the Roman Empire, but the entertainments also illustrated Rome’s brutality at this time.

· The seating that emphasized social distinctions marginalized certain members of the Roman Empire, such as women and slaves, showing that Rome’s power included the ability to elevate or lower the status of certain groups.

· The Flavian emperors chose land for the site that had been annexed by the previous emperor, Nero, for his private use. In returning the land to the Roman people and making it a public space, the Flavians were aligning themselves with the Romans they ruled, arguably positioning themselves as precursors to the five “good” emperors.

Forum of Trajan

· The building of imperial fora was in some ways a competitive endeavor, with each emperor trying to outshine his predecessors to show that he was the most powerful of the Roman emperors. The Forum of Trajan was the final and last of these imperial fora and can be interpreted as an effort on the part of Trajan to show that he was greater and more powerful than earlier emperors Caesar, Augustus, and Vespasian, whose fora are located nearby.

· The design of the Forum of Trajan is connected to the tradition of erecting triumphal monuments and holding victory ceremonies to celebrate Roman military leaders who had achieved an important victory, otherwise called a “triumph.” In the time of the Roman Empire, these monuments and ceremonies were political statements that celebrated the person of the emperor as well as the greatness of the Roman Empire and Roman civilization as a whole.

· The Senate decided after Emperor Trajan’s death to place the emperor’s ashes inside the base of the Column of Trajan in the forum, showing how important the Senate believed his military accomplishments were to both his rule and his legacy after death.

VH911019_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use one example of specific visual evidence to explain how the visual characteristics contribute to a sense of architectural space.
Response accurately uses one example of specific visual evidence to explain how the visual characteristics contribute to a sense of architectural space.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· One-point (linear) perspective creates the illusion of recession in space by using vanishing points.

· Atmospheric (aerial) perspective creates spatial depth by softening focus and/or color saturation.

· Trompe l’oeil panels and columns use illusionism to exist seemingly within the actual interior space and to create a sense that the. architectural elements are outside the walls on which they are painted

· Chiaroscuro was used to model architectural forms in order to suggest three dimensions.

o.d: accurately uses two examples of specific visual evidence to explain how the visual characteristics contribute to a sense of architectural space.
o.af:
· One-point (linear) perspective creates the illusion of recession in space by using vanishing points.

· Atmospheric (aerial) perspective creates spatial depth by softening focus and/or color saturation.

· Trompe l’oeil panels and columns use illusionism to exist seemingly within the actual interior space and to create a sense that the architectural elements are outside the walls on which they are painted.

· Chiaroscuro was used to model architectural forms in order to suggest three dimensions.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain how visual characteristics of the work are typical of ancient Roman wall painting.
Response does accurately explain how visual characteristics of the work are typical of ancient Roman wall painting.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Fresco paintings were typically used for the large-scale decoration of interior walls, as can be seen in both the Villa of Publius Fannius Synistor at Boscoreale and the House of the Vettii at Pompeii.

· These frescoes often depict cityscapes of buildings designed in the classical style.

· The architectural elements that are depicted express Roman interest in and enthusiasm for Greek art and architecture.

· Painting lavish, illusionistic architectural elements is an expression of Roman wall painting in the Second Style.
