VH913634_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH913634_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the imagery of the Arnolfini Portrait.
Response does accurately describe the imagery of the Arnolfini Portrait.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· A husband and wife stand side by side, her hand in his.

· Both wear rich, fur-lined clothes.

· They are surrounded with the belongings of a wealthy couple, such as a chandelier, sandals, a dog, a richly hung bed, a draped and cushioned chair, and a mirror.

· An open window allows light to fall into the room, creating highlights and shadows.

· The artist’s signature is written across the back wall, and he may also be reflected in the mirror.

· The mirror is surrounded by scenes from the Passion, and a rosary hangs beside it.

VH913634_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH913634_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the imagery of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the imagery of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici

· At the center of the composition, a framed portrait of Marie de’ Medici is held by Cupid and Hymen.

· Henri IV, king of France, dressed in armor, gazes at the portrait.

· A personification of France urges the king forward.

· Two putti play with discarded pieces of armor, while deep in the background and set into the landscape, a city destroyed in some armed conflict burns.

· Above Marie de’ Medici float the Roman gods Jupiter and Hera, flanked by birds symbolizing their characteristics, an eagle and a peacock.

Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo

· A couple stand in an undefined space, with a baby and a servant child between them; the servant child is carrying the baby.

· Both of the adults are richly dressed in garments that indicate their origins: the man wears European suiting, a frilled shirt, and a powdered wig and carries a hat; the woman wears a traditional dress for a native of Mexico and Central America.

· The man lifts his hand in an affectionate gesture toward the small child while the woman gestures toward both the child and the servant as if presenting them.

· An inscription between the adults indicates what caste is represented.

The Tête à Tête

· A husband and wife sit in a lavish, spacious interior, surrounded by possessions that signify wealth, such as paintings, furniture, carpets, a china tea or coffee set, a musical instrument, a chandelier, and a fire screen.

· Each wears luxurious aristocratic clothing, frilled and beribboned.

· Servants, including a dismayed accountant carrying a stack of bills and a yawning man who attempts to clean up the disordered dining room, attend them.

· The husband and wife seem exhausted—the wife leans back on a chair with her legs spread and stretches her arms, a mirror in one hand, and the husband sits collapsed on a chair, legs also spread.

· The husband has a large spot on his neck, a sign of syphilis.

· Discarded items litter the floor, including a sword, a music book, a game board and instructions, and cards, contributing to the general disorder of the scene.

VH913634_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH913634_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the imagery of the two works depicts marriage and relationships.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the imagery of the two works depicts marriage and relationships.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici

· In both cases the married (or soon to be married) couple are shown as wealthy and well-dressed members of the elite.

· Both painters use symbolic animals (birds, dog) to show character traits of those in the painting.

· Both painters have inserted religious imagery into the portraits of these couples, one Christian and the other classical.

· In both cases the painter uses symbolism, such as the cupids, birds, chariot, and personification in the Rubens painting, or the dog, oranges, St. Margaret finial, and mirror framed in Passion scenes in the van Eyck painting, to interpret the meaning of the marriage shown.

Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo

· In both cases the husband and wife are shown together, as a couple, and both are richly dressed, showing their prosperity.

· Both works emphasize the importance of offspring in a marriage, whether subtly, by using symbolism (van Eyck), or overtly by showing the child (Juárez).

· Both use gesture to indicate relationships, although the meaning of each gesture is not always transparent.

The Tête à Tête

· Both paintings depict prosperous interiors that demonstrate wealth and high social standing.

· Both include Christian imagery, the St. Margaret finial and Passion paintings on the mirror in the case of the van Eyck and the standing saint paintings hanging in the back room in the case of the Hogarth.

· Both marriages are set in the context of Christian expectations of marriage, though only one satisfies them.

· Both include dogs that comment on the action, in the van Eyck a dog standing before the couple who represents fidelity and in the Hogarth a small dog who seems intent on revealing infidelity.

VH913634_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH913634_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the imagery of the two works depicts marriage and relationships.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the imagery of the two works depicts marriage and relationships.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici

· The setting of each image emphasizes the sphere in which each couple belongs: Jan van Eyck’s prosperous merchant couple in their well-appointed home, their primary domain, and the French king in a landscape that symbolizes the realm that he governs.

· Van Eyck uses overtly Christian symbolism, whereas Rubens uses symbolism taken from classical mythology to depict the responsibilities of marriage.

· The van Eyck shows the couple in the same space, their home, whereas Rubens shows the king in person, but his future wife is depicted in a portrait, as they have not yet met, signaling that their marriage is diplomatically arranged.

· In the Van Eyck painting the husband (the likely patron) addresses the viewer with his gaze and perhaps his gesture, acknowledging the viewer, while the wife’s eyes are demurely lowered. In the Rubens painting the husband gazes at the portrait of his wife and gestures in surprise (or joy) while the wife (who was the patron) gazes outwards at the viewer from her portrait, expressing her agency.

Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo

· The Arnolfini portrait is intended to represent actual people in their actual (or ideal) relationship, whereas the Juárez painting is intended to show a type or class of marriage, not an actual couple.

· The Arnolfini portrait shows the couple in their environment, surrounding them with accessories that indicate their success and their religious beliefs. The Juárez painting includes nothing (other than clothing) to show how the couple lived or what religion they practiced.

· The Arnolfini portrait may hint at children to come, but it doesn’t show any, whereas the Juárez painting shows the child who is the result of the marriage. It also includes a servant, which is not included in the Arnolfini portrait.

The Tête à Tête

· The van Eyck depicts a successful, pious marriage; the two are depicted as joined in a successful marriage based on their gestures and surroundings, including the Christian objects. The Hogarth depicts a debauched, unhappy marriage, with a husband and wife who virtually ignore each other and a spill of playthings that surrounds them.

· The painting by Van Eyck shows a middle class merchant interior, a compressed space full of bedroom furniture, whereas the painting by Hogarth shows a large, aristocratic interior.

· The work by Van Eyck likely shows an actual couple, whereas the work by Hogarth depicts an invented narrative with fictitious and symbolic characters.

· In both cases the couples are shown in what at that time would have been considered a public room, but they are different rooms: the van Eyck shows a bedroom, whereas the Hogarth shows a dining/sitting room suite. The van Eyck bedroom may be a subtle nod to the purpose of this marriage: Christian procreation. The dining/sitting room combination in the Hogarth indicates the life of revelry and diversion enjoyed by the couple.

· In the van Eyck painting, the trappings of Christianity, the prayer beads, the mirror with Passion scenes, and the St. Margaret finial are used as signals of Christian piety, while Hogarth uses various symbols to signal the impiety of the couple.

VH913634_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH913634_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one difference in the cultural attitudes communicated by the two works about marriage and relationships.
Response does accurately explain one difference in the cultural attitudes communicated by the two works about marriage and relationships.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici

· The Arnolfini portrait shows marriage as a personal relationship whereas the Marie de’ Medici image shows marriage as a political relationship.

· Although both images represent marriages that were arranged, each image references different motivations for the arrangement of the marriage it depicts.

Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo

· The Arnolfini portrait showcases a marriage that satisfied social norms, whereas the Juárez painting is focused on the concern that some marriages could upset the established order of society.

The Tête à Tête

· The van Eyck painting represents a marriage that conforms with cultural attitudes of piety and modesty, whereas Hogarth’s work satirizes a marriage that has abandoned piety and modesty.

· Van Eyck portrays a couple in a successful marriage, whereas Hogarth portrays a marriage as unsuccessful.

· While the van Eyck painting uses symbolism to support the idea that marriage was a holy union that brought prosperity and offspring, the Hogarth uses symbolism to show that overriding the natural inclination to marry for love in favor of marriage for material interests will ultimately lead to disaster.

VH913634_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH913634_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the Arnolfini Portrait in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the Arnolfini Portrait in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Some scholars have suggested that the painting was intended as a kind of visual marriage contract, with Jan van Eyck as its witness, or a prospective picture of a betrothal before the transfer of the dowry.

· At the time that the Arnolfini portrait was painted, the chief duty of a wife was to provide and raise children.

· The bedroom was a public room at that time, and the luxurious items in it would have been part of a meaningful display of wealth.

· The painting contains symbols related to fidelity and fertility.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Marriage was then considered a pious, Christian state, and wives were expected to be modest and prayerful, signaled by the rosary and mirror frame.

· Wives displayed the economic success of their husbands by wearing expensive garments, such as the voluminous and fur-trimmed dress worn by the woman here.

· A prosperous merchant like Arnolfini would likely have married someone much younger, preferably from another wealthy family and provided with a dowry, and expected her to bear many children. Her hand, resting on the mound of lifted drapery, may have been intended to remind the viewer of the expected pregnancies.

VH913634_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH913634_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Most of Marie de’ Medici’s role as wife and widow was to work on behalf of the country and dynasty, much of which she did alone.

· The marriage of Marie de’ Medici and Henri IV was diplomatically arranged for financial, dynastic, and patriotic reasons.

· The painting cycle was intended to be publicly displayed in the Palais de Luxembourg to communicate the sanctioned story of Marie de’ Medici’s life.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The imagery of the work can be interpreted as showing both divine and civic approval for this marriage match, as Henri is urged toward his future bride from above and behind.

· Marie de’ Medici, a foreigner and the patron of these paintings, sought to recast her role as protector of the dynasty and defender of French interests after her husband died and she became regent for her son. Rubens therefore includes images of antique deities as well as a personification of France in order to signal divine and political approval for Marie de’ Medici’s marriage to Henri IV.

· The painting portrays a one-sided representation of events rather than the more complicated reality of Marie de’ Medici’s life, by showing various figures demonstrating approval of her marriage and ignoring the conflicts with her family and her husband’s court.

Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· The tension related to interracial marriages that underlies the creation of casta paintings was a direct result of Spain's colonial activities.

· This work was likely one of a set of paintings that created a taxonomy of people based on their racial origins.

· This work may have been intended to be given to an aristocrat or sent back to Spain to be used as instruction about the dangers of intermarriage.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The depiction of an interracial couple in Juárez’ painting is typical of Casta paintings, which were a genre of paintings that were intended to show the outcomes of relationships between people of different races or backgrounds.

· The depiction of an interracial couple in Juárez’ painting illustrates perceived concerns of immigrants to New Spain, and Spaniards still in Spain, as they became more anxious about issues related to racial mixing in New Spain, where these paintings proliferated.

The Tête à Tête

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· The Hogarth painting comes from a suite of six paintings that traced the unhappy series of events resulting from an arranged marriage.

· The content of the Hogarth painting was directed primarily at the merchant classes, as it was intended to be transformed into a print and then sold commercially to reach a wider audience.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The series as a whole served as a commentary on the decline of the aristocracy and its attempts to shore up family fortunes by arranged marriages to newly prosperous merchant families rather than allowing their children to marry for love, by showing the unhappy outcome of a marriage of convenience.

VH928184_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH928184_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the content of the religious narrative that is referenced or depicted in the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa.
Response does accurately describe the content of the religious narrative that is referenced or depicted in the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· Saint Teresa is shown swooning as an angel is about to pierce her with a bronze spear or arrow.

· Saint Teresa is shown experiencing a spiritual vision.

VH928184_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH928184_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not describe the content of the religious narrative that is referenced or depicted in the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the content of the religious narrative that is referenced or depicted in the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Röttgen Pietà

· The Virgin Mary is shown grieving over the body of Christ after the events of the Crucifixion and before the burial.

Lamentation from the Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel

· Mary, John, and Christ’s followers are shown mourning over his dead body after the Crucifixion.

Isenheim altarpiece, closed

· Christ’s Crucifixion is shown with Christ suspended on the cross and his followers (John the Evangelist, John the Baptist, Mary Magdalene, and the Virgin Mary) looking on.

VH928184_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH928184_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the two works represent the religious narrative.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the two works represent the religious narrative.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Röttgen Pietà

· Both works are sculptures showing two figures: one reclining and one in an upright position.

· The reclining figures in both are posed in an expression of pain, with head thrown back and mouth open. The upright figures in both gaze toward the reclining figures.

· Both works show figures with emotional expressions.

Lamentation from the Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel

· In both works, the main figure is shown reclining while the other figure or figures in the group gaze at them.

· Both works use strong diagonals to direct the viewer’s attention. In Giotto’s work, the diagonal of the rock leads to the grouping around Christ, while the implied and actual diagonals of the angel’s body direct attention to Teresa.

· Both works show figures with emotional expressions.

Isenheim altarpiece, closed

· Both works emphasize the drama of the scenes through the use of strong contrasts of light and dark.

· Both works use strong diagonals to create a sense of drama and motion.

· In both works the emotional content of the scene is signaled by the dramatic swooning posture of a female figure.

VH928184_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH928184_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the two works represent the religious narrative.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the two works represent the religious narrative.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Röttgen Pietà

· The Röttgen Pietà has Christ placed on Mary’s lap, creating a compact figural group, whereas the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa separates the two figures, with the angel standing over Saint Teresa.

· Christ is dead and shows signs of physical torment on his body, with gaping, bleeding hand, foot, and side wounds, a crown of thorns, and a bleeding forehead. Teresa’s pain is psychological, and her expression can also be understood as eroticized.

· Mary’s face demonstrates sorrow and concern, whereas the angel smiles at Teresa.

Lamentation from the Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel

· Ecstasy of Saint Teresa shows only two figures within a limited setting, whereas Lamentation shows a large group of figures in an outdoor setting.

· The figures in Lamentation depict a wide array of emotional responses to the event through their facial expressions and dramatic gestures. The figures in Ecstasy of Saint Teresa convey less strong emotions through their facial expressions, while the dramatic drapery worn by Saint Teresa heightens the visionary quality of the scene.

· Giotto’s scene occurs in a landscape setting with blue sky, a rocky outcrop, and a tree, whereas Bernini’s figures occupy a supernaturally charged space with dramatic light effects.

Isenheim altarpiece, closed

· The Crucifixion is dominated by the central placement of the figure of Christ, who is shown physically larger than his followers. The focus of Ecstasy of Saint Teresa is on both figures because of the compositional balancing of both figures.

· The Crucifixion shows the scene occurring in a deep outdoor setting with several figures observing. Ecstasy of Saint Teresa is a more intimate scene between two protagonists that occurs in an undefined setting.

· Christ is dead and shows signs of physical torment through the greenish-grey hue of his body with numerous small cuts, bleeding hand, foot, and side wounds, a crown of thorns, and a bleeding forehead. Saint Teresa’s pain is psychological, and her expression can also be understood as eroticized.

· The faces of Christ’s followers demonstrate sorrow and grief, whereas the angel smiles at Teresa.

VH928184_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulates a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH928184_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one difference in how both works elicit an emotional response from the viewer.
Response does accurately explain one difference in how both works elicit an emotional response from the viewer.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Röttgen Pietà

· The Röttgen Pietà portrays suffering and the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa portrays religious ecstasy to elicit an emotional response.

· Viewers of the Röttgen Pietà were expected to empathize with Mary’s sorrow and feel sadness over Christ’s physical torment after viewing the physical marks of his suffering and Mary’s sorrowful expression. Viewers of Ecstasy of Saint Teresa were intended to be immersed in the experience of Teresa’s vision and, similarly, spiritually transformed by the visually overwhelming experience of standing in the chapel.

Lamentation from the Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel

· Giotto’s Lamentation portrays sorrow and the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa portrays religious ecstasy to elicit an emotional response.

· Giotto’s work was intended to create a sense of empathy among viewers who could identify with the sorrow and grief shown in the bodies and faces of Christ’s followers. Viewers of Ecstasy of Saint Teresa were intended to be immersed in the experience of Saint Teresa’s vision and, similarly, spiritually transformed by the visually overwhelming experience of standing in the chapel.

Isenheim altarpiece, closed

· Grünewald’s Crucifixion panel from the Isenheim altarpiece portrays suffering and the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa portrays religious ecstasy to elicit an emotional response.

· Viewers of the Crucifixion from the Isenheim altarpiece were expected to empathize with the sorrow of Christ’s followers and feel sadness over Christ’s physical torment after viewing the physical marks of his suffering and the sorrowful expressions of his followers. Viewers of Ecstasy of Saint Teresa were intended to be immersed in the experience of Saint Teresa’s vision and, similarly, spiritually transformed by the visually overwhelming experience of standing in the chapel.

VH928184_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH928184_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual or contextual evidence about the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific visual or contextual evidence about the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· The narrative is taken from Saint Teresa’s autobiography, in which she described experiencing the mystical vision depicted here. She described the experience as bringing her both pain and ecstasy and also bringing her into a mystical union with God.

· Saint Teresa was a Carmelite nun who attempted to reform the church by bringing more meaning into spiritual ritual through intense meditation leading to mystical experience.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The work was done during the Catholic Counter-Reformation, when works of art were designed to encourage active participation on the part of the viewers and appeal to multiple senses, which explains why Bernini chose to depict an intense religious experience in a theatrical way.

VH928184_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH928184_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual or contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific visual or contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Röttgen Pietà

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Recent plagues, famines, and wars led northern European Christians to meditate on images that emphasized pain and suffering.

· The Pietà was created during a time when private religious meditation became more popular among European Christians, creating a demand for imagery that enabled meditation.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Recent plagues, famines, and wars led northern European Christians to meditate on images that emphasized suffering, as exemplified by the Röttgen Pietà ’s exaggerated depiction of physical and emotional pain.

· Worshippers were encouraged to create an emotional connection with the holy figures depicted in images like this one by meditating on the specific details of the narrative of the Virgin Mary grieving over her dead son and by identifying with the suffering of the holy figures.

Lamentation from the Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Late medieval audiences showed a new interest in emotionally charged works that were intended to stimulate meditation and devotion connected to new modes of spirituality.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Worshippers were encouraged to create an emotional connection with the holy figures depicted in images like this one by meditating on the specific details of the narrative of Christ’s friends and family mourning over his dead body and by identifying with the sorrow and grief expressed by the figures.

Isenheim altarpiece, closed

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Recent plagues, famines, and wars led northern European Christians to meditate on images that emphasized pain and suffering.

· Grünewald’s depiction of the Crucifixion is thought to have been influenced by the visions of Saint Bridget, which included graphic descriptions of the Crucifixion and Christ’s torment.

Possible examples of explanations how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Worshippers were encouraged to create an emotional connection with the holy figures depicted in images like this one by meditating on the specific details of the narrative of the crucified Christ being mourned by his followers and by identifying with the suffering of the holy figures.

· The emphasis on physical and emotional suffering in the work is likely related to the original placement of the altarpiece in a monastery with an adjoining hospital where people were being treated for ailments.

VH928193_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH928193_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one element of the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza.
Response does accurately describe one element of the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The frontispiece represents a schematic diagram/map of the city of Tenochtitlan and the Mexica (Aztec) empire.

· In the center an eagle is shown perched atop a cactus growing from a rock, which was a sign given to the Mexica people by the god Huitzilopochtli to show them where to build a new city.

· The ten men grouped around the central motif are legendary leaders or founders of the city.

· A temple and skull rack probably symbolize the sacred precinct of Tenochtitlan.

· Fighting warriors symbolize the conquest of the Mexica/Aztec of neighboring cities.

· Bordering the work are fifty-one Aztec year glyphs.

VH928193_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VH928193_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the audience for whom the Codex Mendoza was made.
Response does accurately describe the audience for whom the Codex Mendoza was made.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· It was created 20 years after the Spanish conquest of Mexico, commissioned by the first viceroy of New Spain, Antonio de Mendoza.

· It was made to record information on the Aztec empire with the intent of sending it to the King of Spain, Charles V.

VH928193_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH928193_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza was most likely intended to function for its intended audience.
Response use one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza was most likely intended to function for its intended audience.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The codex provides a chronicle or selective account of the history and customs of the Mexica (Aztec) and their rulers; the frontispiece records the founding of the capital and empire as an important part of this narrative.

· The codex was intended to inform the Spanish king about the history and culture of his new subjects by recounting its history before the Spanish conquest.

· The Mexica artists that created this work might have seen it as a way to preserve elements of their cultural identity by recording their own history in the traditional Mexica (Aztec) style.

o.d: Response uses two examples of specific contextual evidence to explain how the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza was most likely intended to function for its intended audience.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The codex provides a chronicle or selective account of the history and customs of the Mexica (Aztec) and their rulers; the frontispiece records the founding of the capital and empire as an important part of this narrative.

· The codex was intended to inform the Spanish king about the history and culture of his new subjects before the Spanish conquest.

· The Mexica artists that created this work might have seen it as a way to preserve elements of their cultural identity by recording their own history in the traditional Mexica (Aztec) style.

VH928193_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how an art historically valid interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning.
VH928193_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain why the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza is important for understanding the likely meaning of the work for the people who created it.

Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain why the content of the frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza is important for understanding the likely meaning of the work for the people who created it.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· By depicting the foundation and history of Tenochtitlan and the Aztec empire, the work depicts the historical and cultural background of an area that the Spanish had recently conquered.

· The work indicates that the settling of the area took place through conquest, emphasizing the strength of the Aztec empire, and in turn demonstrating the power of the Spanish conquerors.

· By including the Aztec calendar system and other Aztec glyphs, and by commissioning Mexica (Aztec) scribes and artists who could still claim firsthand knowledge of preconquest Aztec life, the patron likely intended to communicate elements of Mexica (Aztec) culture to the Spanish king.

· The inclusion of Aztec year glyphs and other Aztec glyphs and the recording of important historical events from the history of the Aztec empire in the traditional Aztec style might also have been an expression of indigenous pride by the artists who created the work and might have been a way to preserve elements of their culture and history, records of which were mostly destroyed by the Spanish conquerors.

VH928201_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one architectural element of the Palazzo Rucellai.
Response accurately describes one architectural element of the Palazzo Rucellai.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The facade is divided into three tiers by entablatures.

· The tiers decrease in height from bottom to top; together with subtle changes in design, this gives the impression of a gradual decrease in mass.

· Each story is defined by pilasters of a different order.

· The bottom tier of the facade at ground-floor level is distinguished from the facade of upper floors through square windows, portals, and a strip of crosshatched stone at the very bottom, projecting strength and stability.

· Arcades with round arches surround windows of the second story and third story.

· The building is crowned by a projecting classical cornice.

VH928201_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH928201_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how Alberti references earlier architectural traditions in the Palazzo Rucellai.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how Alberti references earlier architectural traditions in the Palazzo Rucellai.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The design incorporates the Flavian Amphitheater or Colosseum’s three classical architectural orders.

· The design incorporates the Flavian Amphitheater or Colosseum’s three-part elevation to organize architectural elements.

· The design references the early Roman imperial design method of framing arcades with engaged colonnades.

· The design references early Roman imperial design through classical proportions and/or harmonies.

· The design references early Roman imperial design by articulating or clarifying classical elements.

VH928201_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH928201_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how Alberti departs from earlier architectural traditions in the Palazzo Rucellai.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how Alberti departs from earlier architectural traditions in the Palazzo Rucellai.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Alberti freely reinterpreted classical architectural elements into new Renaissance forms.

· Alberti employed classical architectural elements on a building type unknown in antiquity.

· Alberti created new types of capitals instead of using the Colosseum’s Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian orders.

· Alberti included Rucellai family designs in the friezes that are not found on the Colosseum.

· Alberti translated the Colosseum’s deep, vaulted surface into a flat, planar surface.

· Alberti converted the Colosseum’s engaged columns into flattened pilasters.

· Alberti linked the palazzo with the Florentine citizens or public space by adding an extensive bench.

VH928201_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain the meaning or significance of continuity and/or change between works of art (or group of related works of art) within a related artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH928201_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use contextual evidence to explain how Alberti’s references to earlier architectural traditions express the ideals of the Italian Renaissance.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain how Alberti’s references to earlier architectural traditions express the ideals of the Italian Renaissance.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Alberti expressed the Renaissance ideal of humanism through references to the classical past.

· The elite class during the Florentine/Italian Renaissance was associated with the classical aesthetic.

· The competing leading families of Florence/Italy used references to classical societies and cultures in art and architecture to demonstrate their wealth and power.

· The identification with classical traditions expresses the civic pride of Florentine families.

VH928248_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VH928248_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the specific function of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
Response does accurately describe the specific function of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The church is dedicated to Sainte Foy, a young girl who was martyred by the Romans in the second century C.E. and who became a popular saint in Southern France. Her relic was housed in an ornate reliquary and displayed in the church.

· Sainte-Foy lies along the Romanesque pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostella in Northern Spain, and pilgrims would stop at the church to view relics, including those of Sainte Foy, in order to obtain blessings and to demonstrate their piety, in the hope of being saved on Judgment Day.

· The popularity of Sainte-Foy brought pilgrims and wealth to the small town, as visitors came to see her relic.

· Sainte-Foy also functioned as a monastery where monks lived, prayed, and worked.

VH928248_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH928248_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
Response does accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Sainte-Foy includes a cruciform plan, side aisles, and an apse with five radiating chapels.

· The nave is barrel vaulted with an arcade of arches rising from clustered piers.

· The church also contains a crossing tower and westwork.

· The western facade contains a pair of doors topped by an arched tympanum with biblical scenes, including the Last Judgment.

· The tympanum shows the central figure of Christ in a mandorla, hands gesturing down toward hell and up toward heaven.

· Below Christ’s feet, St. Michael and the Devil weigh newly risen souls and lead them into either heaven or hell, depending on the verdict.

· The lower part of the tympanum is divided into two halves; the left side shows figures of the saved contained under arches representing paradise, whereas the right side shows the damned being tortured in hell for their various sins.

VH928248_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH928248_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to- explain how the function influenced the design of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain how the function influenced the design of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· As a pilgrimage church, amendments had to be made to allow for the flow of additional traffic without interrupting the regular services or the practices of the monks, including the following.

· The cruciform plan symbolized the sacred sign of the cross while also helping to control the crowds passing through.

· An ambulatory led around the apse, flanked by radiating chapels that contained shrines.

· Pilgrims would enter through the north transept, traverse through the ambulatory visiting the shrines contained in the radiating chapels, and exit through the opposite transept.

VH928248_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH928248_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain how the function influenced the sculptural program of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain how the function influenced the sculptural program of the Church of Sainte-Foy.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Images from the tympanum were chosen to remind pilgrims, monks, and clergymen of the dangers of sin, including specific examples of what hell might look like.

· The tympanum depicts saints, including Sainte Foy, whose relic the pilgrims came to visit.

· The depiction of the Last Judgment and the weighing of souls reminded those who entered of the need for repentance and the importance of doing good works and leading a pious life.

· The lavishly decorated reliquary held within the church was intended to reflect the precious nature of the relic held within.

VH928248_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how an art historically valid interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning.
VH928248_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain why the sculptural program of the Church of Sainte-Foy is important for understanding the significance of the site for its original audience.

Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain why the sculptural program of the Church of Sainte-Foy is important for understanding the significance of the site for its original audience.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The role of saints as intercessors on behalf of believers created a direct connection between the visit of the pilgrims to the Last Judgment depicted in the tympanum.

· Medieval Christians believed that prayers offered to saints at the site of their remains would improve chances of salvation, which explains the enormous value placed on holy relics and the popularity of making pilgrimages to see them.

· On the tympanum, the hand of God beckons the kneeling Saint Foy, reminding believers of the saint’s ability to intercede with Christ on the behalf of sinners who pray to her.

· On the tympanum there are an altar, chalice, columns, and arches that represent the church that visitors are about to enter. Those who entered hoped to receive divine blessings from God just as Saint Foy herself did.

· The reliquary drew pilgrims close to the physical remains of Saint Foy, to ask for her blessing.

VH928255_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.

o.d: Response does not accurately describes one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II.
Response accurately describes one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Four tall, slender minarets rise above the exterior corners of the mosque, communicating the prayer hall’s central plan.

· A large dome, with a ring of windows surrounding its base, covers the interior space.

· The plan combines the shape of an octagon with a square and is covered by a round dome.

· Half domes in the corners of the hall ease the transition between the square base and the round dome.

· The dome rests on squinches decorated with muqarnas and supported by piers.

· The Mihrab niche, covered by a half dome, is directly opposite the entrance.

· Intricate nonfigural ornamentation includes muqarnas, striped arches, calligraphy, vegetal forms, and geometric patterns on brilliantly colored glazed tiles.

VH928255_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain how one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates continuity with global conventions of mosque architecture.
Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain how one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates continuity with global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The minarets, towers that the muezzin traditionally climbed to sing out the call to prayer, serve the same function as those at every mosque.

· The Mihrab niche, indicating the Qibla wall and direction to face in prayer, is an element found in every mosque.

· The ornamentation reflects Islamic avoidance of figural imagery in religious contexts, as observed in all Islamic religious architecture.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain how one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates changes from global conventions of mosque architecture.
Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain how one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates changes from global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The central plan of the prayer hall in the Mosque of Selim II departs from the traditional rectangular layout for prayer halls.

· The large central dome creates a soaring, light-filled interior space unlike that found in earlier mosques with lower flat or vaulted ceilings.

· The use of a central dome covering the entire prayer hall creates a unified interior space that differs from the segmented space created by rows of supporting columns in earlier mosques.

· The brilliantly colored glazed tiles increase the impression of a light-drenched interior space, since they reflect the light entering windows from every side of the structure. These are particular to Ottoman construction.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain why one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates changes from global conventions of mosque architecture.
Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain why one visual characteristic of the Mosque of Selim II demonstrates changes from global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The use of a large central dome over a central-plan structure reflects the Ottoman Empire’s recent conquest of Byzantine territory and the influence of Byzantine central-plan Christian churches with domes.

· The soaring interior space and monumental scale of the mosque reflect the architect Sinan’s desire to create an Islamic structure more impressive than Hagia Sophia, built by Byzantine Christians a thousand years earlier.

· In the ongoing military and political struggles between the Islamic Ottoman Empire and Christian Europeans for control of the eastern Mediterranean, the soaring interior space and monumental scale make the mosque an emphatic statement of both the power of the Ottoman sultan and the ultimate triumph of Islam.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain how the work conveys the intellectual environment of late eighteenth-century Europe.
Response does accurately explain how the work conveys the intellectual environment of late eighteenth-century Europe.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· By depicting a scientific experiment, the work represents the increasing value placed on scientific research and innovations of thought and technology in eighteenth-century Europe.

· Works like this appealed to Wright of Derby’s patrons, many of whom were industrial entrepreneurs who became wealthy through risk-taking schemes and their faith in scientific progress.

· By painting an ensemble of figures, Wright of Derby suggests the collaborative atmosphere of the Age of Enlightenment. Wright of Derby belonged to the Lunar Society, a group of merchants, traders, and aristocrats who met monthly to discuss ideas related to science and technology. By depicting a scientific experiment as opposed to a religious subject, the work suggests a growing dissatisfaction with religious thought and doctrine, leading some thinkers to adopt the concept of deism, which proposes the existence of a creator God who is no longer interested in the affairs of humanity.

· The presence of children alludes to the great interest and debate among philosophers of the seventeenth century about how children should be educated.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament).
Response accurately describes one visual characteristic of the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament).
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

Exterior

· The exterior was built using sandy- and honey-colored limestone.

· There are large, square towers rising from one side as well as several other smaller towers.

· The Elizabeth tower holds the Great Clock of Westminster, whose bell is often referred to as Big Ben.

· The incorporation of pinnacles and turrets creates a sense of verticality and a spiked or pointed appearance that counters the long horizontal plan of the structure.

Interior

· The lavishly decorated interior includes stone reliefs, freestanding statuary, gilding, and marble-veneer flooring.

· A grand chandelier, stained glass windows with metal grilles, and mosaics with heraldic symbols are used for ornamentation.

· Pointed arches and rib vaulting are used.

· Tympana over the doorways each depict a patron saint of the United Kingdom: St. George (England), St. David (Wales), St. Andrew (Scotland), and St. Patrick (Ireland).

· The tracery and lacework on the stained glass lancet windows, and the tall towers are typical of architectural elements used on medieval churches

· The pointed arches, rib vaulting, relief sculpture, spires, pinnacles, and tympana are all elements used in Gothic architectural structures.

· The use of tympana filled with religious imagery over the door frames is reminiscent of the portals of medieval European churches.

· The mosaics and marble incrustation incorporated into the decorative scheme are techniques used in antiquity and Byzantine churches.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain why the architects chose to include references to earlier architectural traditions in this building.
Response does accurately use specific evidence to explain why the architects chose to include references to earlier architectural traditions in this building.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· After the old palace had burned down, a competition was held for designs for a new building. The competition had the stipulation that the new structure had to be designed in one of two historical styles considered to represent English culture: Gothic or Elizabethan.

· The architect Charles Barry believed in Gothic as a true and moral style of architecture and also a style that was associated with Englishness.

· The Gothic Revival and the Gothic style stood for a kind of Victorian/ nineteenth-century fantasy that emphasized medieval artisan craftsmanship and a vanishing tradition of handcrafted things.

· In the face of modernization and industrialization, there was a desire during the Victorian era to return to these earlier values that were considered to be more pure, because many thought that modern society had squandered moral virtues.

· Whereas the modern, industrialized city skyline of the nineteenth century was dominated by factories and smokestacks, representing the search for profit, the medieval city was dominated by church steeples, which symbolized moral virtues and piety.

o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The map-like qualities of the work and its sense of movement in all directions can be interpreted as references to the contemporary art theme of globalization and interconnectedness.

· The abstract swirl of marks, etc., could be viewed as representing the force of migration or displacement, especially given the explosive look of the central black swirl. This is a theme of contemporary art.

· The sense of an explosion could be viewed as a reference to violence and its effects on people, another theme of contemporary art.

· Mehretu has written of her work as a “stratified, tectonic geology . . . with the characters themselves buried—as if they were fossils,” which ties into the contemporary idea of recapturing or rediscovering history.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of Androgyne III references the classical Western tradition of depicting the human body.

o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

Characteristics that reference the classical Western tradition of depicting the human body.

· The fragment of the figure is recognizable as human and has natural proportions.

· As in many classical works, the figure is unclothed.

· The presentation of a fragment of a figure is reminiscent of the discovery of ancient sculptural fragments.

Characteristics that depart from the classical Western tradition of depicting the human body

· The figure intentionally lacks a head, its legs are fragmented, and its arms are partially present. (To know about the arms requires having seen an alternate view of the work.)

· The figure is made of burlap and organic materials rather than more permanent materials such as marble or bronze.

· The figure is supported on a stretcher rather than a traditional base.

· The figure is not gender specific.

· The work does not celebrate the humanity of the individual but rather suggests the anonymity of countless oppressed human beings.

· The figure is bent over with its shoulders hunched and does not interact with its environment.

· The figure does not look healthy.

· The interior of the figure is exposed as hollow within its burlap body-shell. (To know about this requires having seen an alternate view of the work.)

VH942882_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the content of The Saint-Lazare Station.
Response does accurately describe the content of the Saint-Lazare Station.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· The work shows the inside of a train station with a steam train pulling in.

· Sunlight is filtering through the windows and skylights of the train station, creating a play of light and shadows.

· Smoke and steam are issuing from several different sources in the image, partially obscuring engines, the tracks, and parts of the station.

· The locomotive of the approaching steam train is issuing from its smokestack a cloud of gray smoke, which is rising to the roof of the station.

· Several people are seen waiting for approaching trains or crossing the tracks.

· Several large apartment buildings are visible in the background that have the characteristic look of the modern, new building blocks of Paris in the late nineteenth century.

VH942882_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH942882_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not describe the content of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the content of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Illustration from The Results of the First Five-Year Plan

· Speakers are shown addressing a large crowd from a platform.

· Crowds of people are shown carrying signs and flags in what appears to be a parade, while others line the street to watch.

· A large picture of Lenin addressing an audience appears to rise from behind the crowds on the right.

· A red silhouette of power lines appears in the background.

Nadar Raising Photography to the Height of Art

· The work depicts the photographer Gaspard-Félix Tournachon (known as Nadar) in his personal hot-air balloon, using his camera to take aerial or bird’s-eye view images of a city (Paris) below.

· Many of the buildings in the city just below Nadar are marked with the word “Photographie,” suggesting the proliferation of professional photography studios in Paris by 1863.

· The balloon (of which only the basket is visible) appears to be pushed by strong winds, causing the basket in which the photographer stands to tilt and his hat to fly off.

· Overall, the posture of the photographer combined with the tilting of the balloon creates a rather comical effect.

A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery

· The work depicts a group of seven figures, all of varying ages and genders, looking at an orrery—a model of the solar system—as they hear a lecture about astronomy given by a philosopher.

· As the three children learn by looking, two older males assist the philosopher, one taking notes while the other turns the crank that makes the orrery move. A third male looks in admiration at the philosopher, who stands as the tallest and oldest figure in the work.

· The figures shown in the work depict the stages of learning: observation, realization, assisting the teacher, and becoming the teacher.

· The work depicts a scene that would have been popular during the Age of Enlightenment, giving emphasis to empirical observation and a scientific approach to knowledge.

VH942882_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH942882_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the works depict technological and/or scientific change.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the works depict technological and/or scientific change.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Illustration from The Results of the First Five-Year Plan

· Both works use a triangular compositional format to suggest a symbolic upward movement of progress.

· Both works depict instruments of modern technology; included in the Monet are the train and the iron, steel, and glass architecture of the train station, and in the Stepanova are the public address speakers and the electrical transmission towers.

Nadar Raising Photography to the Height of Art

· Both Monet and Daumier depict a modern view of the city of Paris, showing the grand boulevards and new apartment buildings that were developed under the direction of Baron Haussmann.

· Both Monet and Daumier depict a modern mode of travel. The first steam locomotive was launched in 1812; the first hot-air balloon was first invented and flown in 1783.

A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery

· Both works of art employ an emphasis on light to draw the viewer into the painting.

· Both works of art eschew traditional subject matter and make modern technology the subject of their works, as opposed to historical or religious subjects.

VH942882_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH942882_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the works depict technological and/or scientific change.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the works depict technological and/or scientific change.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Illustration from The Results of the First Five-Year Plan

· Monet painted his work using the traditional media of oil on canvas; Stepanova uses the relatively new method of photomontage, in which two or more images (usually photographs) are juxtaposed to give the illusion of a single image.

· Monet painted in the style of Impressionism, using color to record the effects of light, smoke, and steam, and painterly brushstrokes to suggest a dynamic atmosphere; Stepanova created in the style of Constructivism, in which the artists tried to integrate art and life to promote the ideological aims of the political regime.

Nadar Raising Photography to the Height of Art

· Daumier depicts the taking of aerial photography as dangerous, impractical, and ridiculous; Monet glorifies train travel, placing it in the Saint-Lazare train station, which resembles a cathedral.

· Monet was inspired by photography and created his series of paintings of the train station in the form of photographic snap shots of the station; Daumier suggests that photography is not inspirational and should not be elevated to an art form, because many people can set up photographic studios, and therefore it is not individual or unique.

A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery

· A steam-engine locomotive train was a technological advancement in modern travel; an orrery was a pedagogical device that assisted in the teaching and learning of the solar system.

· Monet viewed actual trains at the Saint-Lazare station and drew sketches for the paintings on-site; Wright of Derby may not have seen an actual orrery and may have painted a modified version of an orrery based on period engravings and etchings.

· Monet attempts to capture natural light as a major formal element in his painting; Wright of Derby uses tenebristic, artificial lighting to infuse drama into his scene.

VH942882_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulates a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH942882_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one similarity or difference in how the works convey the artists’ attitudes toward technological and/or scientific change within their respective cultures.
Response does accurately explain one similarity or difference in how the works convey the artists’ attitudes toward technological and/or scientific change within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Illustration from The Results of the First Five-Year Plan

Similarities

· Both artworks present a one-sided view of the positive aspects of technological change.

· Both artworks present a positive view of technological change without any regard for, in the case of the Monet, the neighborhoods and countryside changed by the new rail stations and trains or, in the case of the Stepanova, the massive economic failures and poverty caused by the Five-Year Plan.

· Both works suggest a dissolution of traditional class structures: in the Monet, the ease of train travel allowed people of many economic backgrounds to travel for work or leisure; in the Stepanova, the Five-Year Plan promoted the elimination of private property for a more communal ownership.

Differences

· Although Stepanova’s work serves a propagandist purpose, Monet’s work does not.

· Stepanova’s artwork is an example of propaganda, in that she clearly promotes the agenda of the Soviet government, and its political cause, in a somewhat misleading way. Monet’s artwork is not politically motivated.

· Monet’s artworks in this series were not shown in the official, state-sanctioned Salon exhibitions; Stepanova’s illustrations were reproduced in the official, state-sanctioned propaganda magazines of the era.

Nadar Raising Photography to the Height of Art

Differences

· Daumier mocks the growing status and importance of photography; Monet does not mock or downplay the growing status and importance of train travel.

· Daumier focuses on the negative effects of technological innovations, such as the commercialization of art, whereas Monet does not depict negative effects of technological change.

A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery

Similarities

· Both Monet and Wright of Derby glorify technology and science in their works, showing appreciation of new technological and scientific advances.

· In the way that the subject matter is depicted in their paintings, both Monet and Wright of Derby suggest that technology is worthy of worship.

VH942882_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH942882_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about The Saint-Lazare Station in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about The Saint-Lazare Station in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Train travel was still a fairly new mode of transportation at the time when Monet painted this work, made possible through advances in technology and infrastructure.

· Parisian streets and neighborhoods, for better or worse, were changed through the projects of Baron Haussmann.

· Commuting as well as leisure travel were becoming part of a new way of life for modern Parisians.

· Monet made studies on-site at the Saint-Lazare train station and finished the paintings in this series in his studio.

· Monet exhibited between six and eight paintings from the series at the Third Impressionist Exhibition in 1877.

Possible examples for explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The station and other buildings depicted represent nineteenth-century advancements in architecture, made possible by new innovations in the use of iron, glass, and steel, suggesting that Monet chose to highlight technological advancements in a positive way in his work.

· The work depicts the newly enlarged Gare Saint-Lazare train station, which tripled in size under Haussmann, indicating that Monet was embracing changes connected to urban modernization.

· Monet embraced the modernity of the subject of the train station in this work, which went against traditional and academic subject matter.

VH942882_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH942882_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Illustration from The Results of the First Five-Year Plan

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· The subject of the image is the rise of Communism and the implied success of the First Five-Year Plan, instituted by Stalin in the Soviet Union.

· The Five-Year Plan was an initiative started by Stalin to accelerate industrialization in the USSR through collective farming, expanding the military, and strengthening steel production.

Possible examples for explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The work is celebrating the First Five-Year Plan, instituted by Stalin in the Soviet Union, by including imagery that highlights how technological advancements benefited society.

· In actuality, the Five-Year Plan caused extreme poverty and famine. However, Stepanova only portrays the results of the Five-Year Plan in a positive way.

Nadar Raising Photography to the Height of Art

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Daumier’s lithograph was published in a French journal.

· Daumier made this lithograph in response to the ruling of a French court that declared photographic images to be the intellectual property of the photographer because they reflected the photographer’s personal vision.

· Lithography was itself a relatively new invention (invented in 1796) and was only sixty-six years old when Daumier made this lithograph.

· Nadar did in fact take aerial-view images of Paris from his hot-air balloon close to the time that this lithograph was made.

Possible examples of explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Daumier rejected the idea that the new technology of photography could be considered art and expressed his views in this work by making fun of photography.

A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Wright of Derby seems to have been interested in scientific clubs that existed during his time.

· Wright of Derby may have attended lectures on astronomy.

· Orreries were models of the solar system that were invented in the eighteenth century and were popular around the time that this painting was created.

· Wright of Derby’s painting was exhibited publicly in London.

Possible examples for explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· The depiction of people engaged in a lecture about astronomy suggests that Wright of Derby regarded scientific education as positive and important.

· The depiction of a scientist giving a lecture about the solar system suggests that Wright of Derby regarded scientific research as positive and important.

· Wright of Derby was interested in the scientific advancements of his time, which is reflected in the way that he chose to represent the subject of a scientific lecture.

VH942897_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Identify a work of art.
VH942897_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Does not provide two accurate identifiers for selected work of art
Provides two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Fallingwater

· Architect: Frank Lloyd Wright

· Location: Pennsylvania, United States

· Materials: Reinforced concrete, sandstone, steel, and glass

· Date: 1936–1939 C.E.

House in New Castle County

· Date: 1978–1983 C.E.

Monticello

· Location: Virginia, United States
