· Date: 1768–1809 C.E.

VH942897_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH942897_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not describe the design of Villa Savoye.
Response does accurately describe the design of Villa Savoye.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The structure’s design is geometric, with unadorned surfaces.

· The structure is raised above the ground on freestanding posts called pilotis.

· Because the walls are not load bearing, they allow for the use of ribbon windows, running the entire length of the façade.

· The interior has an open plan.

· The interior has a spiral staircase.

· The structure has a rooftop garden.

· The design provides space for an automobile to be driven underneath the structure.

VH942897_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH942897_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not describe the design of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the design of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Fallingwater

· The structure was built over a waterfall.

· The structure’s design is geometric, with unadorned surfaces.

· The structure has multiple terraces that project out into space through the use of cantilevers.

· The structure is asymmetrical.

· The interior has an open plan organized around a central hearth.

· The design employs contrasting textures (concrete, painted metal, and natural stone).

· The structure includes long bands of windows and glass doors.

House in New Castle County

· The structure’s facades are dominated by arched screens and flattened cut-out shapes of Doric columns.

· The structure has a pitched roof with large gables.

· The interior includes a vaulted music room with colorfully painted arches that also appear as cut-out shapes.

· The siding of the home is painted white.

· The roof is covered with undecorated wood shingles.

Monticello

· The structure is symmetrically designed In the French pavilion style.

· The design incorporates classical features such as Doric columns, a portico, and a pediment.

· A domed second-story room is situated behind and above the central portico on the west facade.

· The interior centers on two large rooms that served as an entrance hall and an exhibition space.

· The house is part of a U-shaped plan that incorporates two sunken, terrace-covered wings.

· The house includes a number of the architect’s inventive amenities, such as dumbwaiters, disappearing beds, hidden staircases, and folding doors.

VH942897_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH942897_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the two works were designed to accommodate daily life.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the two works were designed to accommodate daily life.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Fallingwater

· Each house was designed as a retreat, located in a natural environment.

· Each house provides a band of windows and terraces, providing tranquil views of the surrounding landscape from the interior.

· Each house utilizes an open plan, allowing for natural light and for flexibility when arranging furniture and living areas.

House in New Castle County

· Both were designed as retreats, located within a natural environment.

· Both provide views of the surrounding area from large windows located above the ground floor.

· Both have spacious rooms, allowing for flexibility in arranging furniture.

· Both have large windows providing ample natural lighting.

Monticello

· Both were designed within a natural environment.

· Both provide views of the surrounding area from large windows looking out in all directions.

· Both homes include innovative features to increase the comfort and ease of daily life. For example, the Villa Savoye has unique ramps and a spiral staircase; Monticello has dumbwaiters and staircases hidden within closet-like alcoves.

VH942897_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH942897_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the two works were designed to accommodate daily life.
Response does accurately use visual evidence from both works to explain one difference in how the two works were designed to accommodate daily life.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Fallingwater

· The walls of the Villa Savoye have a smooth, planar quality. In contrast, Fallingwater uses natural materials, such as stone and local rocks, so that nature can be experienced indoors as well as outdoors.

· Although both homes are in secluded natural environments, the observer is made aware of nature’s presence at Fallingwater by the ever-present sound of the waterfall located underneath the house.

· The outdoor terrace at the Villa Savoye confines the occupant to the square perimeter of the house. The projecting terraces at Fallingwater, by contrast, allow one the opportunity to walk farther out, away from the house and into the natural surroundings.

House in New Castle County

· The walls of the Villa Savoye have a smooth, planar quality to suggest a seamless integration between life and technology. In contrast, the New Castle County home adapts traditional design features and motifs to reflect a whimsical dialogue between the past and the present.

· The architectural features of the Villa Savoye were designed primarily to be functional rather than ornamental. In contrast, many of the design features of the New Castle County home have only a decorative function.

Monticello

· The walls of the Villa Savoye have a smooth, planar quality, suggesting a machine-like aesthetic where daily life is impacted by the modern, technological world. In contrast, Monticello adapts classical design features that suggest formality and orderly governance over daily life.

· The layout of the Villa Savoye employs an open plan, suggesting a degree of flexibility in how the interior space can be used. In contrast, the rooms at Monticello are arranged in a symmetrical fashion, suggesting a far more structured lifestyle.

· The entrance to the Villa Savoye is not grandiose but is somewhat obscure, located conveniently below the main living area to provide easy access into and out of automobiles. While Monticello has multiple entrances, its design is centered around a striking entrance via a portico on the east facade.

VH942897_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulates a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH942897_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one difference in the aesthetic philosophies that the architects expressed in the design of these structures.
Response does accurately explain one difference in the aesthetic philosophies that the architects expressed in the design of these structures.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Fallingwater

· Le Corbusier created a home that reflected the use of modern technology through clean, geometric forms; Frank Lloyd Wright created a home that reflected an interest in nature by orienting this home around natural features in the landscape.

· Le Corbusier preferred the use of industrial materials, such as steel and reinforced concrete; Frank Lloyd Wright used a wider variety of materials, including natural stone found locally.

House in New Castle County

· Le Corbusier envisioned a home that reflected modernist purity through the use of clean, geometric forms; in contrast, the architects of the House in New Castle County reintroduced ornamentation or decoration into contemporary architecture.

· Le Corbusier preferred the innovative use of industrial materials, such as steel and reinforced concrete; the architects of the House in New Castle County used traditional house-building materials, such as wood and stucco.

Monticello

· Le Corbusier envisioned a home that reflected Modernist purity through the use of clean, geometric forms to suggest a seamless integration between life and technology; Jefferson sought out classical design features to reflect a principled vision of a newly born American democracy.

· Le Corbusier envisioned the future of architecture by breaking away from the ornamental conventions of the past. In contrast, Jefferson adapted design features from the antique world in order to equate his age with that of the past.

VH942897_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH942897_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about Villa Savoye in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about Villa Savoye in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Le Corbusier designed a series of houses based on his Five Points of Architecture, a universal system that could be applied to create what he called a “machine for living.”

Possible examples of explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Le Corbusier devised a purist style based on the beauty of machines; in his Vers une Architecture, he praises the designs of ocean liners, forms that can easily be compared to design features of the Villa Savoye.

VH942897_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH942897_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Fallingwater

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Frank Lloyd Wright espoused an idea of organic architecture, which is a holistic approach to architecture that includes the building’s setting as well as elements of interior design.

Possible examples of explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Frank Lloyd Wright espoused an idea of organic architecture, which is a holistic approach to architecture that includes the building’s setting, which is represented in Fallingwater through the incorporation of the building into its natural surroundings.

House in New Castle County

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Venturi critiqued the dominant Modernist aesthetic and promoted an architecture that favored multiple meanings over consolidated form.

Possible examples of explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Venturi often incorporated historical styles and features in what some have termed postmodernist architecture. In the House in New Castle County, he drew on the vernacular architecture of the region, including the design of eighteenth-century barns.

Monticello

Possible examples of specific and relevant evidence that could support a claim

· Like many Neoclassical architects of his time, Jefferson was influenced by the Renaissance architecture of Andrea Palladio.

· Jefferson was influenced by the classically based architecture that he encountered while living in France.

Possible examples of explanations of how specific and relevant evidence justifies the claim

· Jefferson regarded Roman architecture as the ideal representation of the republican ideals that he sought to incorporate into the newly formed republic of the United States and therefore adhered to basic rule-based architectural principles that governed order in ancient Greco-Roman architecture, as seen in Monticello.

VH954356_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Does not provide two accurate identifiers for selected work of art.
Response provides two accurate identifiers for selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· Artist: Caravaggio

· Date: 1597-1601 C.E. Also acceptable: a date within 50 years of the original

· Culture: Baroque

· Materials: Oil (on Canvas)

· Location: Rome, Italy (“Rome” alone is acceptable; “Italy” alone is not acceptable)

Chartres Cathedral

· French Gothic (“Gothic” alone is acceptable)

· Chartres, France (“France alone is NOT acceptable)

· Notre Dame de la Belle Verriere window

· Original construction c. 1145-1155 C.E.; reconstructed c. 1194-1220 C.E. Also acceptable: a date

within 100 years of the original.

· Limestone, stained glass (“stained glass” alone is acceptable. “Stone” is not acceptable.)

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· Artist: Bernini

· Date: c. 1647-1652 (also acceptable: a date within 50 years of the original)

· Culture: Baroque

· Materials: Marble (sculpture), stucco and gilt bronze (chapel) (“marble” alone is acceptable)

· Location: Cornaro Chapel OR Santa Maria della Vittoria OR Rome, Italy (“Rome” alone is acceptable, “Italy” alone is not acceptable).

VH954356_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.

Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of

reasoning.
o.af:
Examples of possible claims might include the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· The light indicates God’s spirit or presence and dramatizes the story climax, his choosing of a disciple.

· Light is associated with divinity, in contrast to the darkness of sin, eliciting an emotional response from the viewer.

· Light and setting communicate to the audience that Christian salvation was open to all.

· The artist’s use of light created a dramatic scene, drawing the viewers into the narrative.

Chartres Cathedral

· The windows at Chartres demonstrate the concept of lux nova, or “new light”

· The light permeating the church symbolically represents God, God’s word and/or heaven

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· Light highlights the intensity of St. Teresa’s mystical union with God.

· Light is used in the work to suggest the presence of the divine.

The use of light in the work was intended to encourage intense faith.

VH954356_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C EVIDENCE: VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH954356_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· The artist uses a diagonal beam of light, crossing the painting from the upper right to the lower left.

· The artist employs tenebrism, the use of bold contrasting lights and darks.

· The artist uses light to emphasize hands, gestures, expressions and characters to assist in deciphering the narrative.

· The artist uses light to reveal a dingy tavern.

· The painting was created during the time of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, a time of church reform and intense spiritual activities.

· Artists in the Baroque often used light to create dramatic, theatrical effects.

· In the biblical narrative, Matthew is a tax collector, an occupation held in great disdain during Jesus’ lifetime.

Chartres Cathedral

· Chartres has an extensive number of stained glass windows which enabled artists to allow colored light to permeate the structure’s vast interior.

· The large and numerous windows were permitted by the use of flying buttresses, a Gothic innovation.

· The dominant color of the stained glass windows is sapphire blue, a color associated with the Virgin Mary.

· Large windows with multicolored stained glass depict biblical subjects and narratives. One of these windows is Notre Dame de la Belle Verriere.

· Varied segments of society, ranging from royal heads of state to guild members, were charged with patronizing the church by donating beautiful windows through which light passes and illuminates subjects invested with both sacred and secular interests.

The windows exemplify the concept of lux nova or new light, a concept that was central to the Gothic use of stained glass within cathedrals.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· The chapel is dramatically lit by a window hidden behind a broken pediment above the main sculpture group.

· The deeply cut folds of St. Teresa’s drapery in particular create dramatic light and shadow effects.

· The figures of St. Teresa and the angel are positioned against bronze rays that shoot downward from above and represent, as well as reflect, natural light.

· The painting was created during the time of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, a time of church reform and intense spiritual activities.

· Artists in the Baroque often used light to create dramatic, theatrical effects. Bernini’s background as a set designer made him particularly adept at creating such effects.

o.d: Response provides two specific examples of visual and/or contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· The artist uses a diagonal beam of light, crossing the painting from the upper right to the lower left.

· The artist employs tenebrism, the use of bold contrasting lights and darks.

· The artist uses light to emphasize hands, gestures, expressions and characters to assist in deciphering the narrative.

· The artist uses light to reveal a dingy tavern.

· The painting was created during the time of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, a time of church reform and intense spiritual activities.

· Artists in the Baroque often used light to create dramatic, theatrical effects.

· In the biblical narrative, Matthew is a tax collector, an occupation held in great disdain during Jesus’ lifetime.

Chartres Cathedral

· Chartres has an extensive number of stained glass windows which enabled artists to allow colored light to permeate the structure’s vast interior.

· The large and numerous windows were permitted by the use of flying buttresses, a Gothic innovation.

· The dominant color of the stained glass windows is sapphire blue, a color associated with the Virgin Mary.

· Large windows with multicolored stained glass depict biblical subjects and narratives. One of these windows is Notre Dame de la Belle Verriere.

· Varied segments of society, ranging from royal heads of state to guild members, were charged with patronizing the church by donating beautiful windows through which light passes and illuminates subjects invested with both sacred and secular interests.

The windows exemplify the concept of lux nova or new light, a concept that was central to the Gothic use of stained glass within cathedrals.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa
· The chapel is dramatically lit by a window hidden behind a broken pediment above the main sculpture group.

· The deeply cut folds of St. Teresa’s drapery in particular create dramatic light and shadow effects.

· The figures of St. Teresa and the angel are positioned against bronze rays that shoot downward from above and represent, as well as reflect, natural light.

· The painting was created during the time of the Catholic Counter-Reformation, a time of church reform and intense spiritual activities.

· Artists in the Baroque often used light to create dramatic, theatrical effects. Bernini’s background as a set designer made him particularly adept at creating such effects.

VH954356_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
The response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· The diagonal beam of light indicates God’s spirit or presence where stark tenebrism amplifies the association of light with divinity; where the divine light does not fall, the unilluminated areas thus look even darker.

· The stark lighting emphasized the dingy setting and unidealized contemporary characters, indicating that salvation was open to all.

· The ideals of the Catholic Counter-Reformation strove to make Christian narratives and doctrines more understandable and meaningful to a broad Catholic audience. Works of art created at this time often used light to achieve this goal.

· Light illuminates Matthew’s dark, sinful life and promises a transformation and conversion.

Chartres Cathedral

· The predominant blue color signifies heaven and is symbolically linked with the Virgin Mary and her role as the Queen of Heaven. As Queen of Heaven, Mary acts as a primary mediator between humans and her son.

· The intended effect of the light passing through the windows was to move the pious believer through dramatic sights so that they feel drawn closer to God’s heavenly kingdom.

· The concept of lux nova originated with Abbot Suger of St. Denis. Suger understood this as a way to illuminate the soul and to mystically unite the soul with God.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· Since the window from which the light emanates is hidden, the illuminated effect is one of a mystical, heavenly or divine nature. The work suggests the presence of the divine through the brilliant light in the chapel.

· In the context of the Catholic Counter Reformation, Bernini’s use of light was intended to encourage active participation and intense faith and devotion from viewers.

· The dramatically lit scene of Teresa and the angel, similar to a stage set, was intended to elicit a multisensory emotional response in viewers.

· The work is based on writings by Saint Teresa, a nun who attempted to bring more meaning into spiritual ritual through intense meditation that lead to a mystical experience, partly symbolized by light effects in Bernini’s work.

· The dramatic light and shadow effects created by the deeply cut folds of St. Teresa’s drapery heighten the work’s visionary qualities.

VH954356_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, developing any of the following:

Calling of Saint Matthew

· The Calling of Saint Matthew exemplifies Caravaggio’s treatment of religious subject matter in his mature work, which is characterized by realism combined with a theatrical/artificial use of light.

· Caravaggio depicts Matthew and the characters that surround him as ordinary people who would have seemed familiar to the sixteenth/seventeenth century audience; the stark use of light only serves to highlight their ordinary looks.

· Caravaggio’s choice to place a biblical event in a contemporary sixteenth/seventeenth-century setting filled by ordinary, and somewhat questionable looking, characters, can be interpreted as making the story more accessible to the contemporary audience.

· The effect of Caravaggio’s strategic lighting in creating a sense of mystery and spiritual drama is heightened by its combination with an ordinary, contemporary setting.

Chartres Cathedral

· While the architects of Chartres Cathedral increased the size of the windows to maximize the amount of light entering the church’s interior, the use of stained glass windows actually created a relatively dimly lit interior.

· Contrary to common misconception, French Gothic churches did not usually contain brightly lit interiors during medieval time, but rather, the light was filtered through the stained glass, creating a mystic, otherworldly experience.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· The multisensory emotional response elicited by the work was similar to the aims of Ignatius of Loyola’s Spiritual exercises.

· The inclusion of portraits of members of Cardinal Cornaros’ family who are depicted watching the events from balconies on either side of the chapel, suggests their emotional involvement in this spiritual experience, and, by extension, invites the involvement of the audience, according to the goals of the Counter Reformation of using art to increase piety and devotion

o.d: Response does not accurately use one example of specific visual evidence to explain how the artist used these visual characteristics to create a sense of movement
Response accurately uses one example of specific visual evidence to explain how the artist used these visual characteristics to create a sense of movement.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The structure’s flowing lines can be seen as both chaotic (because of their irregularity) and calm (because of the building’s asymmetrical balance) as they move through space.

· The rippling forms can symbolize musical movement.

· The interaction of sculptural, irregular, and/or asymmetrical forms reflects the movement and rhythms of the city.

· The reflective, stainless steel exterior engages light as an architectural detail that changes from day to night, making time an additional element of movement.

· The contrasts of light and shadow as one looks at the image create visual motion.

· The composition of forms makes the structure seem to float over the building’s base, disassociating from the ground.

VH963683_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how the work demonstrates continuity or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH963683_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain how the work departs from earlier architectural traditions in the United States.
Response does accurately explain how the work departs from earlier architectural traditions in the United States.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· In contrast to the traditional features of earlier public architecture in the United States, the building’s design is playful and dramatic, creating a more organic structure that interacts visually with its environment.

· Relatively economical industrial materials were used in place of more traditional and more expensive materials such as stone.

· Gehry used sophisticated computer-assisted design (CAD) software, which made it possible to diverge as he did from the traditional rules of architecture.

· The concert hall is intended to facilitate audience interaction and reflect the pulse of Los Angeles.

· Thomas Jefferson’s Monticello (as an example of traditional United States architecture) reflects Jefferson’s theory that public architecture should teach and delight. Gehry’s architectural intention is to enable audience interaction with the structure in accord with the structure’s purpose.

VH963728_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH963728_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of Summer Trees.
Response accurately describes one visual characteristic of Summer Trees
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

• The image consists of vertical overlapping bands of ink.

• The image contains a gradation of tones and opacities that range from light gray to deep black.

• The image includes no colors, only values of black and gray on white paper.

• Soft, bleeding bands and edges that indicate ink was applied to a wet surface.

• Opaque tones and rough lines show that ink was applied to dry paper.

• The vertical bands are an abstracted form of the trees in Song’s title and reference the landscape.

• The ends of strokes and the small dark lines that appear at the bottom of the page suggest the bottoms of tree trunks and, therefore, the ground.

• Alternating placement of the bands with the blacks on top suggests a shallow sense of space, another way of referencing landscape painting.

VH963728_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of Summer Trees references earlier painting traditions.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of Summer Trees references earlier painting traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Ink on paper

· Precisely controlled lines

· Use of black tones without color

· Subtle, expressive use of medium

· Tree motif with symbolic meaning

· Reference to natural world via title

VH963728_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH963728_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of Summer Trees departs from earlier painting traditions.
Response does accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how one characteristic of Summer Trees departs from earlier painting traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The trees are much more abstracted than in traditional East Asian works.

· The handling of the ink and composition place emphasis on formal qualities.

· The work shows some influence of Color Field painting, especially works of Morris Louis.

· No Korean characters or text are included.

VH963728_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain the meaning or significance of continuity and/or change between works of art (or group of related works of art) within a related artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VH963728_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain why Song Su-nam’s artistic decisions in creating Summer Trees were influenced by earlier painting traditions.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain why Song Su-nam's artistic decisions in creating Summer Trees were influenced by earlier painting traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Song’s choice of materials, traditional motif, and East Asian painting style reflect his involvement, in the 1980s, in Korea’s “Sumukhwa” or Oriental Ink Movement. The name of this group translates to “ink wash painting,” which references the scholar-poet or literati, painting tradition that emerged in eleventh-century China or earlier.

· Song rejected the mediums and styles of Western art, feeling that they did not express his Korean identity. This work’s embrace of a traditional painting style, subject, and medium demonstrates a sense of pride and connection to a distinct, noble East Asian painting history.

VH963751_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Does not provide two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art.
Response provides two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Preying Mantra

· Artist: Wangechi Mutu

· Medium: Mixed media on Mylar (collage)

· Date: 2006 (or the 2000s or a date within ten years of 2006)

· Culture: Born in Kenya, educated in England and the United States

Rebellious Silence, from the Women of Allah series

· Artist: Shirin Neshat

· Medium: Photography and ink

· Date: 1994 (or the 1990s or a date within ten years of 1994)

· Culture: Born in Iran, educated in Iran and the United States, lives in exile in the United States

Untitled (#228), from the History Portraits series

· Artist: Cindy Sherman

· Medium: Photography and ink

· Date: 1990 (or the 1990s or a date within ten years of 1990)

· Culture: Born, educated, and lives in the United States

VH963751_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
o.af:
Examples of possible claims include the following:

Preying Mantra

· In her work, Mutu focuses on her identity as a twenty-first-century African woman.

· Mutu’s work engages with the effects of colonial domination, particularly in her native Kenya.

· She focuses on female subjectivity, exoticism, and in the mixing of cultures, which produced a new cultural identity.

· Mutu creates works incorporating the female body, specifically an imagined “African” body that is subject to sexism and racism on a global scale.

Rebellious Silence, from the Women of Allah series

· In her work, Neshat explores the identity of contemporary Muslim women.

· Neshat works from her own experiences, having been born and raised in Iran and later educated in the United States, to focus on women’s identities.

· Neshat focuses on portraying Muslim woman and their personal and/or religious convictions through the lens of Western representation.

· Her works focus on the contradiction of the representation of women in Islamic cultural norms versus Western cultural norms, and how each portrays tradition and modernity. Included in this are how the women relate to their respective societies in public and private spheres.

· Neshat uses calligraphy in order to incorporate artistic traditions of Iran with the language of the Revolution including texts by women.

Untitled (#228), from the History Portraits series

· Sherman’s work addresses issues of female identity in Western culture.

· Her work often deals with issues of female identity, sexuality, and the objectification of women.

· Sherman’s work recreates works from older European art that depicts women in order to examine the construction of female identity.

· Although Sherman uses herself as the subject matter in her works, she attempts to hide herself both literally and figuratively, trying not to be recognized or look like any other character.

VH963751_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C EVIDENCE - VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH963751_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Preying Mantra

Visual Evidence:

· The subject in the work is reclining, with her crossed legs nearest the viewer, and is staring suggestively, with her right hand behind her head.

· The skin of the subject appears dappled by sunlight, and mirrors the colors of the surrounding tree leaves, which creates a camouflaging effect.

· A tree is positioned in the left foreground.

· A green snake can be seen close to the woman in the work.

· Throughout the work, Mutu has assembled (collaged) images related to Western culture

· Mutu has created a cone-like crown collage from images of feathers.

· Hanging from the left ear lobe of the woman are chicken feet, insect legs, and pinchers.

· The facial features of the woman show the use of magazine images.

Contextual Evidence:

· The tree (left side) reflects the creation myths of Kenyan ancestors, and could also be connected to the Christian idea of the Tree of Knowledge.

· The green serpent could be linked with the biblical narrative of Adam and Eve.

· The play on words in the title—“preying mantra” versus “praying mantis”--suggests the idea of hybridity.

· The blanket the subject rests upon resembles Kuba cloth, the traditional fabric of the Kuba people in the Congo.

Rebellious Silence, from the Women of Allah series

Visual Evidence:

· The image shows the a woman wearing a Muslim head scarf/chador.

· The woman’s face is covered in calligraphic text.

· A gun is positioned in front of the woman’s face, pointed upward, and visually dividing her face in half.

· One side of the woman’s face is in shadow.

Contextual Evidence:

· At the time of Neshat’s birth in Iran, the country was ruled by a Shah; the Shah was later overthrown by revolutionaries who abolished monarchy in favor of a conservative, theocratic government.

· The Farsi script continues a long line of Islamic calligraphic art. The text on this work is from Tahereh Saffarzedeh’s poem “Allegiance with Wakefulness,” which honors the conviction and bravery of martyrdom.

· Neshat included text that addressed emotional and sexual desires in her Women of Allah series, and was one of the first Iranian women to do so.

Untitled (#228), from the History Portraits series

Visual Evidence:

· The work recalls the scale, colors, and subject matter of many Renaissance and Baroque paintings.

· Although the work resembles a painting, it is actually a photograph.

· Sherman appears in the work dressed up to resemble a figure in a historical painting.

· Sherman is holding a head that resembles a Halloween mask.

· On closer inspection many objects in the work appear to be cheap replicas of what they represent.

Contextual Evidence:

· The content of this image comes from a biblical story of Judith who saves the Israelites from the conquering Assyrian general Holofernes by seducing and killing him by decapitation.

· Sherman portrays the biblical heroine Judith holding the head of Holofernes in one hand and a dagger in the other.

· Sherman’s work shows a strong similarity to the works of Renaissance artists.

· The subject was popular in Renaissance and Baroque art.

· Sherman wants her work to be seen as feminist in nature but not as Feminist art.

· Sherman’s work series entitled History Portraits re-creates pivotal works of Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical art.

· The color of the red drapery that Sherman wears can be associated with lust, seduction, blood, and violence.

VH963751_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Preying Mantra

· Mutu refers to the praying mantis both in the title and visually, with bent legs and a camouflage color. Rather than the depicted female figure being vulnerable to a sexual predator, the viewer is vulnerable to the subjects’ gaze, and may therefore be the victim who is preyed upon.

· Although continuing the Western theme of the reclining female nude, the female body in this work is depicted in a way that aesthetically departs from Western standards.

· The collage elements of the work support the notions of interwoven traditions, or hybridity, in post-colonial Africa.

· Mutu make use of the Western tradition of the reclining female nude, with pose and gaze female suggesting a position of power.

Rebellious Silence, from the Women of Allah series

· The artist has chosen specific symbols to represent the association of Western thought with representations of the Muslim world including the chador, the gun, text, and the subject’s gaze.

· As Neshat’s work was created during feminist movements in the United States and Europe, the artist chose to explore ways to reconcile the differences between these progressive movements and the reduction of women’s civil and political liberties in her native country of Iran.

· In the post-revolutionary Iranian period, the chador was a visible sign in public of women’s bodies being protected from becoming sexualized objects of the male gaze. Some women find the chador empowering and affirmative of religious identities but for Westerners, it can be seen as a sign of oppression.

· Oftentimes prior to this work, women were often portrayed in art as not returning the viewer’s gaze. In Neshat’s work, however, the subject is gazing back at the audience, freeing herself from this objectification.

· Neshat is influenced by the tradition of calligraphy in Middle Eastern and Indian cultures. Poetry is used in this series as the literal and symbolic voice of women.

Untitled (#228), from the History Portraits series

· Although Sherman is the subject in this work, she has made herself disappear into a created character through makeup, costumes, and settings designed, composed, lighted, and photographed by her.

· Sherman’s dominant female heroine serves as a contrast to the overtly masculine visions of the female in the history of art.

· Sherman’s works are made to appear artificial. By revealing herself in disguise, she is drawing attention to the staged and mannered nature of historical portrait paintings that she seeks to comment on with her work.

VH963751_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to developing any of the following:

Preying Mantra

· Mutu was born in Nairobi, Kenya, and did her post-secondary education later in Europe and the United States. Her work therefore shows a reflection of living in and knowing both African and Western cultures.

· With her work, Mutu explorer ways of depicting the human body that depart from traditional ideas of perfection.

Rebellious Silence, from the Women of Allah series

· Neshat was born and raised in Iran, and came to the United States to pursue higher education. Later, upon her return to Iran after the Revolution, she felt the country was completely different to the country she had known. The Women of Allah series was initiated shortly after her return to Iran, as she was haunted by the experience of her changed homeland.

· The Islamic Revolution allowed women to feel liberated from previous class structures and certain social constraints. The chador helps keep this balance, preventing the wearer from becoming a sexual object.

· By having text written across the images, Neshat is metaphorically enabling speech even when the subject may be in a situation not allowing full expression of thought and speech.

· Neshat considers her lifestyle to be American, but her personality Iranian. She considers her work to function as translation, conveying the meaning of one culture to the other in a visual language that communicate both sensibilities.

Untitled (#228), from the History Portraits series

· By using costumes, wigs, makeup, accessories, props, and masks, Sherman has changed female stereotypes and put her protagonist women in control of how they are represented.

· By recreating and at the same time manipulating a historical painting, Sherman makes a statement about the way we perceive ourselves and others, how our perception is mediated by the images that we encounter daily. Her photographs are meant to mislead.

· Sherman completed this series while living in Rome; however, she did not visit the works she used as references in person. Instead, she created her works based on reproductions in books, using the same print reproductions available to all consumers, because she wanted to comment on imagery that was available to everyone.

VH963770_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Does not provide two accurate identifiers for selected work of art
Response provides two accurate identifiers for selected work of art
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following.

The Gates

· Artists: Christo and Jeanne-Claude

· Location: New York City

· Materials: Mixed media installation (or steel, vinyl, and fabric)

· Date: 1970–2005 C.E. (Also acceptable: 1970’s to first decade of the 2000s or a date within 10 years of the original)

· Artist: Maya Lin

· Location: Washington, D.C., United States

· Materials: Granite

· Date: 1982 C.E. (Also acceptable: 1980s or a date within 10 years of the original)

VH963770_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
o.af:
Examples of possible claims might include the following:

The Gates

· The Gates interacted with the natural and built environment of Central Park in New York City, in order to intensify visitor awareness of the park.

· The temporary nature of The Gates gave the work a sense urgency. It quickly passed into memory, but while it existed, it changed the way New York’s iconic urban park was seen and experienced.

Vietnam Veterans Memorial

· The Vietnam Veterans Memorial transforms one of the most visited sites in Washington, D.C., the National Mall, in order to affect a large audience.

· The Vietnam Veterans Memorial transforms a part of the National Mall in order to cause visitors to immerse themselves into the experience of the memorial.

· The Vietnam Veterans Memorial transforms a part of the National Mall in order to memorialize without political intent the lives lost in the Vietnam War.

· The Vietnam Veterans Memorial transforms a place of historical and symbolic significance in Washington, D.C., the National Mall, in order to draw connections to the national history and identity of the United States.

VH963770_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C: EVIDENCE - VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH963770_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

The Gates

Visual Evidence

· Each gate consisted of a rigid orange vinyl frame with fabric of the same color hanging from the top.

· The Gates was installed along several miles of walkways throughout Central Park.

· Several thousand gates were installed on temporary steel platforms so that the poles were not permanently drilled into the grounds of the park, thereby protecting the roots of the trees.

· The brightly colored fabric was made of heavy nylon. It hung in pleats from metal gates.

· The Gates responded to the park’s pathways in that the width of each gate was relative to the size of the path.

· The appearance of the installation was affected by wind and weather conditions.

Contextual Evidence

· Because The Gates was installed in February, a river of bright saffron could be seen through the barren trees of the park.

· The Gates changed the way visitors saw and experienced moving throughout the park.

· The gates were installed on temporary steel platforms so that the poles were not permanently drilled into the grounds of the park, thereby protecting the roots of the trees.

· The project took nearly 30 years to complete after it was initially rejected.

Vietnam Veterans Memorial

Visual Evidence

· The memorial is made of polished black granite; it consists of two long wings that meet at an oblique angle.

· The walls of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial point on one end to the Washington Monument and on the other end to the Lincoln Memorial.

· Many thousands of names of United States service members who died in the Vietnam War are inscribed on the great slabs of black granite, creating a rougher texture on the otherwise smooth, reflective surface.

· The highly polished surface reflects the images of the visitors as they contemplate the dense field of the names of the dead and missing.

· The walls are sunken into the earth rather than rising into the sky as is often typical of monuments and memorials.

· Viewers follow a gentle descent from each end as they follow the names of the deceased in chronological order.

· The area within the memorial is quiet and meant for personal reflection.

Contextual Evidence

· Lin’s submission to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund was chosen for its simplicity and nonpartisan design.

· Lin’s design for the memorial made no comment on the controversial nature of the war and focused on the individuals who served and lost their lives.

· It is common to find gifts or remembrances left along the path, laid again the wall. Viewers may also create rubbings of names.

· The memorial is situated on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., in one of the most visited sites in the United States.

· The memorial is situated on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial.

VH963770_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

The Gates

· The Gates temporarily transformed Central Park in order to cause visitors to contemplate traditional ideals about what makes a landscape picturesque.

· As the wind caught the brightly colored nylon fabric, the visitor walking the pathways would be temporarily covered by a ceiling that looked like golden sunlight.

· Participants were meant to move, like the fabric, down the pathways in a sea of color that seemed to be without end.

· The fluttering saffron cloth raised above the walkways interacted with and transformed the natural and built environment of the park, thereby intensifying awareness of the park by the visitors.

Vietnam Veterans Memorial

· The movement from the initial descent at one end of the wall to the center and out again is emblematic of a cathartic journey through pain, grief, and acceptance.

· The black slabs of stone cut into the Earth to create what resembled a healed scar in the lush green grass of the Mall.

· The abstract and the intimate are combined in the stark design, with the list of individual names and the years of their deaths.

· The memorial is not meant to be static as viewers move along the path, touch the wall, and leave remembrances.

· The ends of the memorial connect to the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial, uniting with the past and reminding visitors of the high price paid in the defense of freedom throughout the nation’s history.

VH963770_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, development of any of the following:

The Gates

· Christo and Jeanne-Claude first proposed The Gates in 1976 but faced overwhelming opposition and complaints that the installation of their work would deface the iconic park. Even after approval in 2003, many viewed the work as in direct conflict with nature, despite the fact that Central Park is a human creation.

· Though no public money was used to fund the project, the support of newly elected mayor Michael Bloomberg, a collector of Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s work, was understood to be essential to the project moving forward.

Vietnam Veterans Memorial

· The organization in charge of the request for proposals, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, stipulated that the design must provide opportunities for reflection and include the names of all of the dead or missing.

· Opposition to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial centered on its Minimalist style. Critics argued that the memorial should be more traditional, with figurative elements that glorified war and service members. Many thought the choice of black granite as a symbol of mourning was a denigration of Vietnam veterans. Others fought against Lin as the designer because of her young age and Asian heritage. It was argued that the design competition should be reopened and the selection committee should be composed entirely of veterans. As a compromise, a statue grouping of soldiers and a raised American flag was incorporated into the nearby space.

· The Vietnam Veteran’s Memorial remains one of the most visited works of public art in the country.

VH966402_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how artistic decisions about form, style, materials, technique, or content shape the work
VH966402_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: The response does not accurately uses specific evidence to explain a technique Cezanne uses to create a sense of space in this work.
The response accurately uses specific evidence to explain one technique Cezanne uses to create a sense of space in this work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The size of the tree makes it appear close to the viewer.

· The overlapping shapes of the tree trunk, the branches, and the ground on which it stands make them appear to be in front of the lake and the opposite shore.

· The small scale of the houses creates the sense that they are relatively far away.

· The use of blue in between the branches refers to the sky.

· The use of consistent colors throughout the painting makes the visual space shallow; the farthest mountaintops look as close as the shore of the lake, for example.

o.d: The response accurately uses specific evidence to explain two techniques Cezanne uses to create a sense of space in this work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The overlapping shapes of the tree trunk, the branches, and the ground on which it stands make them appear to be in front of the lake and the opposite shore.

· The small scale of the houses creates the sense that they are relatively far away.

· The use of blue in between the branches refers to the sky.

· The use of consistent colors throughout the painting makes the visual space shallow; the farthest mountaintops look as close as the shore of the lake, for example.

VH966402_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how this work departs from earlier Western traditions of landscape painting
VH966402_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately explain how this work departs from earlier Western traditions of landscape painting.
The response accurately explains how this work departs from earlier Western traditions of landscape painting.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· There is no use of aerial or linear perspective.

· The top of the painting does not look like it is in the far distance.

· Colors are not blended into each other to model the forms of the mountains.

· The landscape on the far side of the lake is depicted through fractured areas of color with straight lines and angles; this makes the representation somewhat abstract.

· The parallel lines and similar colors of the tree branches and the mountain slopes contribute to the abstraction and help to make the painting as much about design on the surface as about literal depiction of landscape.

· The colors are somewhat arbitrary in that they are not affected as much by their distance from the viewer as they would be in earlier Western traditions.

VH973086_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH973086_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Taj Mahal.
Response does accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Taj Mahal.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit include the following:

· The Taj Mahal is a large central-plan, octagonal structure topped by a dome.

· There are minarets at the four corners and a monumental pointed-arch (iwan) door on each side.

· The Taj Mahal is elevated on a platform and is the focus of a larger complex.

· The entire exterior is made of white marble.

· The design and the use of white make the structure appear to hover or float.

· The complex includes a gateway structure and forecourt, a mosque, and a lavish garden of waterways, fountains, flowers, and trees laid out in a strict geometric plan.

· The exterior of the Taj Mahal is covered with luxurious carved ornamentation, displaying both real and fantastic floral motifs and Qur’anic verses in script, as well as inlaid, semiprecious stones.

· The interior view shows the cenotaph (above the actual coffin) surrounded by white marble, carved screens.

VH973086_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VH973086_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the specific function of the Taj Mahal.
Response does accurately describe the specific function of the Taj Mahal.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit include the following:

· The Taj Mahal was built by Mughal Dynasty ruler Shah Jahan as a mausoleum for his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal, who died in childbirth.

· The Taj Mahal serves as the final resting place for both the wife of the Mughal Shah Jahan, as well as the Shah himself, who was entombed there upon his death decades after his wife.

VH973086_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH973086_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the function influenced the design of the Taj Mahal.
Response uses one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the function influenced the design of the Taj Mahal.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit include the following:

· The monumental size and use of white marble distinguish the Taj Mahal from the other, red sandstone buildings of the complex, emphasizing the central importance of the building within the complex.

· The central chamber holds the cenotaphs of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal.

· The Taj Mahal lies at the highest point in the grounds and dominates views from the gardens and the surrounding area.

· The use of white suggests connection with divine principles.

· The design of the Taj Mahal invokes the idea of the Hasht Bihisht, or “Eight Paradises” mentioned in the Qur’an, through its interior plan, which consists of eight small chambers arranged around the central octagonal room where the cenotaphs of the Shah and Mumtaz are located.

· Shah Jahan was a ruler of the Islamic Mughal dynasty, under which the arts and architecture of India blended Persian and Central Asian influences.

· Visible influences from Islamic architecture of Persia and Central Asia include the iwans, the central-plan mausoleum, the minarets, arches, and dome and the chahar bagh four-quadrant design of the garden.

Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain why the design of the Taj Mahal can be interpreted as a representation of paradise.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit include the following:

· The gardens surrounding the Taj Mahal can be interpreted as symbolic of the gardens of Paradise described in the Qur’an and referenced in the Qur’anic script that decorates the building.

· The dominant floral theme in the ornamentation is associated with Paradise.

· The white marble, which is associated with the priestly classes and saints, suggests an elevated spiritual status for Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal.

· The elevation of the Taj Mahal on a platform, surrounded by reflecting waterways, creates the illusion that the mausoleum is the Throne of God perched above the gardens of Paradise, a symbol of the Shah’s imperial and heavenly reign.

VH973545_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how artistic decisions about form, style, materials, technique, and/or content shape a work of art.
VH973545_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

VH973556_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
o.af:
Examples of possible claims include the following:

Dome of the Rock

· The Dome of the Rock was built as an Islamic monument to promote and accommodate Islamic worship in a city already sacred to Jews and Christians.

· The Dome of the Rock was built on a sacred site to purposefully establish Islam as a worthy successor to the earlier Jewish and Christian faiths.

· The Dome of the Rock surrounds a rock believed by Muslims to be sacred in character because of its association with the prophet Muhammad.

The Kaaba

· The Kaaba is the focus of Muslim worship in that it functions as Islam’s most sacred shrine.

· The Kaaba is a destination site for pilgrims seeking to fulfill their religious obligation.

VH973556_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Dome of the Rock

Visual Evidence

· The dome of the structure was originally made of gold. It is currently made of aluminum covered with gold leaf.

· The octagonal building includes a double ambulatory surrounding the central rock.

· Verses from the Qu’ran are included in the ornamentation of both the interior and the exterior of the structure. The verses include the shahada, the Islamic confession of faith. They also refer to the Christian Jesus and Mary.

· The interior mosaic decoration also includes lush vegetal imagery along with crowns, jewels, chalices, and other royal motifs.

Contextual Evidence

· The Dome of the Rock is located on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. It is built upon what is known as the Noble Enclosure, the site of the ancient Jewish Temple of Solomon.

· It is one of the first Islamic buildings ever constructed.

· The Dome of the Rock is located near a similarly centrally planned Christian structure, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

· Some traditions suggest that the site marks the grave of Adam.

· Some traditions suggest that the site marks the spot where Abraham prepared to sacrifice his son Isaac.

· Islamic tradition holds that Muhammad ascended to Heaven from the spot on a winged creature called al-Buraq. During the so-called Night Journey, known as the Miraj, the prophet Muhammad met Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and other prophets and prayed with them.

· Throughout its history, the Dome of the Rock has displayed sacred relics of the prophet Muhammad.

The Kaaba

Visual Evidence

· The cubic structure stands isolated in a large, open space within a mosque in the center of the city of Mecca.

· The Kaaba is draped each year in a new black cloth, called a kiswa, embroidered with a band of sacred verses in gold and silver thread.

· The Kaaba houses the Black Stone, a sacred relic, in its southeastern corner.

Contextual Evidence

· According to Muslim tradition, the Kaaba was built by Abraham and his son Ishmael.

· The Black Stone is believed to have been given to Abraham by the angel Gabriel.

· According to Muslim tradition, the Kaaba was cleansed of its idols (statues of pagan gods) by Muhammad.

· Muslims circumambulate the structure seven times.

· Around the world, Muslims are required to pray in the direction of Mecca, the site of the Kaaba, five times a day.

· One of the five pillars of the Islamic faith, required of all Muslims, is to make a hajj, or pilgrimage, to Mecca, the site of the Kaaba.

· The Kaaba, its surrounding mosque, and the entire city of Mecca are off-limits to all non-Muslims.

· The mosque that surrounds the Kaaba is the largest in the world.

· Muslims must enter the sacred area around Mecca in a state of ihram, or purity. For men, this includes wearing a special dress of two seamless white sheets.

VH973556_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Dome of the Rock

· The gold dome of the Dome of the Rock enabled the structure to be seen from all over Jerusalem. All who came to the city, regardless of religion, would have seen the structure as a tribute to the Islamic faith.

· The centrally planned, octagonal structure is similar in design and size to the nearby Church of the Holy Sepulcher, suggesting a desire to compete with the Christian faith by promoting Islam as a worthy successor to its religious rival.

· The verses of the Qur’an are the earliest known ornamental use of these texts.

· The verses of the Qur’an displayed at the Dome of the Rock promote the beliefs of Islam and suggest, through references to Jesus and Mary, that Islam serves as a worthy successor to the Christian faith. The interior inscription refutes the Christian Trinity, exhorting all to recognize Allah as the one true God.

· The motifs of the interior mosaics, evoking paradise and royal power, allude to the triumph of Islam under the rule of the Umayyads that built the structure.

· Later teaching about the Dome of the Rock, in particular its association with the Night Journey of Muhammad, increased its importance as an Islamic sacred destination.

The Kaaba

· The decoration of the Kaaba with the kiswa (the embroidered black cloth) demonstrates the reverence and perpetual care bestowed upon the structure.

· The Kaaba’s presence within the world’s largest mosque demonstrates the respect the Kaaba has within the Islamic world, its vast surrounding space allowing for large crowds who arrive as pilgrims to use the structure as the focus of their worship.

· The presence of the Black Stone in the Kaaba, traditionally believed to have been placed there by Muhammad, reinforces the importance of the Kaaba in Islam. In imitation of Muhammad’s reverence for the stone, Muslims demonstrate their devotion for the relic by touching and/or kissing the stone. The Kaaba’s importance is derived from the traditional belief that it was built by Abraham and Ishmael, serving as a physical reminder of the links between Islam and Judaism.

· The Kaaba serves as a kind of memorial to Muhammad’s conquest of the city of Mecca, commemorating the time when the prophet cleansed the Kaaba of its idols and established for all Muslims a sacred site intended for the pure worship of Allah.

· The act of circumambulating the Kaaba allows Muslims to demonstrate their solidarity in the large space surrounding the structure, recognizing the Kaaba as the focus of their communal worship.

· By coming to Mecca in large numbers and preparing themselves to enter in a state of purity, Muslims maintain a sense of unity represented by the Kaaba itself.

· As the Kaaba is believed to be located in the center of the Islamic universe, its importance is highlighted by the fact that all mosques around the world accommodate Muslim worship by orienting the faithful to pray in the direction of the sacred structure.

VH973556_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining the nuances of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, developing any of the following:

Dome of the Rock

· The Dome of the Rock may have served as a kind of victory memorial. Among the mosaic decorations within are winged crowns that were worn by the Sasanian kings who were defeated by Arab armies. Thus, the decorations emphasize the triumph of the Arabs and of Islam.

· The caliph, Abdul al-Malik, who had the Dome of the Rock built, may have wished to create a monument that would rival the holy sites of Arabia, which were generally inaccessible to his people because of civil war.

· Abdul al-Malik, seeing the prosperity that Jewish and Christian pilgrims brought to the city of Jerusalem, may have wished to increase the city’s wealth by creating a monument that appealed to Muslim pilgrims as well.

The Kaaba

· As the Kaaba was sacred to Meccans before the time of the Prophet, instead of diminishing its importance, Muslims repurposed the structure to accommodate and promote the Islamic faith.

· Muhammad’s purging of idols within the Kaaba speaks to a general ban placed on figurative imagery within Islam.

· Other pious acts of devotion are performed at Mecca, such as the casting of stones at three large pillars to symbolize the stoning of the devil. These reinforce the sacred character of the site surrounding the Kaaba.
