VH973573_rubric_category_1.s: To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
Responds to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
o.af:
Examples of possible claims include the following:

Bamiyan Buddha

· The Bamiyan Buddhas are evidence of the spread of Buddhism from South Asia to the Middle East.

· The Bamiyan Buddhas reflect stylistic elements seen in Hellenistic, Persian, and South Asian art.

· The Bamiyan Buddhas reflect the influence of Mediterranean, Persian, and South Asian cultures through Bamiyan’s location on the Silk Road.

Bahram Gur Fights the Karg

· This Mongol representation from the Persian Book of Kings (the Shahnama) was influenced by the art of China.

· This folio combines aspects of Chinese painting and pre-Islamic Persian traditions.

Petra

· The design of the architecture at Petra reflects the cross-cultural influences on Nabataean culture that resulted from trade.

· The design of the architecture at Petra reflects the influence of Hellenistic culture from the Mediterranean region on Nabataean art.

· The design of the architecture at Petra reflects the influence of Hellenistic culture from the city of Alexandria, the Greek mainland, the islands of the Aegean, and Asia Minor.

· The architecture of Petra reflects the location of the ancient metropolis on the crossroads between important trade routes that connected Mediterranean cultures with Arabia and cultures of Asia and which facilitated a rich cultural exchange.

VH973573_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C: EVIDENCE - VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VH973573_rubric_category_2.s: To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
Response provides one specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Bamiyan Buddha

Visual Evidence

· The Bamiyan Buddhas are typical of Buddhist cave architecture that was common throughout Asia.

· Flowing drapery or robes and treatment of the figure resemble Hellenistic elements, found in Buddhist art from around the same period.

· As one finds in Classical and Hellenistic sculpture, the Buddhas were originally painted.

Contextual Evidence

· Bamiyan was located along the Silk Route, a rich trade route between the East and the West, stretching from Turkey to China.

· Many travelers along this route were Buddhists, and Bamiyan, as a fertile area, was a good place to stop along the route to worship.

· It was possible to circumambulate around the monumental Buddhas, as there was space for this around the heads and (in one Buddha) the feet of the figures; this is similar to the circumambulation at other Buddhist sites.

Bahram Gur Fights the Karg

Visual Evidence

· This is an example of a book illumination on paper.

· An abundance of landscape elements fill the scene, such as trees, earth, plants, and grass.

· An asymmetrical composition is used, in which Bahram Gur is not directly in the center of the image.

· Calligraphic text is included with the image.

Contextual Evidence

· The Mongols were a nomadic people who originated in central Asia.

· The Mongols fostered economic growth, and art flourished; book illustration thrived, and books were items of prestige.

· The story shown is from the Shahnama, and although it was produced during the Mongol period, it uses elements of the Persian hero worship tradition of Persia before Islam.

Petra

Visual Evidence

· The facade of the Treasury at Petra contains Corinthian columns, which were first developed in Hellenistic Greece.

· The facade of the Treasury at Petra contains a central tholos and a broken pediment that are Hellenistic Greek motifs that originated in Alexandria.

· The sculptural ornamentation of the Treasury includes figures from Greek mythology (such as Amazons, Victories, Greek gods) and Egyptian symbols as well as traditionally Near Eastern motifs, such as rosettes.

Contextual Evidence

· The metropolis of Petra contained many elements of a typical ancient Greek or ancient Roman city, such as a Greek theater, baths, a colonnaded street, and a nymphaeum.

· Inscriptions found at the tombs written in Nabataean, Greek, and Latin provide evidence of this cultural exchange.

· Petra gained wealth in the spice trade through its location between the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea; Egypt is located to the west, Syria to the east, Greece and Turkey to the north, and Saudi Arabia to the south.

VH973573_rubric_category_3.s: To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
Response explains how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Bamiyan Buddha

· Circumambulation is a common worshipping practice for Buddhists, as seen at the Great Stupa at Sanchi.

· The figures and drapery of the Bamiyan Buddhas are characteristic of the Gandharan Style of Buddhist art that emerged during the Kushan Period in India, which combined elements from Hellenistic, Persian, and Indian artistic traditions.

Bahram Gur Fights the Karg

· Paper was invented in China in the eighth century.

· The landscape elements are reminiscent of the same elements in Chinese hanging scrolls and ceramics.

· Asymmetrical composition suggests eastern Asian influences.

· More specific influences of Chinese painting include the depiction of the gnarled trees, the use of overlapping forms to create the illusion of space, and the brushstrokes that create the grasses in the foreground.

· The use of text appears in Chinese paintings on paper.

· The Mongols had a long and robust tradition of storytelling.

· Persian traditions included the depiction of mounted heroes, kings, and warriors.

Petra

· The presence of different Hellenistic Greek elements and iconography in the facade of the Treasury demonstrate the exposure of Nabataean society to artistic influences from Hellenistic Greece through the involvement of the Nabataeans in long-distance spice trade that connected Asia, Arabia, and the Mediterranean.

· The presence of many Greco-Roman building types in the city of Petra also shows the connection of the Nabataeans with Greco-Roman culture of the Mediterranean through their control of the long-distance spice trade.

· The presence of rosettes on the facade of the Treasury in Petra shows that the Nabataeans were also exposed to Near Eastern art through their involvement in long-distance spice trade that connected Asia, Arabia, and the Mediterranean.

· The mix of different regional styles and the presence of inscriptions in different languages in the rock-cut tombs at Petra reflect the importance of long-distance trade and cross-cultural influences in Nabataean culture at Petra, with its central location in the spice trade network.

VH973573_rubric_category_4.s:
A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining the nuances of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt

Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt

Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, developing any of the following:
o.af:
Bamiyan Buddha

· As trade expanded, South Asian ideas spread widely, as did Buddhism. This hampered the spread of Hinduism, as Buddhism spread to new communities.

· Research has shown that the two monumental Buddha figures as well as several cave chapels at the site were originally painted, much like the rock-cut Ajanta Caves in Maharashtra, India, suggesting additional connection with artistic traditions in that region.

· At Bamiyan, visitors who wanted to circumambulate the smaller (115 foot) Buddha climbed a staircase inside the cliff up to the level of the Buddha’s shoulder, thus, well above ground level. At the top of the ladder, they could see the top of the vault that surrounded the Buddha, which was painted with an image of the sun god, suggesting in this particular circumambulation a metaphorical journey to heaven.

Bahram Gur Fights the Karg

· The Mongol rulers wanted to associate their rule with Persian heroes and an illustrious Persian past.

· Bahram Gur represents a just ruler and civilized society that defeats the horned wolf, a symbol of chaos and disorder.

· Because the Mongols had a strong oral tradition, they greatly appreciated narrative art that was later translated into their illuminated manuscript production.

· Because the Mongols had been a nomadic people, they treasured small, portable luxury goods such as illuminated books.

· All three traditions (Mongol, Persian, and Chinese) come together in this painting.

Petra

· The size and splendor of the city of Petra, despite its location in the desert, provides evidence for the wealth that the Nabataeans gained from their control of the spice trade routes and further attests to the importance that long-distance trade played in their culture.

· While the Treasury in Petra as well as other rock-cut structures use traditional Greek elements in their facades, they also use and combine them in oftentimes nontraditional ways, combining them with artistic elements from other cultures or ignoring classic rules of Greek architecture (e.g., columns are spaced unevenly).

· Corinthian columns were common in Hellenistic temples and tombs; their presence in the Treasury of Petra, which is thought to have served as the tomb of a ruler, further demonstrates continuity with Hellenistic traditions.

· Alexandria was a prosperous seaport and a great learning center, which helped to spread Greek cultural influence throughout the Mediterranean.

VH975944_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Identify a work of art.
VH975944_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not provide two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art.
Response provides two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

· Culture: Japan, Muromachi period

· Location: Kyoto, Japan

· Materials: light gray gravel, rocks, moss

· Date: Muromachi period, ca. 1480 C.E.; current design most likely dates to the seventeenth century

Under the Wave off Kanagawa

· Artist: Katsushika Hokusai

· Culture: Japan, Edo Period

· Date: 1830-1833 c.e.

VH975944_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH975944_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the specific content of Travelers among Mountains and Streams.
Response does accurately describe the specific content of Travelers among Mountains and Streams.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· It is a monochromatic ink painting of a mountainous landscape on vertically oriented paper.

· The mountains occupy the majority of the paper.

· A road separates the foreground and middle ground.

· Tiny people with donkeys are visible in the foreground if one looks closely.

· The elements of the landscape are rendered in a naturalist fashion; they look convincing.

· Precise control of brush and ink are used to create detailed rocks, boulder, trees, and mountains.

· Mist at the foot of the mountains (blank space on the paper) creates the illusion that the mountains are far off.

· The work represents the vastness and overwhelming quality of nature compared to the small and insignificant presence of humans.

· It does not aim to represent an exact imitation or likeness of nature, but rather the essence of nature captured through a carefully composed arrangement of natural forms.

VH975944_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH975944_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the specific content of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe specific content of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

· Ryoan-ji is a Zen Buddhist temple located in Kyoto, Japan.

· The garden is contained within a walled courtyard in the temple complex of Ryoan-ji.

· The garden contains a karesansui, or dry landscape rock garden, which consists of pebbles and rocks arranged in a composition that represents a natural landscape.

· Fifteen large rocks are set in the gravel in a deliberate, carefully thought-out arrangement.

· There are no plants other than an area of moss around each of the large rocks.

· The gravel is raked into patterns, primarily horizontal with a rind around each of the rock “islands.”

· The rocks are positioned so that a viewer cannot see all of them at once.

· On the far side of the wall, trees and plants contrast with the dry garden.

Under the Wave off Kanagawa

· Under the Wave off Kanagawa is one print in a series of works that focus on individual views of Mount Fuji, the most prominent natural landscape feature in Japan.

· Under the Wave depicts the iconic Japanese mountain in the distance, behind a looming sea wave that dominates the foreground.

· Most of the space in the image is occupied by the giant wave; in its trough, there are long boats with fishermen and Mount Fuji is visible in the distance.

· The boats appear to be at the mercy of the wave, with the wave seeming to be about to crash on the boats.

VH975944_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH975944_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity or difference in how the two works represent the natural world.
Response uses specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity or difference in how the two works represent the natural world.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

Similarities

· Both works depict composed natural landscapes that contain elements representing mountains, streams, and waterfalls.

· Both works are carefully composed arrangements of forms.

· Both works represent the natural landscape as a vehicle for spiritual understanding or enlightenment.

Differences

· Ryoan-ji is a three-dimensional space that consists of a walled area that contains rocks, pebbles, and moss; Fan Kuan’s work is a two-dimensional ink painting on silk.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams creates an illusion of space on a flat surface; the garden exists in space.

· Ryoan-ji represents the natural world in a symbolic way; Fan Kuan represents the natural world in a more detailed and naturalistic manner.

· The landscape at Ryoan-ji is designed to be seen from one specific vantage point, where the viewer should stand. Fan Kuan’s painting is designed to suggest multiple viewpoints on the scene as parts of the scene are seen frontally and others are seen from an aerial vantage point.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams is rich in detail; the garden at Ryoan-ji is very spare and simple.

· The dominant orientation of Travelers among Mountains and Streams is vertical; at Ryoan-ji, it is horizontal.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams includes some representation of people and of human structures; the garden at Ryoan-ji is viewed by people who do not step inside it; no people are in it.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams shows a landscape that appears primarily untouched by people, while Ryoan-ji is a landscape that was created by people.

· The landscape in Travelers among Mountains and Streams is contrived to look informal and natural; the garden at Ryoan-ji is contrived to look (and be) orderly.

Under the Wave off Kanagawa

Similarities

· Both works prominently feature a mountain or mountains.

· Both works include the representation of humans within the landscape.

· In both works, people are subordinate to nature.

· Both works focus on the impressive size and power of nature through comparison: Fan Kuan’s painting by emphasizing the monumental mountains as compared to the miniscule humans and animals; and Hokusai’s print depicts the wave as enormous compared to the distant Mount Fuji.

Differences

· Hokusai represents a specific, recognizable landmark; Fan Kuan represents an ideal representation of the Chinese landscape.

· Hokusai uses color in his work; Fan Kuan uses black ink for a limited color palette of black and gray tones.

· Fan Kuan’s work is a monumental painting; Hokusai’s is a small woodblock print.

· Fan Kuan included a wealth of detail in his painting; Hokusai’s work contrasts flat areas with areas of detail.

· Hokusai incorporated aspects of Western linear perspective into his work; Fan Kuan uses a traditional Chinese representation of perspective.

· In Hokusai’s work, water is represented as the largest landscape feature; in Fan Kuan’s work, the mountains are emphasized.

· Differences in the compositions add to the dynamism of Hokusai’s work in comparison with the serenity of Fan Kuan’s; these include Hokusai’s emphasis on the wave in the foreground versus Fan’s emphasis on the mountains in the background.

o.d: Response accomplishes both parts of this task.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

Similarities

· Both works depict composed natural landscapes that contain elements representing mountains, streams, and waterfalls.

· Both works are carefully composed arrangements of forms.

· Both works represent the natural landscape as a vehicle for spiritual understanding or enlightenment.

Differences

· Ryoan-ji is a three-dimensional space that consists of a walled area that contains rocks, pebbles, and moss; Fan Kuan’s work is a two-dimensional ink painting on silk.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams creates an illusion of space on a flat surface; the garden exists in space.

· Ryoan-ji represents the natural world in a symbolic way; Fan Kuan represents the natural world in a more detailed and naturalistic manner.

· The landscape at Ryoan-ji is designed to be seen from one specific vantage point, where the viewer should stand. Fan Kuan’s painting is designed to suggest multiple viewpoints on the scene as parts of the scene are seen frontally and others are seen from an aerial vantage point.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams is rich in detail; the garden at Ryoan-ji is very spare and simple.

· The dominant orientation of Travelers among Mountains and Streams is vertical; at Ryoan-ji, it’s horizontal.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams includes some representation of people and of human structures; the garden at Ryoan-ji is viewed by people who do not step inside it; no people are in it.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams shows a landscape that appears primarily untouched by people, while Ryoan-ji is a landscape that was created by people.

· The landscape in Travelers among Mountains and Streams is contrived to look informal and natural; the garden at Ryoan-ji is contrived to look (and be) orderly.

Under the Wave off Kanagawa (Kanagawa oki nami ura)

Similarities

· Both works prominently feature a mountain or mountains.

· Both works include the representation of humans within the landscape.

· In both works, people are subordinate to nature.

· Both works focus on the impressive size and power of nature through comparison: Fan Kuan’s painting by emphasizing the monumental mountains as compared to the miniscule humans and animals; and Hokusai’s print depicts the wave as enormous compared to the distant Mount. Fuji.

Differences

· Hokusai represents a specific, recognizable landmark; Fan Kuan represents an ideal representation of the Chinese landscape.

· Hokusai uses color in his work; Fan Kuan uses black ink for a limited color palette of black and gray tones.

· Fan Kuan’s work is a monumental painting; Hokusai’s is a small woodblock print.

· Fan Kuan included a wealth of detail in his painting; Hokusai’s work contrasts flat areas with areas of detail.

· Hokusai incorporated aspects of Western linear perspective into his work; Fan Kuan uses a traditional Chinese representation of perspective.

· In Hokusai’s work, water is represented as the largest landscape feature; in Fan Kuan’s work, the mountains are emphasized.

· Differences in the compositions add to the dynamism of Hokusai’s work in comparison with the serenity of Fan Kuan’s; these include Hokusai’s emphasis on the wave in the foreground versus Fan Kuan’s emphasis on the mountains in the background.

VH975944_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH975944_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one similarity or difference in how both works convey ideas about the relationship between humans and nature within their respective cultures.
Response does accurately explain one similarity or difference in how both works convey ideas about the relationship between humans and nature within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

Similarities

· Both works were created out of a belief that the contemplation of nature is important.

· Both works represent an idea of nature, or an attempt to capture the essence of nature, rather than an attempt of a faithful representation.

Differences

· The representation of nature at Ryoan-ji is meant to inspire viewers to turn inward for enlightenment, rather than to find it in nature. Fan Kuan’s painting represents nature to convey to the viewer the sense of truth and harmony found within nature itself.

· The dry garden at Ryoan-ji is a place where monks perform such ritual actions as sweeping and raking to compose and control the represented landscape. Fan Kuan represents the human element in his painting as small and insignificant compared to the power of nature itself.

Under the Wave off Kanagawa (Kanagawa oki nami ura)

Similarities

· Both works express the idea that nature is a powerful force and important for humans.

· Both works portray human intervention as having little visible impact on nature.

Differences

· Hokusai’s work represents nature as potentially dangerous and threatening; in Fan Kuan’s painting, nature is seen as overwhelming but peaceful.

· While Hokusai’s print can be said to include a reference to the sacred landscape, Fan Kuan’s painting can be seen as a representation of the way that nature embodies spiritual energies and forces that create an order to the world.

· Hokusai’s work depicts an iconic, familiar image of Mount Fuji; Fan Kuan’s representation of nature is rooted in a deep, solitary observation of nature.

VH975944_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH975944_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence about Travelers among Mountains and Streams in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific evidence about Travelers among Mountains and Streams in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point include the following:

Visual evidence

· Although there are both people and a temple in the painting (a sign of human activity), they are tiny and difficult to see.

· The painting is a huge compilation of detail that suggest that the artist observed and studied natural forms close up.

· The size of the painting means that a viewer could visually “get lost” in it, as the artist did in real mountains.

· Fan Kuan used contrast between large and small, mountain and mist, earth and water, black and white, etc., which can be seen as a demonstration of the way that nature contains contrasting forces and energies that remain in balance and harmony.

Contextual evidence

· Fan Kuan was a Song Dynasty painter whose work is associated with Neo-Confucian beliefs about nature, which are also influenced by Chinese Daoism and Buddhist ideas.

· Fan Kuan was a reclusive landscape artist, who sought refuge from political unrest in the search for spiritual enlightenment through an experience of nature’s harmony.

· Fan Kuan studied and painted the mountains repeatedly.

· Fan Kuan considered immersion in nature to be more important than social interaction.

· Travelers among Mountains and Streams is an example of Chinese landscape painting from the Song Dynasty period; like other Chinese landscape painters, Fan Kuan’s goal was to capture the essence of nature, rather than to reproduce the image of an actual place.

· Fan Kuan has been described as a Neo-Confucianist and Daoist (a Chinese philosophy that emphasizes a harmonious relationship with the natural world).

· Through landscape paintings, Fan Kuan was able to visualize concepts of balance and harmony that underlie beliefs about the natural order in Neo-Confucian and Daoist spirituality.

VH975944_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH975944_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence about the selected work in the explanation
Response does accurately use specific evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point include the following:

Ryoan-ji

Visual evidence

· The rocks are deliberately surrounded only by moss and raked gravel to make it possible for viewers to contemplate the individual characteristics of each rock.

· Because the work is three-dimensional, viewers can also see and reflects on the shifts in view that come from walking along the sides.

· Instead of only revering nature without interference, the artists designed the garden through interference, selecting and arranging rocks, etc.

Contextual evidence

· Ryoan-ji is a temple where Buddhist monks conducted their Zen training, which focused on an individual’s mental calm and control, as attained through meditation and ritual actions.

· Zen Buddhism centers on an individual’s journey to attain enlightenment through discipline, concentration, and by transcending the desires of the material world.

· The garden was meant to inspire meditation and interior contemplation for the monks who lived at the monastery.

· The garden itself is not a place that ordinary viewers can enter; viewers cannot physically interact with the objects of their meditation.

Under the Wave off Kanagawa

Visual evidence

· Hokusai chose woodblock, a medium that allows large editions to be created; the prints could therefore be sold inexpensively.

· The people in Hokusai’s print are depicted as being at terrible risk and subjected to the mercy of nature.

· The overall effect of Under the Great Wave is of the tremendous, untamable power of the sea.

Contextual evidence

· The work is an ukiyo-e print, part of the genre of “pictures of the floating world,” artworks depicting subjects that had broad appeal to a newly emerging middle-class and emphasized the fleeting and ephemeral nature of life.

· Mount Fuji has historically been considered a sacred mountain in Japanese culture.

· The series of which it is a part, Thirty-six Views of Mount Fuji, demonstrates a cultural familiarity and iconicity associated with the image of Mount Fuji.

VH976056_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

VH976056_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Justify the attribution by explaining similarities with work by a specific culture from the image set.
VH976056_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of specific visual evidence to justify the attribution by describing relevant similarities between the work shown and other work of the same type by the same African culture.

Response uses one example of specific visual evidence to justify the attribution by describing relevant similarities between the work shown and other work of the same type by the same African culture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The object is a brass relief plaque with holes for attachment at the top and bottom.

· It depicts an armed leader at the center, flanked by two additional armed warriors; four smaller, simpler figures are between the central figure and the attendants at the top and bottom of the plaque.

· The work uses hierarchic scale: the central figure is larger than the two attendant warriors, who are larger than the four small figures.

· Similarly, the central figure’s clothing and armor are the most detailed and elaborate; the small figures’ are the least so.

· Figures are depicted with heads that are proportionately larger than the bodies, using a 1:4 ratio of head to body.

· The figures have stylized facial features (such as raised ridges around the eyes, broad noses, and wide mouths).

· Overall, the plaque shows a high level of technical expertise; not only are the details clear and plentiful but, within the limited low-relief depth, the artist has arranged forms so that there is clear spatial recession.

· The amount of fineness of detail in the plaque suggests that is was made by lost-wax casting.

o.d: Response uses two examples of specific visual evidence to justify the attribution by describing relevant similarities between the work shown and other work of the same type by the same African culture.

VH976056_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH976056_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of visual or contextual-specific evidence to explain how the work reflects the cultural context in which works of this type were created.
Response uses one example of specific visual or contextual evidence to explain how the work reflects the cultural context in which works of this type were created.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The object is a brass plaque or relief that was used to decorate the walls or posts of the royal palace, affirming it as the political and spiritual center of the kingdom of Benin.

· Similarly, it affirmed the power of the king (oba) who commissioned it.

· Brass was associated with Ogun, the god of metal and war, and was a material believed to have protective powers.

· Brass cast using the lost-wax method was reserved for royal commissions or for royally sanctioned commissions from the elite.

· The larger size of each head symbolized the belief that the head referred to a person’s intelligence or character and had a special role in guiding one’s destiny and promoting success.

· The stylized facial features, combining naturalistic and ideal forms, were influenced by the aesthetics associated with artistic traditions of the Yoruba peoples of Ife (a culture with dynastic and artistic connections to the Edo peoples of Benin).

· The hierarchic scale used for the large central, frontal figure dressed in regalia affirmed the political and spiritual power of the leader. The smaller size of the attendant figures holding objects that reinforced the authority of the leader showed that these figures had lesser rank and, at the same time, suggested that the leader depended on the support of his subordinates.

VH976064_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of specific visual evidence to justify the attribution by describing relevant similarities between the work shown and other work of the same type by the same African culture.

o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The figure is shown seated cross-legged on a raised platform and with a calm facial expression and closed eyes.

· The figure’s head, shoulders, and stomach are rounded; the collarbones are well defined.

· The head is 1/3 of the sculpture’s height.

· The figure is an idealized portrait of a king rather than an individualized representation.

· Details of the belts, armbands, bracelets, and shoulder ornaments are part of the royal regalia, as is the projecting headdress at the top of the work.

· The work is carved from hardwood, then burnished and frequently anointed with palm oil, which gives it a dark, glossy surface.

VH976064_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how the possible intent, purpose, and/or function shape the creation of meaning of a work of art.
VH976064_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to accurately explain the function of this type of work.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain the function of this type of work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Ndop (which literally means “statue”) were commissioned by individual leaders to record their reigns for posterity; their choice of individual motifs helped to identify them.

· The ndop were kept in the palace, in a shrine in the women’s quarters; the women kept the ndop burnished and oiled.

· Ndop were believed to have magical powers; for example, one would be placed near a woman about to give birth to assure a safe delivery.

· Based on the ndop’s individual characteristics, such as the drum between the king’s hands, a knowledgeable person can figure out Kuba chronology.

· The king’s soul or spirit counterpart would be housed in the ndop and could continue after his death, making the carving a point of contact with a former king.

VH976064_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how the possible intent, purpose, and/or function shape the creation of meaning of a work of art.
VH976064_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain how one function of the work influenced either the form or the content of this type of work.
Response does use specific contextual evidence to accurately explain how one function of the work influenced either the form or the content of this type of work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Ndop works emphasize the large head in proportion to the body, because intelligence was a valued ideal for a king.

· Because the ndop sculptures were representations of an ideal, they followed strict representational conventions.

· Ndop were considered historical markers within the culture’s orally transmitted history; chronological lineage was maintained through the visual signifiers established by each king.

· Kuba kings wore belts with two knots, conferring the wearer as the supreme legislator of the kingdom. Depicted in this work, the belt is made up of cowrie shells, which in African society have been seen as currency, jewelry, and religious accessories.

· The king in Kuba society was responsible for upholding the stability and order of the community. Part of those requirements was to observe taboos that might include things like not touching the soil. This is illustrated in the work shown, which portrays the king sitting on a raised platform, not in contact with the ground.

VH976098_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH976098_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the design of the Borobudur Temple.
Response does accurately describe the design of the Borobudur Temple.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· Borobudur rises from a hill that was artificially elevated.

· The temple is built of stone.

· Borobudur has a design suggestive of a stupa or a three-dimensional mandala.

· Borobudur resembles a stepped pyramid and has also been referred to as a shrine, a stupa, and a sacred mountain.

· It consists of five quadrilateral terraces and three circular terraces ringed by many small stupas and then is topped with a central stupa.

· Each of the squared terraces contains a wall decorated with bas-relief sculptures and Buddhist images.

Each of the many small stupas holds a seated Buddha (a garbhagriha, or sacred image, in an inner chamber); the large central stupa at the top does not contain a Buddha image and is solid.

VH976098_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH976098_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the design of the selected work.
Response does accurately describe the design of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Great Stupa at Sanchi

· The Great Stupa at Sanchi is made of earth and covered with brick.

· A stone railing was added later.

· The stupa cannot be entered and is a solid mound.

· The plan is that of a mandala, or a diagram of the cosmos as the Buddhists believe it to be.

· The four gates (toranas) are later additions that are ornately carved; the stupa itself is not carved.

Lakshmana Temple

· Lakshmana is an example of Nagara-style Hindu temple architecture. It contains a vimana, the shrine that contains the womb chamber where the image of the central deity sits; several mandapas, or flat-roofed entry porches; and a raised-base platform called a shikara (meaning “mountain peak”).

· Lakshmana Temple is decorated with images of female beauty that serve as fertility figures and promote ideas of growth and prosperity.

· Lakshmana is also decorated with mithuna, or images of couples embraced in sexual union.

· The central temple at Lakshmana contains an image of Vishnu as the three-headed Vaikuntha, recessed in a garbhagriha (an inner chamber).

· Lakshmana is surrounded by four subsidiary shrines at all four corners of the temple.

· The exterior of Lakshmana contains images of Hindu deities set into niches, especially related to Lakshmi, Vishnu, and Ganesha.

· Atop the shikara is a representation of the local amla fruit called amalaka, which symbolizes abundance and growth.

The temple of Angkor Wat

· Angkor Wat contains three concentric galleries.

· The galleries frame a stepped pyramid, which is topped with five tapered towers.

· The structure is surrounded by an enclosure wall, separating the sacred Temple Mountain from a moat that can be crossed by decorated walkways.

· Angkor Wat is ornamented with bas-relief sculptures that depict scenes from great Hindu epics, including Churning of the Ocean of Milk.

· The complex is the largest religious monument in the world.

VH976098_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VH976098_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity or difference in how the two works are intended to facilitate religious practice.
Response uses specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity or difference in how the two works are intended to facilitate religious practice.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Great Stupa at Sanchi

Similarities

· Both have railings that create a ritual path for worshippers to follow a path in their circumambulation of the structures.

· Both complexes contain relief images that narrate Buddhist stories, lessons, and religious ideas to be seen and understood by the worshipper.

· Both share the plan of the mandala, or diagram of the cosmos.

· Both structures have open-air passageways that revolve around a central cosmic axis, called the axis mundi.

Differences

· The Great Stupa at Sanchi is representative of early central Indian stupa design and is relatively simple in structure; the temple at Borobudur is representative of later temple architecture and is much more complex.

· At the Great Stupa, only the four gateways (toranas) are ornamented with sculpture, showing scenes of the Great Departure of the Buddha and the yakshas who assisted him. At the Borobudur Temple, there are continuous relief sculptures as well as many freestanding seated Buddha images.

· The Great Stupa contains two levels of pathways; Borobudur contains eight levels.

· The Great Stupa contains ornamental carvings that carry religious meaning only on the gates; at Borobudur, the entire pathway is extensively ornamented.

Lakshmana Temple

Similarities

· Both Borobudur and Lakshmana have sacred images placed in recessed inner chambers called garbhagriha.

· Both contain instructive images that worshippers view as they circumambulate the temple.

· Both are richly ornamented with relief sculptures throughout the temples.

Differences

· At Borobudur, statues of the Buddha are placed in the stupas at the top; at Lakshmana, the statue of Vishnu is in the womb chamber.

· The imagery at Lakshmana includes secular subjects, such as a sculpted frieze depicting scenes based on the history of the Chandella Dynasty.

· At Borobudur, the sacred space is outdoor; at Lakshmana, the most sacred space is indoor, dark, and windowless.

The temple of Angkor Wat

Similarities

· Both Borobudur and Angkor Wat are built on the plan of a mandala, or a diagram of the cosmos.

· Both structures utilize a central axis, or an axis mundi, placing the temple in harmony with the universe.

· Both are built using a stepped-pyramid architectural design, literally and figuratively heightening the site and the experience for the worshipper.

· Both contain bas-relief sculpture to depict stories that relate directly to their respective religions; looking at these images facilitates an understanding of the religion.

Differences

· Angkor Wat does not contain stupas because it is not a Buddhist structure.

· Borobudur contains Buddhist imagery; Angkor Wat contains Hindu imagery.

· As a Hindu temple mountain, Ankgor Wat is a home for the gods on Earth; it is not a place specifically meant for religious practices.

· Worshippers do not circumambulate Angkor Wat.

o.d: Response accomplishes both parts of this task.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Great Stupa at Sanchi

Similarities

· Both have railings that create a ritual path for worshippers to follow a path in their circumambulation of the structures.

Differences

Lakshmana Temple

Similarities

Differences

The temple of Angkor Wat

Similarities

· Both are built using a stepped-pyramid architectural design, literally and figuratively heightening the site and the experience for the worshipper.

· Both contain bas-relief sculpture to depict stories that relate directly to their respective religions; looking at these images facilitates an understanding of the religion.

Differences

· Angkor Wat does not contain stupas because it is not a Buddhist structure.

· Borobudur contains Buddhist imagery; Angkor Wat contains Hindu imagery.

· Worshippers do not circumambulate Angkor Wat.

VH976098_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VH976098_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not explain one similarity or difference in how both structures express religious meaning within their respective cultures.
Response does accurately explain one similarity or difference in how both structures express religious meaning within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Great Stupa at Sanchi

Similarities

· Both express the ideas/teachings of the Buddha.

· Both are organized according to the mandala.

· Both are constructed to accommodate circumambulation.

· Both complexes contain images that communicate religious meaning.

· Both are intended to facilitate meditation and spiritual enlightenment.

Differences

· At Borobudur, ornamentation that communicates Buddhist ideas is found throughout the temple; at Sanchi, only the toranas are ornamented with sculpture that communicates Buddhist ideas.

· Borobudur was part of a larger ritual complex that included two other temples, all positioned along a straight line. Worshippers may have made pilgrimages to the three sites.

· At Borobudur, the relief sculptures express specific Buddhist ideas as the believer circumambulates; there is no similar specificity at the Great Stupa.

Lakshmana Temple

Similarities

· Both structures are important monuments for their respective religions.

· Both structures use a wealth of carvings to express important ideas.

· Worshippers at both sites circumambulate the temple in a prescribed path.

Differences

· At Borobudur, the entire temple is sacred; at Lakshmana, the recessed womb chamber is the sacred center of the temple complex.

· At Borobudur, worshippers are guided toward relinquishing the external world for the spiritual; at Lakshmana, the two worlds are combined.

· The images at Borobudur focus on Buddhist moral lessons and teachings of the Buddha; the images at Lakshmana focus on Chandella history and the importance of fertility, abundance, growth, and prosperity.

· The imagery of the complexes reflects differences in the two religious traditions they represent.

The temple of Angkor Wat

Similarities

· Both structures are important monuments for their respective religions.

· Both structures use a wealth of carvings to express important ideas.

Differences

· Borobudur is a Buddhist temple complex meant as a place for religious worship; Angkor Wat serves both religious and secular functions.

· Angkor Wat was intended to legitimize the power of King Suryavarman II through his association with the god Vishnu; Borobudur does not legitimize a ruler.

· Angkor Wat was built possibly to serve as the king’s mausoleum (note the orientation toward the setting sun); Borobudur contains stupas, symbolic resting places for the Buddha.

VH976098_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH976098_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the Borobudur Temple in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence about the Borobudur Temple in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· At Borobudur, one must circumambulate through the terraces, moving from the darker lower sections to the higher, lighter section at the top of the structure, thereby both literally and metaphorically reaching an “enlightened” state; at Sanchi, circumambulation is shorter and simpler.

· At Borobudur, the relief sculptures begin at the bottom with moral lessons, and toward the top (as the believer moves toward enlightenment), they contain scenes related to abstract religious ideas.

· At Borobudur, ornamentation includes many statues of the Buddha; the Great Stupa gates include more abstract Buddhist images but do not depict the Buddha as a person.

· Circumambulation, part of both monuments, is intended to help believers meditate and reach a state of enlightenment.

· Statues of the Buddha at Borobudur display different mudras that correspond to their placement within the structure, adding to their meaning at the site.

· Although there are many stupas at Borobudur, at the very top of the temple there is a single stupa that represents the enlightened mind.

· The stupa at the top of Borobudur is the only one that is solid, not pierced, and that does not contain a statue of the Buddha.

· Bas-reliefs depict scenes from the life and teachings of the Buddha for worshippers to view and learn from during their worship at the religious site.

VH976098_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VH976098_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
Response does accurately use specific evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Great Stupa at Sanchi

· Stupas derive from burial mounds and contain relics beneath a dome.

· The Great Stupa was believed to hold actual relics from the Buddha, placed there by order of King Ashoka.

· Circumambulation, for which both monuments were designed, is intended to help believers meditate and, ultimately, reach a state of enlightenment.

Lakshmana Temple

· Lakshmana incorporates the idea of circumambulation but is less elevated than Borobudur.

· Lakshmana Temple was built as an attempt by the ruler to legitimize his rule and show abundance and growth under his rule.

· Mithuna imagery (imagery of couples in sexual union) symbolizes divine union, and through this divine union one can achieve release from the cycle of death and rebirth that only the enlightened can be released from.

· Lakshmi is the Hindu goddess of wealth, fortune, prosperity, and abundance and is the wife of the god Vishnu.

· Images of wealth and prosperity abound at the Lakshmana Temple.

The temple of Angkor Wat

· The temple at Angkor Wat is devoted to the god Vishnu.

· The temple at Angkor Wat is oriented west toward the setting sun, which is associated with funerary monuments.

· The central tower represents Mount Meru, the home of the gods on Earth.

· Relief sculpture subjects include both religious content and images of the king.

· Built under the rule of Suryavarman II (ruled 1113–1145/50 C.E.), the large complex at Angor Wat was an attempt by the ruler to solidify his immortality and link himself with the god Vishnu.

· The five tapered towers symbolically represent the five mountains of Mount Meru, the mythological home of the gods in both Hinduism and Buddhism. Thus, Angkor Wat is a representation of Mount Meru on Earth.

VH976937_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH976937_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the painted elk hide.
Response does accurately describe one visual characteristic of the painted elk hide.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Made using commercial paints and dyes applied to an elk hide.

· Uses stylized forms to represent animals and figures painted freehand and using stencils.

· Depicts eight dancers bent at the waist with arms akimbo moving around a Sun Dance tree with colored streamers. An eagle is represented above the poles or tree and a buffalo head is portrayed below the tree before it was raised.

· Represents some warriors (distinguished by war bonnets made of eagle feathers) and other men wearing feathered headdresses; some are between two tipis (teepees) and others are returning to the camp.

· On the sides, many men on horses hunt buffaloes using bows and arrows, while others skin and butcher the buffalo and separate the animal parts into piles.

· Women sit near a fire.

· The repetition of shapes from the stencils (for example, buffalo and horses) creates unity in the work.

· In many cases, the colors are not realistic (for example, there are pink and blue animals).

VH976937_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VH976937_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the function of the painted elk hide.
Response does accurately describe the function of the painted elk hide.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· A painting that may have been used as a wall hanging or robe

· Affirmed native identity by recording cultural traditions of the Sun Dance and buffalo hunt during a period of radical social change

· Appealed to tourists/art collectors and provided a means of livelihood for the artist.

VH976937_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH976937_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the function or cultural context of the painted elk hide is reflected in its visual characteristics.
Response uses one example of specific contextual evidence to explain how the function or cultural context of the painted elk hide is reflected in its visual characteristics.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Elk hide as well as paints and dyes became commercially available; commercial paints provided more vivid colors than the natural pigments used earlier.

· The forms used to represent animals and figures were influenced by ancient petroglyphs, pictographs, and the tradition of decorating leather goods.

· Stenciling maintained image quality and expedited the painting process for a commercial market.

· Representation of the Sun Dance and buffalo hunt preserved knowledge of traditions on the Wind River Reservation and appealed to tourists visiting the reservation.

o.d: Response accomplishes both parts of this task.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Elk hide as well as paints and dyes became commercially available; commercial paints provided more vivid colors than the natural pigments used earlier.

· The forms used to represent animals and figures were influenced by ancient petroglyphs, pictographs, and the tradition of decorating leather goods.

· Stenciling maintained image quality and expedited the painting process for a commercial market.

· Representation of the Sun Dance and buffalo hunt preserved knowledge of traditions on the Wind River Reservation and appealed to tourists visiting the reservation.

VH976937_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how an art historically valid interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning.
VH976937_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain why knowing the specific cultural context of the painted elk hide is important for understanding its meaning.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain why knowing the specific cultural context of the painted elk hide is important for understanding its meaning.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The Eastern Shoshone had been moved to the Wind River Reservation, which caused great hardship for the tribe.

· In part, the painting reflects Shoshone tradition rather than what were then contemporary conditions.

· The depiction of the buffalo hunt affirmed native identity because it was made during a period in which most buffaloes had been killed or displaced.

· It represented the hunters on horses after horses became part of Plains culture.

· It depicted hunters using bows and arrows long after rifles were used for hunting.

· The use of elk hide was necessary because most buffalos had been killed and displaced and commercially tanned elk hide replaced buffalo hides that were once tanned by hand.

· The Sun Dance was depicted with elements from the Wolf Dance during a period in which the Sun Dance, performed to honor the Creator Deity, had been outlawed while the Wolf Dance continued to be performed.

· The painting of the buffalo hunt and the Sun Dance appealed to tourists because it suggested that tradition persisted and life among the Shoshone flourished during a period of poverty and starvation on the reservation.

VH976938_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VH976938_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the city of Machu Picchu.
Response does accurately describe one visual characteristic of the city of Machu Picchu.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Machu Picchu is a completely self-contained royal estate recognizable for its agricultural terraces.

· Terracing is used on the steep slopes around the central area.

· The city accommodated large spaces for celebrations as well as private paths throughout the complex.

· The royal estate included over 150 houses and was watered by natural springs.

· Buildings and terrace walls were constructed of stone blocks sculpted and carved with precision to fit together perfectly without the use of mortar (ashlar masonry).

VH976938_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VH976938_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the physical context of the city of Machu Picchu.
Response does accurately describe the physical context of the city of Machu Picchu.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The city of Machu Picchu was built as a royal estate for the first Inka emperor and legendary warrior Pachacuti Inka Yupanqui, who was largely responsible for building the Inka Empire.

· Its climate is milder than that of the Inka capital, Cusco, which lies at a higher altitude.

· The site, which provides views of and lies among sacred peaks, may have also been chosen to be used for ceremonial purposes.

· Machu Picchu was built overlooking the Urubamba River but was completely invisible from the river valley below.

· Although smaller than neighboring cities, Machu Picchu had a population of around 1000 and was located 50 miles from the Inka capital of Cusco. The height of Inka culture coincides with the construction of this royal estate.

VH976938_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH976938_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain how the design of the city of Machu Picchu relates to its physical context.
Response does accurately explain how the design of the city of Machu Picchu relates to its physical context.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Terracing was used to create fields for crops to feed the population as well as maize needed for ceremonial purposes.

· Because Machu Picchu is located in a sub-tropical zone that gets nearly 80 inches of rain per year, water management is crucial.

· Builders created a system of stone channels to drain water from rainfall and from a spring near the site. Some of the water is channeled into stone fountains, of which there are sixteen that descend in elevation throughout the site.

· A significant part of construction time was spent underground building foundations to ensure stability in this steep and wet terrain, creating a city that would endure over time. Foundations included large cut rock topped with a sand and gravel base and layers of topsoil.

· Socketed stone wall construction (for example, a convex side of one stone fitted into the concave side of the next stone) allowed for slight movement without destruction from frequent earthquakes in this seismically active region.

VH976938_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VH976938_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain how the design of the city of Machu Picchu relates to its cultural context.
Response does accurately explain how the design of the city of Machu Picchu relates to its cultural context.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The design of Machu Picchu reflects Inka social divisions. Most of the high-status residential buildings were located to the northeast, while the emperor lived in a separate compound at the southwest, showing his exclusive status.

· Graves at Machu Picchu show many of the common people were craftspeople who came from all over the empire; they may have been ordered to move there.

· The Observatory was adjacent to the royal residence, emphasizing astronomical observation and Pachacuti’s claim to be a descendent of the sun.

· Windows in buildings were oriented so that important astronomical events could be seen and recorded.

· Machu Picchu was situated to relate to surrounding sacred peaks, which had long been considered ancestral deities throughout the region.

· Buildings were placed so windows and doors would frame views of these peaks enabling regular interactions with the divine.

· The first fountain (the cleanest, purest water) was located just outside the emperor’s quarters and made into a ritual bath, emphasizing his duties as a sacred king and the importance of his performance in religious rituals.

VH976938_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how an art historically valid interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning.
VH976938_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence to explain how the city of Machu Picchu can be interpreted as expressing central ideas of Inka culture.
Response does accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain how the city of Machu Picchu can be interpreted as expressing central ideas of Inka culture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· The creation of Machu Picchu was an expression of imperial power, with the ruler being able to command people across the empire and to oblige them to work for Inca nobility.

· The division of housing in the city reflected the Inka social hierarchy.

· The site was intended serve the Inka emperor and his family, where they could host feasts, perform religious ceremonies, and administer the affairs of empire, while also establishing a claim to land that would be owned by his lineage after his death.

· The large number of religious structures at Machu Picchu demonstrates the importance of the emperor’s involvement in religious functions of the empire.

· The Inka culture placed great importance on the sun and its ability to sustain life on earth. The Temple of the Sun (the Observatory) was designed with no obstacles to east or west of it. Facing east there are two windows through which the sun shines during sunrise on the winter solstice and facing west, windows frame the rising sun on the summer solstice.

· Machu Picchu was surrounded by the Inka holy mountain peaks of the Huayna Picchu Mountain on the north, the Machu Picchu Mountain on the south, and Mount Yanantin. Being among these peaks makes it an even better royal estate for Emperor Pachacuti.

· The Intihuatana stone, a carved boulder, was used to track the passage of the sun throughout the year, aiding the determination of when religious events would take place. Carved stones were important to the Inka relationship with the Earth. Stones such as this could be found throughout the Inka Empire, and worked as axis mundi.

VR036332_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Identify a work of art.
VR036332_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

VR036332_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe the subject matter of a work of art.
VR036332_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the iconography of the statue of Augustus of Prima Porta.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· Augustus is an idealized youthful leader standing in a contrapposto pose.

· He is dressed as a Roman army commander, raising his right hand as if addressing his troops.

· His breastplate is decorated with reliefs depicting Roman deities, a personification of dawn followed by the chariot of the sun, personifications of conquered territories, the return of the Roman standard, and a female figure with a cornucopia and two small babies.

· Next to his right foot is a figure of Cupid riding a dolphin.

· Augustus is shown barefoot, as are other classical gods and heroes

VR036332_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe the subject matter of a work of art.
VR036332_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the iconography of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· George Washington is depicted standing tall, dressed in an 18th century military uniform.

· His left‐hand rests on a bundle of 13 rods (fasces) and a sword hangs from the bundle.

· Washington wears the badge of the Order of Cincinnati.

· A plow is on the ground behind Washington.

· Washington’s right hand rests on a gentleman’s walking stick.

Jahangir Preferring a Sufi Shaikh to Kings

· Jahangir is seated on an hour‐glass shaped throne. Two cupids inscribe the base of this throne with the wish that the emperor may live a thousand years.

· Jahangir is the largest figure in the composition, situated above figures placed to the side.

· Jahangir is represented with two halos in the shapes of the sun and crescent moon, whose brilliant light two hovering putti above turn away from.

· The name of the artist appears on the stool Jahangir steps on each time he ascends his throne.

· Four people stand in hierarchical order in front of and below Jahangir. At the top is a Sufi shaykh, or holy man, to whom Jahangir is giving a book. Beneath him are an Ottoman sultan, showing a gesture of respect, an English king, and the artist, who holds a painting of himself bowing deeply toward Jahangir.

Ndop (portrait figure) of King Mishe miShyaang maMbul.

· The king is seated on a raised platform surrounded by a geometric band.

· He wears regalia, a headdress, and an armband indicating his royal status, and he holds a ceremonial knife with the handle pointing out.

· The king is an idealized young man. He has geometrically stylized features and his head is one‐third the size of his body, which is marked by rounded contours.

· His eyes are closed or almost closed and he has a calm, composed facial expression.

· He holds a drum depicting a severed hand. This personal emblem is referred to as an ibol.

· The work has a glossy surface due to being rubbed with oil.

VR036332_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VR036332_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain a similarity in how the two works communicate ideals of political power and authority.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· Both statues visually reference Augustus’s and Washington’s accomplishments as military commanders. Augustus’s military armor includes reliefs depicting personifications of conquered territories and the return of a Roman standard that had been lost during a war. Washington’s uniform, sword, and bundle of 13 rods allude to his uniting and leading the 13 colonies in their successful war for independence from Britain.

· Symbolic imagery is clearly displayed in both works to communicate power. Cupid riding a dolphin may reference Augustus’s descent from Venus and his naval victory over Antony and Cleopatra. Houdon uses the 13 rods to allude to fasces, the Roman symbol of authority, and the badge and plow refer to parallels between Washington and the Roman commander Cincinnatus, since both willingly surrendered power at war’s end to resume their lives as civilian farmers.

· Both figures stand confidently upright with calm, rational faces.

· Classical features such as the use of marble, the treatment of drapery, and the contrapposto pose lend legitimacy to each rulers’ authority.

Jahangir Preferring a Sufi Shaikh to Kings

· Both portraits combine imagery of worldly leadership and the ruler’s religious connection.

· Both feature winged cupids or cherubs to suggest divine approval.

· Both figures are linked with empire building. Augustus’ breastplate has personifications of conquered countries. In the painting, foreign leaders await an audience with Jahangir.

· Both portraits reference the sun and its light to reinforce the positive effect each ruler has upon his people. The breastplate relief’s personification of dawn suggests the dawning of a new age under Augustus, and the sun and moon encircle Jahangir’s head, referring to his title, “Light of Faith.”

· Both clothe the leader in regal adornments such as Augustus’ breastplate and Jahangir’s jewelry.

Ndop (portrait figure) of King Mishe miShyaang maMbul.

· Both portraits present an idealized version of the ruler in his prime by following certain established conventions for representing the political qualities of an ideal leader.

· Both works use symbols with kingly significance to emphasize the power of the ruler.

· Both figures convey a sense of poise and calm authority through their facial expressions.

VR036332_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR036332_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain a difference in how the two works communicate ideals of political power and authority within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· Whereas Augustus is represented as idealized and youthful, Houdon captured Washington’s actual likeness. While Augustus wished to be seen as semi‐divine, Washington wanted to appear as a common man.

· While the portrait of Washington highlights his relinquishing of power, the portrait of Augustus emphasizes his on‐going military and political power.

· The aims and messages of the works differ. The portrait of Augustus justifies his power as the first emperor of Rome. In contrast, Houdon’s portrait of Washington underscores the democratic and republican ideals of the newly formed U.S.

· Power in Augustus of Prima Porta is derived from a divine source whereas in George Washington it emanates from the subject’s character and ideals.

Jahangir Preferring a Sufi Shaikh to Kings

· While the portrait of Jahangir emphasizes his devout faith and attention to spiritual matters, the portrait of Augustus focuses more on military and political matters.

· Augustus’s youthful idealization demonstrates his power over worldly affairs, while the aging Jahangir’s authority derives from his spiritual devotion.

· Whereas Augustus claims to be semi‐divine, Jahangir gains power from his religious devotion to Allah.

· Augustus actively commands attention while Jahangir sits quietly, suggesting his spiritual focus.

Ndop (portrait figure) of King Mishe miShyaang maMbul.

· The two works reflect different notions regarding the leadership qualities of an ideal ruler.

· The two works reflect different ideals regarding physical proportions and degree of naturalism in royal portraits

· While both works function as propaganda, the ndop is also believed to embody a portion of his spirit.

VR036332_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR036332_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual OR contextual evidence about the statue of Augustus of Prima Porta in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Visual

· Augustus is idealized as youthful with a smooth face and a powerful, muscular body.

· Augustus wears armor and raises his hand as if addressing troops.

· The statue includes allegorical imagery, Roman gods, and symbols of peace and prosperity.

· The figure of Cupid, the son of Venus, reflects Augustus’s claim of divine ancestry.

Contextual

· Emperor Augustus ruled in a time of political transition as the Roman Republic was replaced by the Roman Empire, in which he held extensive powers.

· The portrait of Augustus legitimized his authority by emphasizing his contributions in expanding Roman territory and ushering in a 200‐year period of peace called the Pax Romana.

· Augustus had propagandistic portraits placed in prominent locations to shape public opinion. This work is believed to have been one of many copies circulated throughout the realm.

· The Augustus of Prima Porta emulates the ideal human form inherited from the Doryphoros.

o.d: Response does accurately use specific visual OR contextual evidence about the statue of Augustus of Prima Porta in the explanation.

Contextual
