VR036332_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR036332_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual OR contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

George Washington

Visual

· Washington is distinguished as an aging fatherly figure with facial wrinkles and a rounded belly.

· At Washington’s request, he appears in contemporary attire rather than traditional classical garb. The button missing from his vest highlights his lack of pretension.

· Represented with one hand on a walking cane, Washington has hung his sword from the bundle of rods showing that he has set his military power aside. The plow reinforces this message.

Contextual

· Washington commanded the Continental Army in the successful American Revolutionary War.

· Washington’s refusal to take on extended ruling powers after the end of the war enabled the creation of the American republic based on democratic principles.

· The Roman commander Cincinnatus served temporarily as a “dictator” during a time of war but peacefully returned this power to the republic once the war was over.

Jahangir Preferring a Sufi Shaikh to Kings

Visual

· Jahangir’s focus on the holy man rather than the worldly leaders communicates his greater concern for religious matters than worldly ones.

· Inscriptions such his title “Light of the Faith” as well as “although to all appearances kings stand before him, Jahangir looks inwardly toward the Dervishes” to reinforce his spiritual power.

Contextual

· Jahangir’s birth had been foretold by a Sufi shaykh. The presence of the Sufi shaykh in this painting refers to this story and underscores Jahangir’s spiritual devotion.

· Jahangir’s openness to other cultures resulted in a court that drew ambassadors, artists, traders, and religious figures from distant realms.

Ndop (portrait figure) of King Mishe miShyaang maMbul.

Visual

· The ndop is shown as calm, composed, and introspective emphasizing thoughtful, stable leadership.

· The idealized facial features are geometrically abstracted and stylized rather than appearing naturalistic.

Contextual

· Every Kuba king since the 18th century has commissioned a personalized ndop figure following sculptural conventions that emphasize stability. These works were regarded as an embodiment of the king’s spirit, and therefore, the king’s power.

· They were kept in the women’s quarters in the palace or a shrine and regularly rubbed with oil to honor and activate the power of the statue.

· The creation of the ndop figures assisted in maintaining oral histories, cultural memories, and songs that recounted the lives and lineage of the Kuba kings.

VR036335_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Identify a work of art.
VR036335_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not provide two accurate identifiers for the selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· Artist: Thomas Cole. Also acceptable: Cole

· Culture: United States; Romanticism; Hudson River School

· Materials: Oil (paint) on canvas. Oil is acceptable; painting is NOT acceptable.

· Date: 1836 C.E. Also acceptable: 1830s; early 19th century; first half of the 19th century; or any date within 50 years of creation. Simply writing “19th century” is NOT acceptable.

Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· Artist: Joseph Mallord William Turner. Also acceptable: Turner

· Culture: British; English; Romanticism

· Material: Oil (paint) on canvas. Oil is acceptable; painting is NOT acceptable.

· Date: 1840 C.E. Also acceptable: 1840s; first half of the 19th century; mid-19th century; OR any date within 50 years of creation. Simply writing “19th century” is NOT acceptable.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· Artist: José María Velasco. Also acceptable: Velasco

· Culture: Mexico; Romanticism

· Material: Oil (paint) on canvas. Oil is acceptable; painting is NOT acceptable.

· Date: 1882 C.E. Also acceptable: 1880s; late 19th century; OR any date within 50 years of creation. Simply writing “19th century” is NOT acceptable.

VR036335_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe form or content of a work of art.
VR036335_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe an element of form OR content of the selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· The painting itself is unusually large for a landscape painting.

· There is a high vantage point with a panoramic view of the landscape, including mountains, trees, and clouds.

· The composition is divided into two halves by a diagonal line.

· The painting is a depiction of a bend in the Connecticut River that the artist saw first-hand.

· The painting includes a small self-portrait within an expansive natural scene.

· The work includes contrasting weather conditions: dark and stormy on one side while sunny and calm on the other.

· Wild, untamed wilderness, including damaged or “blasted” trees on the left is contrasted with a flat, domesticated river valley on the right.

· Animals, crops, boats, and chimneys with smoke can be seen on the right side of the composition.
Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· The painting is comprised of intense colors (orange, red, purple, and blue), making up the sunset, the sea, and the oncoming storm.

· The painting is indistinct, with hazy or atmospheric qualities.

· A dramatic composition is created through the use of movement and strong diagonals.

· There is a strong value contrast between the darker storm and water with the brighter, setting sun.

· Wild brushstrokes and a gestural application of paint lend an expressive quality to the seascape; the ship looks as though it could capsize in the violent ocean waves.

· Carnage can be seen in the water: body parts (hands and legs), sometimes in chains and shackles, are seen in the foreground, along with what appear to be sharks or sea creatures.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· Panoramic views of the land are shown: snowcapped mountains, clouds, vegetation, and rocky outcrops, with Mexico City in the distance.

· Velasco has depicted the natural objects with scientific accuracy.

· Scale within the painting is important as nature dwarfs the humans.

· A zigzag composition leads the eye into the distance.

· A rainstorm can be seen hovering above the mountains.

· A woman and two children, dressed in indigenous clothing, along with two dogs are placed in the foreground, far removed from the city in the background.

· Specific sites of historical importance are depicted in the painting: Villa and Basilica de Guadalupe at the foot of Tepayac Hill; Santa Isabel Lake; Mexico City; and the Popocatépetl and Iztaccíhuatl volcanoes.

· Panoramic views of the land are shown: snowcapped mountains, clouds, vegetation, and rocky outcrops, with Mexico City in the distance.

· Velasco has depicted the natural objects with scientific accuracy.

· Scale within the painting is important as nature dwarfs the humans.

· A zigzag composition leads the eye into the distance.

· A rainstorm can be seen hovering above the mountains.

· A woman and two children, dressed in indigenous clothing, along with two dogs are placed in the foreground, far removed from the city in the background.

Specific sites of historical importance are depicted in the painting: Villa and Basilica de Guadalupe at the foot of Tepayac Hill; Santa Isabel Lake; Mexico City; and the Popocatépetl and Iztaccíhuatl volcanoes

o.d: Response accurately describes two elements of form OR content of the selected work of art.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· The painting itself is unusually large for a landscape painting.

· There is a high vantage point with a panoramic view of the landscape, including mountains, trees, and clouds.

· The composition is divided into two halves by a diagonal line.

· The painting is a depiction of a bend in the Connecticut River that the artist saw first-hand.

· The painting includes a small self-portrait within an expansive natural scene.

· The work includes contrasting weather conditions: dark and stormy on one side while sunny and calm on the other.

· Wild, untamed wilderness, including damaged or “blasted” trees on the left is contrasted with a flat, domesticated river valley on the right.

· Animals, crops, boats, and chimneys with smoke can be seen on the right side of the composition.

Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· The painting is comprised of intense colors (orange, red, purple, and blue), making up the sunset, the sea, and the oncoming storm.

· The painting is indistinct, with hazy or atmospheric qualities.

· A dramatic composition is created through the use of movement and strong diagonals.

· There is a strong value contrast between the darker storm and water with the brighter, setting sun.

· Wild brushstrokes and a gestural application of paint lend an expressive quality to the seascape; the ship looks as though it could capsize in the violent ocean waves.

· Carnage can be seen in the water: body parts (hands and legs), sometimes in chains and shackles, are seen in the foreground, along with what appear to be sharks or sea creatures.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· Panoramic views of the land are shown: snowcapped mountains, clouds, vegetation, and rocky outcrops, with Mexico City in the distance.

· Velasco has depicted the natural objects with scientific accuracy.

· Scale within the painting is important as nature dwarfs the humans.

· A zigzag composition leads the eye into the distance.

· A rainstorm can be seen hovering above the mountains.

· A woman and two children, dressed in indigenous clothing, along with two dogs are placed in the foreground, far removed from the city in the background.

· Specific sites of historical importance are depicted in the painting: Villa and Basilica de Guadalupe at the foot of Tepayac Hill; Santa Isabel Lake; Mexico City; and the Popocatépetl and Iztaccíhuatl volcanoes.

VR036335_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Articulate a defensible claim about the intend behind a work of art.
VR036335_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain the social or political statement that the artist was making in the work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· Cole’s work can be seen as supportive of Manifest Destiny.

· Recent scholarship has suggested that Cole was concerned that rapid development of the land would harm America’s natural resources and beauty.

· Cole promoted, through his landscapes, a sense of pride for America’s unique identity.
Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· Turner viewed slavery as a horrific and dehumanizing practice.

· Turner was against the greed of individuals and institutions directly profiting from the slave trade.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· Velasco viewed Mexican identity as unique and therefore a source of national pride.

· Velasco desired to elevate Mexican painting on the international stage and demonstrate its equal merit with European art.

VR036335_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how the possible intend shapes the creation of a work of art.
VR036335_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use visual evidence to explain how the artist used form or content to reinforce the social or political statement.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· Self-portrait: the artist as a witness to nature connects the viewer to the scene, where Cole seems to be asking for the viewer’s participation in the future of America.

· The larger sized canvas reminds viewers of history painting, spurring moral interpretations of the scene.

· Cole chose a specific, well-known location and depicted it as desirable with verdant forest and peacefully domesticated land. This could be seen as a positive endorsement to promote the ideas of westward expansion or the fulfillment of Manifest Destiny.

· The wild, untamed wilderness and storm on the left could also be seen as a warning against the destructive forces of encroaching civilization.
Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· Body parts and chains in the water reinforce Turner’s views on the cruel and inhumane practice of throwing the dying slaves overboard to collect insurance monies.

· The oncoming storm, gestural brushstrokes and vibrant colors evoke the frenzied, evil intentions of the captain and reinforce Turner’s belief that the slavers should be punished.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· Velasco depicted figures in the landscape wearing uniquely Mexican dress, influenced by its indigenous and folkloric heritage; specific Mexican sites related directly to important events in Mexican history (i.e., the Basilica of Guadalupe); and native flora and fauna in order to highlight Mexican national identity.

· Panoramic views and artistic license taken by the artist allow for several important sites to be included, thus creating an idealized portrayal of the Mexican landscape.

· The rainstorm in the background recedes farther away from Mexico City; Mexico’s dark days are over and Mexico is currently experiencing a period of modern peace and prosperity, according the ruling president.

VR036335_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain why context influences artistic decisions about form or content.
VR036335_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain why the artist depicted the natural world in this way to persuade the viewer of the social or political statement.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Oxbow (View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm)

· The painting provides visual support for the concept of “God-given rights” as a philosophical justification for Manifest Destiny, a belief in divine approval/obligation/justification for “settling” the American west; a concept that had grown since the acquisition of western lands through the Louisiana Purchase of 1804.

· Cole was particularly sensitive to the unique beauty in America and knew that by heightening the aesthetic qualities of the American landscape he would be able to create pride and build a national identity around its natural beauty.

· As a British immigrant, he also understood the destructive potential of industrialization and wanted to caution audiences about rapid expansion or misuse of the land.

· This painting is an example of Romanticism. Romantic landscape painters often glorify nature in order to convey the historical, political or religious values of a place or time. Typically this is done through images of landscapes, seascapes, and other visions of traditional beauty.
Slave Ship (Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, Typhoon Coming On)

· Turner seeks to shed a light on the inhumane practices of slavery and was influenced by an horrific event that had happened in the early 1780s, when a captain sought to collect insurance money by throwing the ill/dying slaves overboard during a storm; insurance companies would compensate for slaves lost at sea but not for those who died on board.

· Turner intended to use this painting to support the British Anti-Slavery Conference to be held in 1840. Slavery had been abolished in 1833 in Britain and 1848 in France, but had not yet been abolished in America. This conference met at the same time as the Royal Academy show where Turner displayed this work. Turner hoped to affect the attendees of the conference, especially Prince Albert.

· This painting is an example of Romanticism. Romantic landscape painters often glorify nature in order to convey the historical, political, or religious values of a place or time. Typically this is done through images of landscapes, seascapes, and other visions of traditional beauty.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel (El Valle de México desde el Cerro de Santa Isabel)

· A message of patriotism, associated with recent history in Mexico; its 19th century independence from Spain, the Mexican–American War (1848–1849), and the nationalist rhetoric of President Porfirio Diaz is suggested by imagery and sites that connect with regional history and culture. The Basilica of Guadalupe and the site of the miracle associated with the Virgin recall Mexico’s Christian tradition while the Popocatépetl and Iztaccíhuatl volcanoes in the background are associated with Mexico’s Aztec roots.

· Velasco is a proponent of the academy in Mexico City, having been trained at the Real Academia de San Carlos in Madrid, which fostered the development of a national school of landscape painting.

· Velasco’s paintings such as this one gained recognition at several World Fairs, appealing to aesthetic tastes of other European countries and the U.S. In this way Velasco achieved a goal of portraying a positive connection between the present and the past for Mexico as it built its identity and reputation.

· This painting is an example of Romanticism. Romantic landscape painters often glorify nature in order to convey the historical, political, or religious values of a place or time. Typically this is done through images of landscapes, seascapes, and other visions of traditional beauty.

VR036336_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe form, style, materials, technique, or content.
VR036336_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe how Leonardo created a sense of depth.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Linear one-point perspective with orthogonal lines visible on the ceiling, on the line of wall hangings, and on the floor.

· Modeling/chiaroscuro used to create a sense of three-dimensionality in the forms.

· Use of foreshortening to make the figures appear to be three-dimensional.

· Windows in the background that allow a view into the landscape beyond depicted using atmospheric perspective.

· Natural light on the figures corresponds to the actual windows in the refectory.

o.d: Response accurately describe how Leonardo created a sense of depth.

VR036336_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe form, style, materials, technique, or content.
VR036336_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe how Leonardo represented the figures.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The disciples each show a distinct emotion that is conveyed through facial expressions and gestures.

· The setting is simple, which focuses attention on the emotional intensity of the group.

· Through the use of foreshortening and modeling, figures appear to exist realistically in space.

· Apostles have differentiated poses, especially in regard to facial expressions and individualized, dramatic hand gestures.

· Apostles, arranged in four groups of three, are interacting with each other and register different emotional responses to the announcement that one of the apostles will betray Christ.

· Judas is differentiated from other apostles by his intense and shadowed facial expression.

· All of the apostles sit on one side of the table facing the viewer.

VR036336_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how artistic decisions about form, style, materials, technique, or content shape the work.
VR036336_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: The response does not accurately use specific visual evidence to explain a way in which Leonardo has created an emphasis on Christ.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The composition positions Christ in the center surrounded by specific groupings of apostles.

· Christ is the focal point of the one-point perspective system with all of the orthogonal lines in the composition meeting at a vanishing point near Christ’s head.

· The light from the window directly behind Christ creates a halo effect.

· The circular pediment above the window (the only curved element in the architecture) also contributes to the effect of a halo.

· Christ, unlike the apostles, has a tranquil and serious expression that reinforces the contrast between the divinity of Christ and the humanity of the apostles.

· Christ appears isolated, in contrast to the apostles being clustered in groups.

· Christ fits within an equilateral triangle, creating a stable center.

· Christ stretches his hands toward the bread and wine on the table.

VR036336_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR036336_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately explain how this work departs from earlier Western traditions of landscape painting.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Leonardo was working from direct observation of the natural world and the human body, which led to heightened realism and naturalism. Leonardo used live models in doing preparatory sketches of these figures.

· Ground-breaking artistic studies in anatomy, including Leonardo’s participation in dissections, enhanced the depiction of figures.

· Leonardo used a one-point perspective system, which was first developed in Florence in the early 15th century and became a standard technique that Renaissance artists used to depict spatial depth.

· Humanism fueled the artistic depiction of individual characteristics and emotions.

· Leonardo embraced classical idealism expressed through mathematics (geometry) of the space, figures, and architecture.

· New iconography developed, such as dispensing with gold haloes in favor of natural light and placing Judas amongst the other apostles rather than being isolated.

· The Christian subject matter reflects the importance of patronage by the Catholic Church and wealthy patrons. Last Supper images were commonly found in monastic refectories in this period.

· Leonardo used the new medium of oil paint and/or the revival of fresco painting to represent Renaissance interests in experimentation and the classical past.

o.d: The response accurately explains how one visual characteristic of Last Supper is typical of the Renaissance, the era in which Leonardo worked.
o.af:

· Leonardo embraced classical idealism expressed through mathematics (geometry) of the space, figures, and architecture.

· New iconography developed, such as dispensing with gold haloes in favor of natural light and placing Judas amongst the other apostles rather than being isolated.

· The Christian subject matter reflects the importance of patronage by the Catholic Church and wealthy patrons. Last Supper images were commonly found in monastic refectories in this period.

· Leonardo used the new medium of oil paint and/or the revival of fresco painting to represent Renaissance interests in experimentation and the classical past.

VR036337_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe contextual elements of a work of art.
VR036337_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe an aspect of the historical OR religious context of the David Vases.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The works were created during a time of stability under the Mongol Empire, which promoted trade along the Silk Road.

· The works were made when China was under the rule of the Mongols, during the Yuan dynasty.

· The works were conceived as an offering/dedication to be placed in a Chinese Daoist temple (in Xingyuan) Note: Buddhist temple according to Gardner’s 15th edition.

· In China at the time, there was an intermixing of religious practices including Daoism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

· The works were commissioned by a wealthy Chinese patron, Zhang Wenjin. An inscription around the necks of the vases includes information about the patron and a dedication of the vases (together with a now missing incense burner) to the temple in the hope to receive protection and blessing of the patron’s family.

· Also among the inscriptions are references to a general recently deified as a god to whom the altar set is offered in exchange for this new god’s protection.

· The works were made in southern China (Jingdezhen/Jiangxi), the center of Chinese porcelain production.

· Vases like these were created to appeal to a variety of consumers in different markets; many were exported.

· The shapes of the vases were modeled after ritual bronzes that could also be used as temple offerings.

VR036337_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about materials.
VR036337_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how the original context influenced the choice of the materials of the David Vases.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The works are made of porcelain, a type of high-fired ceramic with special properties (being hard, white, with a translucent appearance) developed in China.

· Porcelain production was an established artistic tradition within China and Chinese porcelain a popular export good by the time the David Vases were created.

· Cobalt, the mineral used to create the blue pigment in blue-and-white porcelain like the David Vases, was imported to China from present-day Iran.

· Chinese blue-and-white porcelain was developed during the Yuan dynasty as a result of the connection of China with markets in the Middle East.

· Precious materials, such as the porcelain and the cobalt blue underglaze make this a status object that represented the wealth of the patron.

· The use of cobalt to create the coloring was also found in Middle Eastern ceramic traditions; Chinese blue-and-white porcelain appealed to the demands created by Middle Eastern markets.

· Cobalt, the mineral used to create the blue pigment in blue-and-white porcelain like the David Vases, was imported to China from present-day Iran.

· Chinese blue-and-white porcelain was developed during the Yuan dynasty as a result of the connection of China with markets in the Middle East.

· Precious materials, such as the porcelain and the cobalt blue underglaze make this a status object that represented the wealth of the patron.

· The use of cobalt to create the coloring was also found in Middle Eastern ceramic traditions; Chinese blue-and-white porcelain appealed to the demands created by Middle Eastern markets.

VR036337_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, or content.
VR036337_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how the original context influenced the choice of imagery of the David Vases.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The vases are decorated with animals including dragons and phoenixes, which are auspicious and complementary symbols (the yin and the yang), commonly found on Chinese ceremonial and imperial objects.

· Trade with India influenced the elephant head handles.

· Religious contextual imagery correlates elephants in Buddhist art to a symbol of strength.

· Dragon and phoenix communicate power in Chinese culture, and would have reinforced the patron's status, as well as invoked prosperity.

· Vine and floral motifs were inspired by Islamic or Iznik ceramics, here depicted in new forms such as plantain leaves and traditional Chinese flowers such as peonies.

VR036337_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how one art historically valid interpretation of a work is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning.
VR036337_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain how the David Vases exemplify cross-cultural interaction.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Combined elements of cobalt blue from the Middle East with porcelain found in China create the distinctive blue-and-white wares that are only possible with trade along the Silk Road.

· With expansion of the Mongol empire, artists in China added exotic animals including the elephant into their design choices along with traditional Chinese creatures.

· Blending of Middle Eastern cobalt blue pigments and motifs with Chinese sacred symbols demonstrate the influence of secular trade on religious objects through the Silk Road and Mongol Empire.

· The connections of the Chinese blue-and-white porcelain in Middle Eastern markets and its later global appeal (such as the stylistic and technical influence in 17th century delftware) shows the cross-cultural connections of Chinese porcelain production.

· The purchase of the vases as part of an extensive collection of Chinese ceramics in the 20th century by European collector Sir Percival David exhibits the continued global appeal of Chinese blue-and-white porcelain from this time.

VR036338_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how the possible intent, purpose, and/or function shape the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VR036338_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use an example of specific evidence to explain the commentary that the artist was making on the cultural context in which the artist was working.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Basquiat included terms alluding to American pop culture, African American history, African American culture in the 1970s–1980s, and portrayals of African Americans without romance, stereotype, or irony in order to celebrate African American history and culture and to challenge pervasive discrimination and stereotypes of African-Americans, especially in arts and entertainment.

· Basquiat used elements of his autobiography—places, dates, names, etc.—in order to create work based directly on his personal background, racial identity, and life experience, especially as a minority artist working inside and outside of the elite art scene.

· Basquiat used techniques, materials, and visual elements drawn from or perceived in the art world as “low” or “outsider” (such as graffiti) in order to push boundaries, challenge what was considered art, and to question the distinction between “high” and “low” art.

· Basquiat included recognizable figures, often portraits of popular artists, musicians, friends, etc., in order to confront changes in the art scene of the 1980s, which valued celebrity and commercialism.

· Basquiat also used text in unconventional ways—using visual elements that call attention to specific words by eliminating, hiding, or obscuring them or employing verbal puns, jokes, or word play that challenge the meaning or use of specific words or images.

VR036340_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Describe visual elements of a work of art.
VR036340_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe a material OR technique used in the construction of the Great Mosque of Djenné.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

Materials:

· The mosque is made from adobe (the Spanish term for mud brick), which is made from earth and other available organic matter such as mud, sand, straw, dung and/or rice husks, based on what is available, and water to form the mud bricks. Note: the use of “brick” alone is not sufficient to earn the task point.

· Additional media: terracotta tiles/ceramic vessels/tubes and lids that cap openings in the roof, timber (palm) in the form of the projecting torons and the roof beams, and mud plaster coating the bricks.

· Ostrich eggs are placed at the tops of mud-brick pillars on the exterior.

Techniques:

· The building is a post-and-lintel construction made of stacked mud bricks with projecting pilasters/buttresses on the exterior and 90 mud-brick pillars connected by arches on the interior that support a roof of mud and palm wood.

· The exterior of the building is coated in plaster to protect the mud bricks from the effects of weather and must be periodically recoated (the specific name of the annual ceremony where this occurs is Crepissage or Crepissage de la Grande Mosquée).

· The torons/timbers projecting from the exterior both reinforce the mud-brick walls and serve as scaffolding for the periodic replastering.

VR036340_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR036340_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how an architectural feature of the Great Mosque of Djenné demonstrates continuity with global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The Djenné mosque contains the typical functional and symbolic mosque components of a qibla wall oriented in the direction of Mecca, mihrab, a minbar, and minarets.

· It also has the characteristic mosque spaces of a prayer hall and a courtyard.

· Its soaring height in comparison to the surrounding buildings makes it the visual center of the community, a typical characteristic for a primary congregational mosque or Friday mosque.

· Its monumental size is the norm for Friday mosques, which are supposed to be able to hold all Muslim males in the community.

· It has spaces reserved for women (in this case its galleries) as is typical of mosques.

VR036340_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR036340_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how an architectural feature of the Great Mosque of Djenné demonstrates change from global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The Djenné mosque uses the materials and techniques characteristic of the region, in this case adobe/earthen construction, and thus it differs from mosques built in other regions of the world.

· The interior and exterior are largely simple mud brick and mud plaster, rather than the colorful two- or three-dimensional decoration seen in other traditions, such as tile, mosaic, stone, or colored and decorated plaster.

· The building's exterior projecting pilasters/buttresses and pointed crenellations mimic the town's domestic architecture and thus are local in derivation.

· Ventilation is provided by openings in the roof capped with terracotta, and small niches in roof/towers.

· The wood beams (torons) projecting from the exterior are a regionally specific architectural variation.

· The pillars topped with ostrich eggs are also a regionally specific trait.

· The Djenné mosque's flat roof differs from other traditions of mosque building (which can include a central dome flanked by squinches/semidomes; soaring iwans and rows of small domes; or rows of trussed timber roofs).

· The Djenné is also constructed on a raised platform that elevates it 3 meters above its surroundings.

VR036340_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain why a specific work of art demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR036340_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain why an architectural feature of the Great Mosque of Djenné demonstrates change from global conventions of mosque architecture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The use of thick adobe/mud brick walls is a response to local environmental conditions, insulating the interior from heat and maintaining a more constant temperature.

· Ventilation systems are also a response to heat and a local architectural solution to this environment.

· Replastering is an adaptation to the local rainy seasons and tied to local pre-Islamic beliefs that emphasize cyclical renewal.

· Wooden beams (torons) reinforce the structure and are used for scaffolding in during periodic re-plastering.

· Ostrich eggs incorporate references to local, pre-Islamic cultural concepts related to purity and fertility.

· The monumental exterior, with its projecting elements (buttresses, crenellations, and towers), was likely inspired by surrounding buildings and the knowledge of trained masons who participated in building the mosque.

· The appearance and construction continue the long tradition of mud masonry in Djenné while also visually and architecturally connecting the mosque to its community surroundings.

· The elevated platform helps to protect the mosque from the annual flooding of the nearby Bani River.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe one visual characteristic of the Mesa Verde cliff dwellings.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Settlement built in an elevated position above the floor of a canyon in direct contact to cliff below a natural overhang/ledge

· Site plan consists of a cluster of rectangular rooms as well as well as numerous round structures (kivas).

· Clusters of architectural units that were sometimes several stories high, containing groups of rooms that were connected to each other

· Interior of round structures (kivas) situated mostly below ground were originally entered through an entrance in the roof using a ladder.

· The tops of some of the higher buildings touch the natural ceiling of the rock ledge below which the settlement is situated.

· Towers are also part of the site.

· Structures are built of stone and timber

· Walls plastered with adobe

· Some of the walls were painted with murals

VR041916_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art
VR041916_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain how the design of the Mesa Verde cliff dwellings was influenced by an aspect of Ancestral Puebloan culture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Ancestral Puebloans were farmers who lived in settlements (pueblos) that often contained sizable building complexes composed of clusters of connected rooms, such as a cliff palace.

· The cliff palace reflects common features of the communal living structure of Ancestral Puebloan settlements in that it comprises clusters of multistoried architectural units containing groups of rooms that were connected to each other.

· Connected rooms are thought to have been used by a family unit, with individual rooms in each unit serving different functions as living quarters or store rooms.

· The cliff palace reflects a later trend of Ancestral Puebloan culture of building settlements in canyons, with some settlements built in direct contact with cliffs.

· Clusters of residential buildings at the cliff palace were organized around circular, subterranean structures, called kivas (in Ancestral Puebloan culture, kivas were places of ritual and communal purposes).

· The design of kivas reflects their likely ritual or communal purpose; this is also suggested by the way that residential clusters were organized around these circular structures.

· Some rooms contain wall paintings depicting geometric designs or natural imagery, such as animals, plants, stylized landscape features (such as mountains or streams), and imagery suggesting clouds or rain, which suggests close connection of Ancestral Puebloan culture with the natural environment.

VR041916_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art
VR041916_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain how the design of the Mesa Verde cliff dwellings was influenced by the site’s natural environment.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· Location nestled directly into the side of a cliff might have been chosen because of the protection it offered from the elements; in the winter the sun would heat the cliff face and provide warmth, while in the summer the cliff would provide shade and protection from the heat.

· Dwellings located against cliffs and elevated from the ground provide protection and safety.

VR041916_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how an art historically valid interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning
VR041916_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain why scholars have interpreted the abandonment of the cliff dwellings of Mesa Verde around 1300 C.E. as a reflection of changes that affected Ancestral Puebloan culture in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries C.E.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following.

· The abandonment of cliff dwellings such as the ones at Mesa Verde seems to be part of a shift in habitation patterns that seemed to have coincided with increasing occurrence of droughts, and might have been a reaction to gradual changes in climate.

· A bad drought in the late thirteenth century might have led to a shortage of resources (such as food and water), and might have made it impractical to maintain settlements like the cliff dwellings at Mesa Verde.

· Environmental changes might have led to violent conflicts over access to diminished resources, which may have been the cause for the abandonment of the cliff dwellings.

VR041922_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice
VR041922_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use an example of specific visual OR contextual evidence to explain how the work departs from traditional Chinese painting through the use of Western painting conventions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

Visual Evidence

· The work adopts Western painting conventions—appears similar to nineteenth-century European academic painting:

· Uses Western materials—oil on canvas rather than ink

· Contains foreground and background

· Layers of fine brushstrokes construct a flat painted surface on the canvas, unlike the more expressive/calligraphic brushwork used in traditional Chinese landscape paintings.

· Naturalistic colors

· Modeling—uses tonal variations to create volume and form

· Clear light source

· Idealized bodily proportion—similar to Classical or Renaissance figures

· Balanced classical pose—one leg stepping forward

· Drapery from robe outlines the figure’s body.

· Composition is highly organized—the figure is in the center, dividing the composition in two. Horizon line cuts through the figure’s midsection.

· Depicts figure dominating the landscape—significant departure from traditional Chinese landscapes, such as Fan Kuan’s Travelers Among Mountains and Streams from the image set.

· Uses a wide array of rich colors—unlike other Chinese landscapes, which were traditionally ink on paper, resulting in a limited range of colors.

· Whole composition is painted—traditional Chinese landscapes often had substantial areas of unpainted negative space.

Contextual Evidence

· The work departs from the traditional formats for Chinese landscape paintings, such as hanging scroll, fan, hand scroll, painting on silk, screen or room divider, album leaf.

· Lithographic copies were created of the original painting and distributed across China—unlike older Chinese painted works, which were not mass reproduced and were owned by wealthy individuals.

· Does not contain a directional narrative like a hand scroll, which is intended to be read from right to left.

· Lacks extensive text or poetry, which is a common feature of Chinese landscape paintings.

VR041922_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain the meaning or significance of continuity and/or change between works of art (or a group of related works of art) within a related artistic tradition, style, or practice
VR041922_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence to explain how the work was influenced by the political or cultural context of China in the second half of the twentieth century.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include the following:

· Created as a work of propaganda during the Cultural Revolution (1966–1976) according to the official guidelines prescribed by the Communist Party of China:

· Work lacks abstraction or formalism, which were favored by Western modernist artists of the same time.

· Drew inspiration from Soviet Socialist realist painting, which itself was influenced by nineteenth-century Western academic painting

· Chinese themes, techniques, and painting conventions were purged from the arts during the Cultural Revolution.

· Works should contain a didactic component—teaching about socialism, the Communist Party of China, depicting an important moment in Chinese revolutionary history.

· Heroic/politicized depiction of Mao Zedong (dominates the landscape, strong stance, clenched fist)

· Work contributed to Mao’s cult of personality, which reached its height during the Cultural Revolution (1966–1976).

· Work was widely distributed across the China, displayed in people’s homes, and used during marches and rallies.

VR041928_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe the iconography of a work of art
VR041928_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the iconography of the Last Judgment tympanum of the church of Sainte-Foy in Conques.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

· The blessed are shown to the right of Christ, the damned to the left.

· Christ is enthroned at the center, and shown as judge over the souls of the dead.

· Christ’s hand gestures signal the act of judgment or the sorting of the souls by gesturing downward toward hell on the right (where the damned are) and upward toward heaven on the left (where the blessed are).

· Below Christ’s feet, Saint Michael and the Devil weigh newly risen souls and lead them into either heaven or hell, depending on the verdict.

· The lower part of the tympanum is divided into two halves: the left side shows figures of the blessed contained under arches representing paradise, whereas the right side shows the damned being tortured in hell for their various sins.

· The tympanum depicts saints, including Sainte Foy, whose relic the pilgrims came to visit.

VR041928_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe the iconography of a work of art
VR041928_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately describe the iconography of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Funerary banner of Lady Dai

· The banner contains the first known portrait in Chinese art of Lady Dai.

· The upper part of the banner shows the celestial realm, including the Sun with a three-legged crow, a toad on a crescent moon, dragons, and a deity whose body is composed of human and dragon features.

· Roughly in the center of the panel is a portrait of Lady Dai standing on a platform accompanied by her attendants, representing her ascent to the celestial realm in the afterlife.

· The lower part of the banner shows mourners with Lady Dai’s coffin.

· The bottom of the panel shows the underworld, including fish, other animals, and a deity.


Last Judgment of Hu-Nefer

· Hu Nefer is led by the jackal-headed god Anubis to a scale on which his heart will be weighed to determine whether he is worthy to enter the afterlife.

· Several gods or mythical creatures are shown observing the weighing of Hu Nefer’s heart while the results are being recorded by the ibis-headed god Thoth.

· After Hu-Nefer has successfully passed the test, he is brought before Osiris, the god of the underworld.

· In the top register, Hu-Nefer is shown in front of several gods.

VR041928_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning
VR041928_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one similarity in how the two works depict death and the afterlife.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Funerary banner of Lady Dai

· Generally symmetrical composition

· Presence of a clear vertical axis

· Division of scenes into horizontal registers

· Both show deceased in the afterlife.

· Both include images of divine beings.

· Both include images of specific individuals.

Last Judgment of Hu-Nefer

· Both works show a judgment of the dead, depicting what will happen after death.

· Both works use horizontal registers to organize the imagery.

· Both works include text.

· Both works include a figure who is seated on a throne and presides over the judgment of the dead.

· Both images use either a depiction of (Hu-Nefer) or visual reference to (through the position of Christ’s arms in the tympanum) a scale to represent the idea of a person’s judgment according to his or her deeds during his or her lifetime.

· Both works include images of specific individuals.

VR041928_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning
VR041928_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific visual evidence from both works to explain one difference the two works depict death and the afterlife.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Funerary banner of Lady Dai

· The tympanum is an architectural relief sculpture, while the funeral banner is painted on a two-dimensional surface.

· Several representations of deities are depicted on the banner, but only one God is shown in the tympanum.

· The funeral banner is intended to be read vertically as Lady Dai moves up into the celestial realm, with the underworld being on the bottom and the heavenly realm on top, while the tympanum is divided into different scenes that are grouped around a central figure, with the scenes on the left relating to the fate of the blessed while the scenes on the right relate to the fate of the damned.

· The figures in each of the two works are stylized in different ways according to the visual traditions of their respective cultures.

Last Judgment of Hu-Nefer

· The tympanum is an architectural relief sculpture, while the Last Judgment of Hu Nefer was painted on a two-dimensional surface.

· The scenes in the tympanum are arranged around a vertical axis with Christ in the center, while the last Judgment of Hu-Nefer is to be read from left to right.

· In contrast to the Last Judgment tympanum, the Judgment of Hu-Nefer uses continuous narration by repeating the figure of Hu-Nefer several times as he progresses through several stages of his journey into the afterlife.

· The Judgment of Hu-Nefer depicts the fate of one person who is being judged according to his earthly deeds, while the tympanum depicts the fate of multiple people being judged.

· The Judgment of Hu-Nefer does not directly depict the fate of those who fail to pass divine judgment, while the Last Judgment tympanum places equal emphasis on depicting the fate of the blessed and the fate of the damned.

· The figures in each of the two works are stylized in different ways according to the visual traditions of their respective cultures.

VR041928_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art
VR041928_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain one difference in how both works convey ideas related to death and the afterlife within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Funerary banner of Lady Dai

· The iconography of the tympanum is informed by Christian theology; the banner reflects Han era beliefs about the structure of the cosmos.

· The tympanum depicts collective divine judgment at the end of times, whereas the funeral banner depicts the funeral and journey of an individual noble woman into the afterlife.

· The composition of the tympanum reflects the monotheistic nature of Christianity by focusing on the central depiction of Christ; the funeral banner includes depictions of multiple deities and mythological figures.

· The funeral banner is a status object intended to show the wealth of the individual who died, while the tympanum serves a pedagogical purpose in teaching or reminding visitors of the church about central Christian beliefs.

· The tympanum conveys the belief that humans will be judged after death according to their worldly deeds, while the funeral banner does not depict judgment of the deceased but rather focusses on the funerary rites surrounding her death and her continued existence in the afterlife.


Last Judgment of Hu-Nefer

· The tympanum reflects the monotheistic nature of Christianity, while the Judgment of Hu-Nefer reflects the polytheistic nature of ancient Egyptian religion.

· The theological tradition underlying the iconography of the tympanum assumes that all people will rise from the dead and be judged at the same time, while the Judgment of Hu-Nefer shows the induction into the afterlife is an individual process and occurs after death.

· The Judgment of Hu Nefer was intended to provide guidance to the recently deceased in their journey to the afterlife, while the tympanum serves a pedagogical purpose in teaching or reminding visitors of the church about central Christian beliefs and the importance of leading a pious live.

VR041928_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim
VR041928_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the Last Judgment tympanum of the church of Sainte-Foy in Conques in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The tympanum is a stone relief placed above the main entrance to a church, where it would be seen by all those who entered.

· The tympanum depicts the Second Coming of Christ, based on the Book of Revelation, during which the souls of the deceased and the living are being judged according to their sins and punished or rewarded accordingly.

· The imagery of the tympanum would have been chosen to remind pilgrims, monks, and clergymen of the dangers of sin, including specific examples of what hell might look like.

· The church of Sainte-Foy was an important pilgrimage site during the Middle Ages and therefore received many visitors who were hoping to improve their chances of achieving salvation after death by performing pious deeds such as visiting the holy relics of Sainte Foy, which were kept in the church.

· The imagery of the tympanum would have been chosen to remind pilgrims, monks, and clergymen of the dangers of sin, including specific examples of what hell might look like.

· The church of Sainte-Foy was an important pilgrimage site during the Middle Ages and therefore received many visitors who were hoping to improve their chances of achieving salvation after death by performing pious deeds such as visiting the holy relics of Sainte Foy, which were kept in the church.

VR041928_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim
VR041928_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific contextual evidence about the selected work in the explanation.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Funerary banner of Lady Dai

· The funeral banner was buried with other grave goods placed on a coffin that contained the body of the deceased.

· The funeral banner was displayed in a funeral procession prior to the burial of Lady Dai.

· Han period burials often included expensive objects, which were buried with the dead and which were intended to emphasize the status of the deceased.

· The funeral banner represents Han era cosmology, which included Earth, heaven, and the underworld.

· Religious beliefs of the Han era include a pantheon of deities and immortal beings.

Last Judgment of Hu-Nefer

· The Judgment of Hu-Nefer was part of a Book of the Dead, a series of texts intended to help a deceased person successfully complete the journey after death into the afterlife.

· Like other examples of the Book of the Dead from New Kingdom Egypt, the scroll that contained the Judgment of Hu-Nefer was buried with the deceased (in this case, Hu-Nefer).

· According to ancient Egyptian religious believes, a person had to pass a judgment by the gods to determine whether he or she had led a good or pious life in order to be permitted to enter the afterlife; those who failed the test were destroyed and thereby prevented from entering the afterlife.

VR043197_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. To earn this point, the thesis must make an art historically defensible claim that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

o.d: Does not respond to the prompt with an art historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning
o.af:
Examples of possible claims might include the following:

Untitled (#228), from the History Series

· Sherman’s work recreates works from older European works art that depict women in order to examine the construction of female identity.

· In her work Untitled (#228), Cindy Sherman references a common theme/certain types of imagery from older European painting traditions to comment on the traditional representation of women in European culture/art.

· Cindy Sherman critiques the history of European art by placing herself in photographs that are intended to resemble “old master paintings.”

Dancing at the Louvre, from the series The French Collection, Part I; #1

· Faith Ringgold uses the Louvre and represents paintings there to comment on how racism limits opportunities for Black Americans.

· Faith Ringgold combines images of older works of European masters and folk art traditions as well as narrative text to challenge traditional artistic conventions.

· Faith Ringgold creates a visual and written narrative that places African American women and girls dancing in front of the Mona Lisa to defy and raise questions about traditional museum conventions.

· Faith Ringgold is using her work to comment on the limitations that have historically been placed on female artists.

The Swing (after Fragonard)

· Yinka Shonibare appropriates elements of Fragonard’s Rococo painting in order to comment on the history of colonialism in Africa.

· Yinka Shonibare created this work as a parody of Fragonard’s work in order to present a different interpretation of Fragonard’s subject.

· Yinka Shonibare appropriates elements of Fragonard's painting and combines them with different cultural references to challenge the viewer to question how societal identities are constructed globally.

VR043197_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C: EVIDENCE: VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VR043197_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible..

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Untitled (#228), from the History Series

Visual Evidence:

· The work is about 7 feet high, a monumental scale that is more likely for a master painting than a photograph.

· The work is a photograph made to resemble an old master oil painting.

· The pose, costume, and composition are linked to European works of the Renaissance and Baroque that depict Judith and Holofernes.

· Sherman places herself into the image in the role of Judith.

· Sherman looks directly at the viewer, emphasizing her dominance.

· Sherman’s use of cheap props (such as a Halloween mask), fake blood, and theatrical makeup and outfits makes the work recognizable as a contemporary work.

Contextual Evidence:

· Sherman’s earlier work often dealt with the way men choose to view women; in this work, she continues that theme within the context of European art history.

· Sherman chose one of the few traditional stories depicted in European art in which a woman acts aggressively.

Dancing at the Louvre, from the series The French Collection, Part I; #1

Visual Evidence

· The work depicts two African American women and three girls.

· The figures are depicted in the Louvre in front of the painting of the Mona Lisa, which is flanked by images of two other old master paintings.

· The three girls and one of the women and are dancing.

· The figures all appear to be dressed for a special occasion.

· The work is quilted, with the exception of the outer border.

· Around the edges of the painted image is a pieced border.

· The text (story) is written on strips of fabric at the top and bottom of the central image.

Contextual Evidence

· Quilting is considered a traditional craft of women.

· Ringgold often combines cultural references taken from a variety of different sources in her works to create a cultural commentary.

The Swing (after Fragonard)

Visual Evidence

· The pose of the figure in the installation mimics the pose of the woman in the Fragonard painting with the same name, the sculpted greenery closely reflects the greenery above and below the figure in the painting, the shoe that flies off the figure’s foot in the painting is included in the installation, and the billows of the installation figure’s dress reflect the billowing fabric in the painting.

· By omitting the male figures that are depicted in Fragonard’s painting from the installation, the artist invites the viewer to take their place as the voyeur looking at the female figure.

· The installation uses Dutch wax fabric for the dress of the figure, which differs from the way the dress is depicted in Fragonard’s painting.

· Shonibare’s figure does not have a head, in contrast to the woman in Fragonard’s painting.

Contextual Evidence

· Shonibare’s figure is dressed in clothing made of Dutch wax cloth, historically Dutch fabric originally based on Indonesian designs, which became very popular in Africa.

· France had multiple colonies in Africa, which stimulated the French economy and contributed to the wealth of the French upper class.

· Fragonard’s painting is generally accepted as a depiction of the somewhat frivolous wealthy or aristocratic class in eighteenth-century England.

VR043197_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Untitled (#228), from the History Series

· The monumental scale of the work references the size of Renaissance or Baroque oil painting with biblical subject matter.

· In her work, Sherman does not present herself seductively, as most women in European paintings of the relevant times are presented, in order to challenge the sexualization of women in Western paintings.

· By referencing one of the few traditional stories in the Western canon that represents a woman in a position of power, Sherman is examining the role of women in traditional Western painting.

· By meeting the viewer’s gaze, Sherman comments on the way women are traditionally put on display/are often objectified in traditional Western paintings.

· By including cheap commercial objects in her work, Sherman challenges conventions surrounding “high” art.

Dancing at the Louvre, from the series The French Collection, Part I; #1

· Ringgold gives the figures in her work a dominant place within the museum by placing them dancing in front to the masterpieces.

· While the painting depicted in the work represents the Western painting tradition that was dominated by White men, the work focuses primarily on Black women and girls.

· Quilting over the painted representation of the Renaissance works draws them into the tradition of African American and other women’s quilting.

The Swing (after Fragonard)

· The figure’s lack of head likely references France’s historic use of the guillotine during the Reign of Terror in the 1790s.

· The use of Dutch wax fabric removes the figure from the traditional Western context.

· By using Dutch wax to clothe a figure from an eighteenth-century French painting, Shonibare comments on cultural hybridity as a result of colonial exchange.

· By depicting the figure without a head and placing the viewer in the position of the voyeur from Fragonard’s painting, Shonibare satirizes eighteenth-century upper-class French culture.

VR043197_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d:
Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt

Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, development of any of the following:

Untitled (#228), from the History Series

· By using costumes, wigs, makeup, accessories, props, and masks, Sherman has changed female stereotypes and put her protagonist women in control of how they are represented.

· By recreating and at the same time manipulating a historical painting, Sherman makes a statement about the way we perceive ourselves and others and how our perception is mediated by the images that we encounter daily. Her photographs are meant to mislead.

· Sherman completed this series while living in Rome; however, she did not visit the works she used as references in person. Instead, she created her works based on reproductions in books, using the same print reproductions available to all consumers, because she wanted to comment on imagery that was available to everyone.

· Sherman’s lack of expression suggests that she is not shocked by her own action; she displays the head (mask) in a dispassionate way.

Dancing at the Louvre, from the series The French Collection, Part I; #1

· The depiction of framed European oil painting in the work is echoed by the pieced frame that surrounds the quilt, connecting two different artistic traditions.

· As well as being a stand-alone work of art, the work was also reproduced by Ringgold in a children’s book, further questioning how art should be displayed.

The Swing (after Fragonard)

· Shonibare’s use of Dutch wax fabric calls attention to a material that has a complex history and, although assimilated into and identified with African aesthetics, is actually a global product representing colonial imperialism and power.

· By referencing a French Rococo painting that depicts frivolous subject matter, but at the same time altering the image (such as removing the head and clothing the figure and Dutch wax fabrics), Shonibare criticizes upper-class French culture that profited from colonialism.

· It was part of a ceremonial and administrative royal complex located in the citadel at Persepolis, situated on a high plateau and heavily fortified.

VR121051_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, or content in the creation or meaning of a work of art
VR121051_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how the design or sculptural program of the Audience Hall (apadana) of Darius and Xerxes was influenced by the historical context of the ancient Persian Empire.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· It was built as part of the new capital Persepolis in the Persian homeland under Darius I and intended to emphasize the power of the Persian Empire/emperor.

· It was part of the citadel and palace complex, which were symbols of kingly authority in the Persian Empire.

· The low-relief carvings of figures dressed in different regional attire of subject nations that belong to the Persian Empire reflects the division of the Persian Empire into different tribute-paying areas inhabited by different peoples.

· The depiction of representatives bearing offerings from their respective countries as tribute payments for the Persian king directly reflects the function of the apadana as a place where the Persian king would have received foreign visitors and tribute from representatives of conquered peoples.

· The Audience Hall (apadana) at Persepolis reveals the vastness of the Persian empire by including artistic styles and materials from the different cultures ruled by the Persians as well as representations of many different conquered peoples.

· The mix of different artistic traditions reflects the cultural diversity and cultural and religious tolerance of the Persian Empire, which continued to allow the existence of administrative structures and languages, as well as local religious traditions, under Persian administration.

· The influence of different artistic traditions reflects the interconnectedness of Persian culture with other ancient Mediterranean cultures.

· For example, the location of the imperial complex on a raised platform with a single-access approach of wide shallow steps follows Assyrian fashion, while the rectangular grid plan of the complex is comparable to Egyptian and Greek cities.

· The composite capitals of the columns in the Audience Hall combine elements from different traditions (such as palm fronds recall Egyptian capitals, volutes similar to Greek Ionic capitals, combined with animal protomes that are not typical in Greek or Egyptian capitals)

VR121051_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how one art historically valid interpretation of a work is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, and/or meaning
VR121051_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain why the sculptural program of the Audience Hall (apadana) of Darius and Xerxes can be interpreted as expressing the power of the ancient Persian Empire.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The relief program (including royal guards, Persian nobles and dignitaries, representatives from subject nations) underscores and reinforces the power of the Persian king and the breadth of his dominion.

· The scale of the hall itself and the sculptural program are meant to impress visitors and demonstrate the power of the Persian Empire.

· The animals (bulls, eagles, and lions) depicted throughout the sculptural program of the Audience Hall (apadana) are traditionally associated with Persian kingship and represent the power and authority of the king.

· Animal combat scenes are a common theme in ancient Near Eastern art and might also be interpreted as emphasizing the ferocity of the rulers and their forces.

· Ranks of warriors covering the walls in repeated patterns also emphasize Persian military strength.

VR121062_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a specific work of art demonstrates continuity within an artistic tradition, style, or practice
VR121062_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how the work references or departs from different earlier artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

Visual Evidence

· The work appropriates elements of content and style from an eighteenth-century Rococo painting by Fragonard.

· It includes a female figure on a swing, wearing an eighteenth-century-style dress.

· The swing hangs from a branch; there is the suggestion of natural scenery.

· The figure’s pose—she is playfully kicking off her shoe.

· The work also differs in significant ways from Fragonard’s Rococo painting.

· It is an installation, an art form commonly used in postmodern art, which is interactive and blurs the line between different types of media—something that is very different from a traditional painting such as Fragonard’s The Swing.

· The figure on the swing is headless.

· Though the cut of the dress resembles that in Fragonard’s painting, the fabric is completely different in style and not the type of fabric that Rococo painters would have displayed.

· The natural scenery, which Fragonard depicts in a fairly naturalistic manner, is only hinted at in the installation; the branch, for example, seemingly floats in the air.

· While Fragonard includes the figure of a young man/lover in his work, Shonibare does not; instead, the viewer is put in the position of taking on the young man’s voyeuristic role as an eager onlooker.

Contextual Evidence

· The use of Dutch wax fabrics references multiple traditions; they are fabrics that are popular in West African cultures but are also inspired by Indonesian textile making traditions (batik) and were originally produced in Western Europe (Netherlands and Britain).

· By appropriating elements of Fragonard’s painting, the work also references general characteristics of Rococo painting, such as the lighthearted, frivolous subject matter and the focus on pursuits of the aristocracy.
