VR121062_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain why a specific work of art demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice
VR121062_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use specific evidence to explain how Shonibare creates meaning in this work by referencing earlier artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· By combining appropriated imagery from eighteenth-century European Rococo painting with African wax fabrics, Shonibare comments on the legacy of European colonialism.

· Shonibare explores questions of cultural identity, cultural authenticity, and colonial exploitation by including and engaging with references to different cultural traditions.

· By beheading the figure on the swing, which can be interpreted as a reference to the beheading of members of the French aristocracy during the French Revolution, Shonibare creates a critical commentary towards wealth, excess, and privilege.

· By creating the work as an installation and putting the viewer in the role of the voyeur/eager onlooker, Shonibare makes the audience complicit.

· By incorporating Dutch wax fabrics, Shonibare references the imbalance of power relationships in colonial trade networks and its effect on cultural identity.

VR121079_rubric_category_2.ti: PART C: EVIDENCE: VISUAL AND CONTEXTUAL
VR121079_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

To earn either point, the evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Does not provide a specific example of visual OR contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Adam and Eve

Visual Evidence:

· The bodies of both Adam and Eve are depicted in a naturalistic manner.

· They stand in active yet balanced poses. Their weight is shifted on their hips as they lean in toward each other (use of contrapposto).

· Dürer uses fine lines and crosshatching to depict the figures in a detailed manner with naturalistic shading to imply volume.

· Adam and Eve’s bodies are depicted according to mathematical proportions.

· They are placed within an idyllic natural /wild landscape: animals are in harmony with one another.

· Includes Latin text identifying the artist.

Contextual Evidence:

· During the Renaissance, the art and philosophy of Classical antiquity were reintroduced to Christian Europe.

· During the Renaissance, artists used close/empirical/scientific observation to construct accurate representations of nature and the human form.

· Due to the popularization of woodcuts, intaglio prints, and other forms of mechanically reproducible media, Dürer was exposed to works of Classical art.

· The figures of Adam and Eve were modeled from sculptures of Apollo and Venus, which Dürer may have seen while in Italy.

Röttgen Pietà

Visual Evidence

· Christ’s wounds are extremely exaggerated.

· The wounds on Christ’s feet, hands, and chest are surrounded by clotted blood.

· Both Mary and Christ are depicted with large, heavy heads, which tilt downward.

· Christ’s body is rigid, suggesting rigor mortis has set in.

· Christ’s body is sharp and angular. His skin is stretched tight over his protruding ribs. Bones are visible around his shoulder and neck.

· Pain/anguish is visible on Christ’s face.

· Mary’s stare/furrowed brow/downturned mouth gives her a confused/mournful/longing/bitter appearance.

· Colors used for blood, clothes, faces, skin, create a sense of realism.

Contextual Evidence:

· The statue was displayed within a nunnery or church.

· Theme of Pietà (Mary grieving over her dead son) was considered a devotional image.

· The statue was used as a focal point for prayer.

· Greater interest in humanizing Christ developed in the later Middle Ages.

· There was a desire for more personal/direct/emotional connection to the divine in the later Middle Ages.

VR121079_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

To earn this point, the response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: Does not explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Adam and Eve

· Dürer uses reference to Greco-Roman culture/artistic tradition to establish a connection between Christian Europe and Classical antiquity.

· Dürer presents humans in their ideal form/as ideally proportioned figures to capture humanity’s perfection/purity before the Fall, when humans were in harmony with both nature and God/the divine.

· Dürer depicts his figures with idealized proportions/in classical poses to showcase his awareness of the artistic ideals of Greco-Roman antiquity, which regarded the depiction of the idealized human body as expression of beauty and perfection.

· Dürer depicts his figures in a naturalistic manner to showcase his awareness of the humanist ideas popular at the time, which were inspired/grounded in philosophical traditions of Greco-Roman antiquity and which put emphasis on the human realm and experience of the world.

Röttgen Pietà

· Using such graphic imagery evokes an emotional response in the viewer. The artist wanted to make the viewer aware of Christ’s pain so they would empathize with him.

· Focusing on the damage to Christ’s body humanizes him. In this work, Christ does not appear as an all-powerful God, but rather he is shown as a mortal being.

· The artist focused on the damage to Christ’s body to make the viewer feel connected with Christ and the divine. Looking at Christ’s tortured body, the viewer is made aware that through Christ, God experienced suffering as man does.

· Mary and Christ’s large heads draw attention to their facial expressions and evoke a sense of strain and burden, which emphasizes their humanity/helps the viewer relate to them.

VR121079_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

To earn this point, the complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d:
Does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt

Response demonstrates a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt
o.af:
Examples of possible ways for students to earn this point include, but are not limited to, development of any of the following:

Adam and Eve

· The animals included in the work (cat, elk, ox, and rabbit) represent the four humors, or four temperaments, a pseudoscientific/protopsychological system used by Greek and Roman thinkers to measure a person’s personality/the workings of the human body.

· The mass production of Dürer’s prints such as Adam and Eve helped spread ideas on humanism.

· Dürer integrates his native German artistic traditions with those from classical antiquity by combining the depiction of human figures based on classical ideals with a distinctly German-looking forest/with a focus on nature that reflects Northern European sensitivities.

· Dürer transforms/alters a traditional/Christian/biblical narrative (Adam and Eve in Eden) by incorporating ideas and visual elements from outside sources (Humanism/the Classical world).

Röttgen Pietà

· This work is distinctly different from the Byzantine/earlier medieval depictions of the Lamentation/Pietà in which Christ and Mary are not humanized and instead are depicted as transcended/aloof/divine beings.

· Inspired by the work of Christian mystics, such as Saint Francis of Assisi and Hildegard of Bingen, artists used their works to evoke a religious/emotional response in their viewers.

· The wars/famines/plagues of the 14th century helped popularize mysticism in Germany/art that emphasized extreme emotions (joy, tragedy, and suffering).

· Like works of Renaissance art this sculpture focuses on the emotions of its figures/humanizes its figures. However, unlike Renaissance art (whose figures are generally proportional and idealized) this sculpture evokes an emotional response/humanizes its figures using abstracted/grotesque imagery.

VR121098_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how the possible intent, purpose, and/or function shape the creation or meaning of a work of art
VR121098_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does not accurately use an example of specific evidence to explain how the design of the work was influenced by its specific function and/or religious context.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include:

· The viewing area used for meditation and reflection, which are major components of Zen Buddhist practice, relates to Zen Buddhist teachings, according to which enlightenment can be reached through meditation.

· The dry garden symbolizes a landscape; this relates to the importance of nature to both Buddhism and to Shintoism, Japan’s native religion.

o Rocks represent water features such as ponds, lakes, rivers, and the ocean.

o Large rocks represent mountains.

o Moss/grass represents land.

· The empty space within the garden, reflects Zen beliefs and practice.

o The simplicity of the space emphasizes the importance of calm, meditative reflection within Zen Buddhism.

o The monochromatic color scheme of the space is conducive to meditation and reflection in Zen Buddhism and contributes to the space’s empty/bare/stark appearance.

o The empty/bare/stark appearance of the space corresponds with the Zen Buddhist concept of enlightenment.

Enlightenment is attained when one transcends the illusionary, material world and reaches a higher state of being.

VR121148_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning
VR121148_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not use specific evidence from both works to explain a similarity or difference in how both works communicate their function as luxury items through their design, material, or technique.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Pyxis of al-Mughira

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—Pyxis uses ivory, and the All-T’oqapu tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both use specialized labor—Pyxis used skilled craftspeople to carve and process the ivory, and the All-T’oqapu tunic used skilled weavers.

· Both contain intricate designs—Pyxis contains courtly scenes, animals, and interwoven patters/plant forms, and the All-T’oqapu tunic contains a series of geometric motifs held within a grid format.

Differences:

· Pyxis was designed as a private luxury item to be displayed within the ruler’s palace, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic was a luxury garment designed to be worn publicly by the ruler.

· The All-T’oqapu tunic was designed as a piece of luxury clothing, while the Pyxis was designed to hold perfume or other luxury substances.

‘Ahu ‘ula (feather cape)

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—the feather cape uses valuable feathers of specific birds, and the All-T’oqapu Tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both use specialized labor—the feather cape used skilled workers to create the cape and gatherers to collect the feathers, and the All-T’oqapu tunic used skilled weavers.

· Both contain symbolic designs that communicate their use by certain privileged individuals—the feather cape contains simple geometric forms and colors, and the All-T’oqapu tunic contains a series of geometric motifs held within a grid format.

· Both use bright colors and patterns that would have made the wearer stand out visually.

Differences:

· The feather cape was designed to be worn in battle, as well as for representative functions, by a high-status individual in Hawaiian society, while the All- T’oqapu tunic was designed to be worn publicly by the Inka emperor.

Merovingian looped fibulae

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—the fibulae use gilt silver and precious stones, and the All-T’oqapu tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both required specialized labor to be created—the fibulae used highly skilled metalworkers, while the All-T’oqapu tunic used highly skilled weavers.

· Both contain intricate designs that made both items time-consuming to create.

· Both use brightly colored materials and complex striking designs/motifs that would have made the item stand out when worn by the owner.

Differences:

· The All-T’oqapu tunic was specifically designed to function as an article of clothing for the Inka emperor, whereas the fibulae are a pair of expensive decorative brooches, intended to be displayed by the wearer as part of their outfit.

· The All-T’oqapu tunic contains complex abstract geometric motifs arranged on a grid pattern, whereas the fibulae contain stylized figural/animal imagery.

· Both required specialized labor to be created—the fibulae used highly skilled metalworkers, while the All-T’oqapu tunic used highly skilled weavers.

· Both contain intricate designs that made both items time-consuming to create.

· Both use brightly colored materials and complex striking designs/motifs that would have made the item stand out when worn by the owner.

Differences:

· The All-T’oqapu tunic was specifically designed to function as an article of clothing for the Inka emperor, whereas the fibulae are a pair of expensive decorative brooches, intended to be displayed by the wearer as part of their outfit.

· The All-T’oqapu tunic contains complex abstract geometric motifs arranged on a grid pattern, whereas the fibulae contain stylized figural/animal imagery.

o.d: Response does accurately use specific evidence from both works to explain two similarity and/or differences in how both works communicate their function as luxury items through their design, material, or technique.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Pyxis of al-Mughira

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—Pyxis uses ivory, and the All-T’oqapu tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both use specialized labor—Pyxis used skilled craftspeople to carve and process the ivory, and the All-T’oqapu tunic used skilled weavers.

· Both contain intricate designs—Pyxis contains courtly scenes, animals, and interwoven patters/plant forms, and the All-T’oqapu tunic contains a series of geometric motifs held within a grid format.

Differences:

· Pyxis was designed as a private luxury item to be displayed within the ruler’s palace, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic was a luxury garment designed to be worn publicly by the ruler.

· The All-T’oqapu tunic was designed as a piece of luxury clothing, while the Pyxis was designed to hold perfume or other luxury substances.

‘Ahu ‘ula (feather cape)

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—the feather cape uses valuable feathers of specific birds, and the All-T’oqapu Tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both use specialized labor—the feather cape used skilled workers to create the cape and gatherers to collect the feathers, and the All-T’oqapu tunic used skilled weavers.

· Both contain symbolic designs that communicate their use by certain privileged individuals—the feather cape contains simple geometric forms and colors, and the All-T’oqapu tunic contains a series of geometric motifs held within a grid format.

· Both use bright colors and patterns that would have made the wearer stand out visually.

Differences:

· The feather cape was designed to be worn in battle, as well as for representative functions, by a high-status individual in Hawaiian society, while the All- T’oqapu tunic was designed to be worn publicly by the Inka emperor.

Merovingian looped fibulae

Similarities:

· Both use expensive materials—the fibulae use gilt silver and precious stones, and the All-T’oqapu tunic uses camelid fibers and dyes.

· Both required specialized labor to be created—the fibulae used highly skilled metalworkers, while the All-T’oqapu tunic used highly skilled weavers.

· Both contain intricate designs that made both items time-consuming to create.

· Both use brightly colored materials and complex striking designs/motifs that would have made the item stand out when worn by the owner.

Differences:

· The All-T’oqapu tunic was specifically designed to function as an article of clothing for the Inka emperor, whereas the fibulae are a pair of expensive decorative brooches, intended to be displayed by the wearer as part of their outfit.

· The All-T’oqapu tunic contains complex abstract geometric motifs arranged on a grid pattern, whereas the fibulae contain stylized figural/animal imagery.

VR121148_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art
VR121148_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does not accurately explain a similarity or difference in how both works communicate social status within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Pyxis of al-Mughira

Similarities:

· Both involved specialized craftspeople who the owners had access to due to their high status.

· Both were made from expensive materials, which the owner could access/afford due to their high status.

Differences:

· All-T’oqapu tunic demonstrates the power of the wearer by showcasing his control over people and resources within the empire, whereas the Pyxis was intended to demonstrate the owner’s power/high status by showcasing his material wealth.

· Pyxis displays scenes of courtly life related to the life of its owner, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic contains geometric motifs that symbolize different groups of people/geographic areas under the control of the ruler.

‘Ahu ‘ula (feather cape)

Similarities:

· Both involved specialized craftspeople who the owners had access to due to their high status.

· Both were made from expensive materials, which the owner could access/afford to due to their high status.

Differences:

· The feather cape was often given as a gift to honor high-status individuals, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic was created specifically for the ruler to represent his control over land and groups of people.

· The feather cloak uses colors and designs, which reflect the social status of a powerful individual, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic contains geometric motifs that symbolize different groups of people/geographic areas under the control of the ruler.

Merovingian looped fibulae

Similarities

· Both contain designs that symbolize power—The fibulae contain animal symbolism, such eagles, while the All-T’oqapu tunic contains a series of geometric motifs held within a grid format that symbolized control over different groups of people and territories.

· Both involved specialized craftspeople who the owners had access to due to their high status.

· Both were made from expensive materials, which the owner could access/afford due to their high status.

Differences:

· The iconography of the fibulae communicates social status through individual figurative symbols of power, such as the eagle, whereas the All-T’oqapu tunic communicates social statues through the combination of many different abstract geometric motifs, each symbolizing a certain group of people/geographic area under the control of the Inka ruler.

o.d: The response does not accurately use specific visual evidence to explain a way in which Kollwitz expresses a sense of anguish in her work.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Sharp, angular forms of the figure’s faces and bodies create tension.

· Details on figures’ faces and hands give them a bony/deathly appearance.

· Stark contrast between black and blank paper is harsh and grim.

· Worried /fearful/concerned expressions on women’s faces.

· Dense mass of figures evokes claustrophobic feelings.

· Figures are huddled closely together as if in protection against an external hostile force.

· Hands appear worn, heavy, and burdensome.

· Hand gestures (up in submission, covering eyes, clutching each other) suggest both fear and anguish.

· Wide eyes stare out of the picture frame toward something unknown, evoking a sense of anxiety.

· Child clings to mother's dress in fear/with worried expression.

· Negative space surrounding figures creates a sense of vulnerability and isolation.

VR187644_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR187644_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the Forbidden City.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Forbidden City

· The Forbidden City comprises 178 acres.

· Designed to be restricted to outsiders and house the imperial court, the city is surrounded by walls that are 10 meters high and a 52-meter-wide moat.

· An artificial river (“river of the golden waters”) winds through the Forbidden City

· The Moon Gate at the entrance had five portals; only the emperor could use the center portal.

· The Forbidden City is designed with a central North South axis.

· The plan included symbols of heaven and good fortune.

· The complex has a roughly symmetrical plan.

· The site had an outer court at the front and inner court at the back with a series of gates, courtyards and wood buildings with low curved rooflines and gates.

· The Great Hall (Hall of Supreme Harmony), part of the Inner Court, is the largest wooden building in China and contained the emperor’s throne.

VR187644_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR187644_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Palace of Versailles, Versailles

· Le Vau placed the town east of the palace using radiating avenues to connect the two areas.

· The park has a tree lined center area.

· A large and verdant garden using trees and soil from the original woods and imported from surrounding areas was planted along an East/West axis.

· The garden was detailed and vivid with colorful “parterres.”

· Fountains/artificial water features are incorporated into the design and layout of the gardens at Versailles.

· The gardens were placed so as to make it seem that the sun rose and set in alignment with the palace and the waterway.

· Versailles has 700 rooms, 2,153 windows, and has 67,000 square meters of floor space to house the imperial court.

The temple of Angkor Wat. Hindu, Angkor Dynasty

· The rectilinear site contained temples and buildings with ceremonial functions surrounded by canals and a moat.

· A mandala design orients the plan of the temple to the sun, moon, and cosmos.

· Angkor Wat has five towers, with the center being the tallest, surrounded by smaller towers, galleries and gates.

· Plan is relatively symmetrical.

· Complex is built along a central axis.

· Plan consists of layers of concentric squares.

Templo Mayor

· The temple complex was a walled enclosure at the center or four quadrants that defined the city of Tenotchitlan.

· The enclosure housed several temples and buildings.

· The Templo Major was 90 feet tall and rose as a steeply stepped pyramid with paired temples at the pinnacle.

· Two steep staircases lead to the top of each of the twin temples.

· The Coyalxauhqui (Bells-on-her-face) monolith rested below the Huiztilopochtli temple.

· Sculptures of serpent heads / serpent sculptures, and frog sculpture were positioned at the bottom of both temple staircases.

· A chacmool sculpture, a reclining figure with a bowl on his abdomen, was positioned in front of the Tlaloc temple.

· There was a large open court in front of the temple for public gatherings.

· The temples were aligned with the sun, which rose between them on the equinox.

VR187644_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar in how they convey meaning.
VR187644_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain a similarity in how both works of architecture communicated ideals of power.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Palace of Versailles, Versailles

· Built on a monumental scale, both complexes displayed the respective rulers’ supreme dominion over the environment.

· Both rulers used the landscape and positioning of buildings to imbue themselves with supernatural divine power; Louis to the power of the sun and Yongle to the power of heaven.

· Both complexes have residences for the royal family and entourage, servants, the military and government officials, functioning as well-appointed mini-cities that contained residents, insulated from outside forces.

· Both complexes use paths, gardens, and water to connect different areas in the vast space.

· Both complexes use state-of-the-art technology to channel water to the space

· Both complexes have expensively decorated throne rooms.

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, artisanship and luxury for their respective cultures.

· Both were built over earlier structures so as to improve on past accomplishments and to address problems with the old capitals.

· Both had spaces for private life, public events, and religious ritual.

The temple of Angkor Wat, Hindu, Angkor Dynasty

· Both complexes have fortress-like walls or moats the complex from the outside and control who is able to accession the interior.

· Both complexes contain buildings and open spaces designed for ritual and ceremonial functions focused on the ruling power.

· Both complexes are built along a central axis with roughly symmetrical plans to create an orderly space that reflects the power and control of the ruler.

· Both complexes have paths, courtyards gardens and water features to connect and different areas in the vast space.

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, craftsmanship and luxury for their respective cultures.

· The plan and layout of both compounds were visually based on tenets of religion with the layout reflecting a connection of the ruling power to the universe.

· Both complexes have artwork that demonstrates the power of the ruler by symbolically linking the emperor to the gods.

· The layout complexes reference the structure of the cosmos in their respective cultures.

· The layout of both sites suggests a high level of social hierarchies.

· Both sites contain spaces designed to host elaborate state rituals in which the ruler played a central role.

Templo Mayor

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, and craftsmanship for their respective cultures.

· The plan and layout of both compounds was visually based on tenets of religion, with the layout of each one reflecting a connection to the universe and nature.

· Both complexes have artwork that demonstrates the power of the state by symbolically linking the rulers to the gods.

· The layout of both sites suggests a high level of social hierarchies existed in both cultures.

· Both sites were the symbolic political and religious centers (axis mundi) of their empires.

· Both sites had spaces for people to gather and hosted elaborate state rituals in which the ruler played a central role.

· Both sites contain buildings associated with the ruling power that were elevated and accessible by levels of stairs in order to reflect social hierarchies.

· Both sites used architectural color symbolism to associate supernatural power with the ruler: gold (yellow) for the Forbidden City and blue/red for the Twin Pyramids at the Templo Mayor

· Built on a monumental scale, both complexes displayed the respective rulers’ supreme dominion over the environment.

· Both rulers used the landscape and positioning of buildings to imbue themselves with supernatural divine power; Louis to the power of the sun and Yongle to the power of heaven.

· Both complexes have residences for the royal family and entourage, servants, the military and government officials, functioning as well-appointed mini-cities that contained residents, insulated from outside forces.

· Both complexes use paths, gardens, and water to connect different areas in the vast space.

· Both complexes use state-of-the-art technology to channel water to the space

· Both complexes have expensively decorated throne rooms.

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, artisanship and luxury for their respective cultures.

· Both were built over earlier structures so as to improve on past accomplishments and to address problems with the old capitals.

· Both had spaces for private life, public events, and religious ritual.

The temple of Angkor Wat, Hindu, Angkor Dynasty

· Both complexes have fortress-like walls or moats the complex from the outside and control who is able to accession the interior.

· Both complexes contain buildings and open spaces designed for ritual and ceremonial functions focused on the ruling power.

· Both complexes are built along a central axis with roughly symmetrical plans to create an orderly space that reflects the power and control of the ruler.

· Both complexes have paths, courtyards gardens and water features to connect and different areas in the vast space.

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, craftsmanship and luxury for their respective cultures.

· The plan and layout of both compounds were visually based on tenets of religion with the layout reflecting a connection of the ruling power to the universe.

· Both complexes have artwork that demonstrates the power of the ruler by symbolically linking the emperor to the gods.

· The layout complexes reference the structure of the cosmos in their respective cultures.

· The layout of both sites suggests a high level of social hierarchies.

· Both sites contain spaces designed to host elaborate state rituals in which the ruler played a central role.

Templo Mayor

· Both complexes serve as exemplars of refinement, taste, and craftsmanship for their respective cultures.

· The plan and layout of both compounds was visually based on tenets of religion, with the layout of each one reflecting a connection to the universe and nature.

· Both complexes have artwork that demonstrates the power of the state by symbolically linking the rulers to the gods.

· The layout of both sites suggests a high level of social hierarchies existed in both cultures.

· Both sites were the symbolic political and religious centers (axis mundi) of their empires.

· Both sites had spaces for people to gather and hosted elaborate state rituals in which the ruler played a central role.

· Both sites contain buildings associated with the ruling power that were elevated and accessible by levels of stairs in order to reflect social hierarchies.

· Both sites used architectural color symbolism to associate supernatural power with the ruler: gold (yellow) for the Forbidden City and blue/red for the Twin Pyramids at the Templo Mayor

VR187644_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are different in how they convey meaning.
VR187644_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT use accurately use CONTEXTUAL evidence from both works to explain a difference in how both works of architecture communicated ideals of power within their respective cultures.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Palace of Versailles, Versailles

· The Forbidden City, built in a dense urban area, had fortress-like walls for protection; Versailles did have a military presence but not a fortress and was created to be expansive and merge into the countryside.

· Versailles, designed with the most current trends and artistry of the time, suggested Louis’s power and refined taste. The Forbidden City had a traditional Chinese design theme to suggest solidity and a link to the glorious past.

· The layout of the Forbidden City, which includes cosmological references, underscores its role as the center of the empire (the Middle Kingdom), whereas the location of Versailles was not seen as a religious or cosmological center of the kingdom.

The temple of Angkor Wat. Hindu, Angkor Dynasty

· Vast amounts of water were harnessed and redirected around the rectilinear areas of Angkor Wat, demonstrating the ruler’s ability to control nature, regulate water for agriculture, and use water as a design element. The Forbidden City did not rely on water on a grand scale but did use small areas of water to border gardens.

· The buildings in the Forbidden City emphasized width rather than height and lacked the tall towers that dominate Ankgor Wat.

· Angkor Wat contains high towers that are intended to reference the peaks of Mount Meru (the world mountain), while the Forbidden City mainly communicates ideas of world order through the organization of its horizontal plan.

· The Forbidden City contains a residential section for the emperor and his household, while there is no evidence of living quarters at Angkor Wat.

· While the Forbidden City contains an audience hall where the emperor presented himself to his subjects and received visitors, Angkor Wat did not contain an audience hall.

· Angkor Wat was created as monument to/residence for a specific god, Vishnu, who was closely associated with the Khmer king who commissioned the complex, while the Forbidden City was built as the residence and seat of the Chinese emperor/the seat of Chinese imperial power.

Templo Mayor

· The architectural and sculptural program emphasizes the connection between the Aztec gods and rulers in order to reinforce the ruler’s control over the empire; the Forbidden City communicated the power of the ruler through the emperor’s residence there, the symmetry and scale of the buildings and plan, and the restricted access.

· The Templo Major had public gathering spaces for witnessing state rituals, while the spaces intended for religious rituals staged inside the Forbidden City were limited to the elite.

· The emperor was personally present in the Forbidden City, which contained imperial residences; while the presence of the rulers at the Templo Mayor was symbolically implied.

· While the Forbidden City contained an audience hall where the emperor would present himself to his subjects and receive visitors, the Templo Major did not contain an audience hall.

· The ritual sacrifices at the Templo Mayor communicated military and political power of the rulers; the Forbidden City’s plan communicated power by emphasizing social hierarchies.

o.d: Response accurately uses CONTEXTUAL evidence from both works to explain ONE difference in how both architectural works communicated ideals of power.

VR189192_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Provide an art historically defensible claim or thesis that establishes a line of reasoning.
VR189192_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must make an art historically defensible claim or thesis that responds to the prompt rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt.

A claim or thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place that may be anywhere in the response.

A claim or thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: Response does NOT provide an art historically defensible claim or thesis that establishes a line of reasoning.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Coiffure

· Cassatt was part of a generation of artists who were appropriating the style of Japanese and other non-western art forms to break with established European/academic traditions.

· Cassatt was influenced by Japanese art because she was visiting World’s Fairs, salons of other artists, artistic clubs, and private galleries.

· Cassatt was fascinated by the new visual qualities that she saw in Japanese prints and other Japanese artworks.

· Cassatt was inspired to create more prints because print culture from Japan was highly popular and European artists were emulating its wide dissemination.

· Cassatt’s interest in Japanese art was part of a broader cultural context of European interest in Japanese art/culture at the time.

· The style of Cassatt’s The Coiffure reflects her interest in Japanese woodblock prints.

Les Demoiselles d’Avignon

· Picasso was part of a generation of artists who were appropriating stylistic devices seen in African or archaic/prehistoric art to break with older European traditions.

· Picasso was influenced by African or archaic/prehistoric art because he was visiting World’s Fairs, ethnographic museums, etc., where this art was on display.

· Picasso’s interest in African or archaic/prehistoric art was part of a broader cultural context of European and French colonialism.

· Picasso’s familiarity with African masks/Iberian sculpture influenced his depictions of female forms in Les Demoiselles d’Avignon.

Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

· Gauguin was part of a generation of artists who were appropriating stylistic devices seen in South Pacific art to break with older European traditions.

· Gauguin was influenced by art of the South Pacific because he moved to Tahiti to escape from European social/sexual conventions.

· Gauguin was fascinated by the new visual qualities that he saw in Tahitian art (textiles, sculptures, and architecture).

· Gauguin was reflecting on birth, life, and death in his paintings because he was highly interested in the spiritual life of Tahiti.

· Gauguin’s interest in art of the South Pacific was part of a broader context of European interest in/exoticizing of non-Western cultures as part of colonialism.

VR189192_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Provide specific examples of visual and/or contextual evidence relevant to the selected work of art and the topic of the prompt.
VR189192_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The evidence provided must be accurate, relevant, and art historically defensible.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately provide specific examples of visual and/or contextual evidence that explain why the artist was influenced by the imagery, styles, or techniques from another culture in the painting, drawing, or print.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Coiffure

Visual Evidence

· Flat areas/planes of color with little tonal variation

· Decorative patterning

· Downcast gaze

· Clear distinction of forms using lines to define their edges

· Shallow picture plane

· Use of the mirror as a formal device

· Depiction of an intimate scene centered around a woman

· Specific poses of body, such as preparation of hair

Contextual Evidence

· World’s Fairs, private salons, and art groups were all highly popular during the late 19th century in the United States and Europe.

· The distribution of Japanese woodblock prints (ukiyo-e) was widespread in the United States and Europe during the late 19th century.

· Interest in Japanese culture as well as in Japanese art, design and material culture, a phenomenon known as Japonisme, was widespread in mid-late 19th century Europe.

Les Demoiselles d’Avignon

Visual Evidence

· The faces of the female figures have a flatness and are fractured.

· The stances of the woman on the left and others are highly stylized.

· There are marks on some of the faces that may reflect scarification or embellishments on sculptures/masquerades.

· Dark outlines form the edges of and divide the figures internally.

· The direct visual address of the women appears confrontational.

Contextual Evidence

· While creating Les Demoiselles Picasso likely visited the Trocadéro ethnographic museum and was collecting non-Western art.

· Picasso was influenced by numerous visual traditions during the period when he created this work including African art and ancient Iberian art, both of which were available to him in Paris.

· The women represent sex workers, specifically prostitutes from a street in Barcelona known for its population of sex workers.

Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

Visual Evidence

· Depiction of Tahitian women as his subjects.

· Depiction of tropical landscape with volcano, ocean, animals, and lush vegetation.

· Bright color palette, particularly complementary colors of yellow/purple, blue/orange.

· The composition reads from right to left like an ancient scroll, fresco or icon.

Contextual Evidence

· Gauguin was living in Tahiti, then a French colony, when he painted this work.

· The 1889 Exhibition Universelle in Paris featured a Tahiti exhibit.

· European traders and missionaries had been present in Tahiti since the 18th century.

VR189192_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how the visual and/or contextual evidence provided supports the argument.
VR189192_rubric_category_3.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
The response must explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

o.d: The response does NOT accurately explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Coiffure

· World’s Fairs, private salons, and art groups were all emphasizing and exposing artists to art from other cultural traditions, such as Japanese art styles.

· The distribution of Japanese woodblock prints led to artists adopting formal elements from these prints into European traditions of etching and engraving. (Responses could make this connection through elements such as flat planes of color, strong outlines, shallow depiction of space etc..)

· The wide dissemination of Japanese prints inspired artists like Cassatt to create more works on paper and break with Salon conventions that stressed painting.

· The themes seen in Japanese prints were adopted into the European context. (Responses could reference themes such as women in domestic spaces, the use of mirrors as a spatial device, preparation of hair, etc..)

Les Demoiselles d’Avignon

· Picasso’s break with older European traditions of depicting women’s bodies as beautiful/available is clear in the flatness of the forms, stylization of the women’s bodies, marks on the faces, and dark outlines – qualities he saw in African and other works.

· The flatness of the space, stylization of the faces and bodies, or marks on faces may have been derived from African or other non-Western art he was seeing at the Trocadéro or collecting.

· The stylization of the women’s poses and facial features is similar to that of ancient Iberian sculptures that he saw during the period when he made this work, which he likely understood as a European “primitive” art.

· Picasso’s depiction of female sex workers as both confrontational and visually linked to African art suggests that he connects threatening sexuality to non-Western cultures.

Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

· Gauguin’s location in Tahiti and depiction of landscape reflect his placing this metaphorical painting in a new space, a break with European tradition.

· Tahitian women depicted by Gauguin represent metaphorical/spiritual moments: birth, life, death.

· Animals, humans, and the landscape all take on idiosyncratic metaphors or iconographic meanings that Gauguin hints at in his correspondence, but does not fully explain.

· Gauguin, like others of his generation, wanted to break with norms. By moving to Tahiti, he acted on the idea that colonized locations were sources of more “pure” visual and spiritual culture and would allow him to regress to a more “pure” and innocent version of humanity.

o.d: The response accurately uses ONE specific piece of evidence to explain the relationship between the evidence provided and an argument about the prompt.

The Coiffure

· World’s Fairs, private salons, and art groups were all emphasizing and exposing artists to art from other cultural traditions, such as Japanese art styles.

VR189192_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
VR189192_rubric_category_4.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response may demonstrate a complex understanding in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections between the evidence and the claim

· Confirming the validity of a claim by corroborating multiple perspectives

· Explaining nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Qualifying or modifying a claim by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

This complex understanding must be developed in the response and consist of more than a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does NOT demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Coiffure

· The development of the technology of photography and particularly ethnographic photography provided additional exposure to non-Western cultural traditions.

· Breaking away from the Salon and challenging painting as the highest art form was spurred by the display of prints in private clubs and exhibitions. The domestic setting of Cassatt’s prints and use of Japanese conventions fit with displays in these intimate interiors.

· Cassatt’s interest in Japanese art was part of a broader cultural context of European interest in/exoticizing of Japanese art/culture during the mid-late 19th century that occurred in the wake of the opening of Japanese markets and ports in the 1850s and the 1853-4 expedition of Commodore Perry.

· A major exhibition of Ukiyo-e prints at the École des Beaux Arts in 1890 influenced Cassatt and other artists. The exhibit included numerous works by Kitagawa Utamaro whose depictions of women in intimate settings were a particular inspiration to Cassatt.

· Cassatt was fascinated by the new visual qualities that she saw in Japanese prints and other Japanese artworks because she was exploring her place as a woman and/or American in the French art world and used the “otherness” of the Japanese subject as a parallel.

· Other 19th century European artists who were particularly interested in Japanese art, design and material culture include Manet, Whistler and Van Gogh. Their responses to this influence could take different visual forms from Cassatt. Some artists incorporated specific examples of Japanese material culture into their works (eg. textiles, folding screens) whereas other artists made direct copies of Japanese prints in painted form.

· Cassatt’s work both invites the male gaze with an invitation to view the woman’s exposed form in a private moment yet seemingly negates sexualization through a focus on formal elements rather than overt eroticism.

Les Demoiselles d’Avignon

· Adopting elements of the stylistic “otherness” of African and other non-European art was also a way for Picasso to reject the Salon and prior established Western artistic traditions.

· Les Demoiselles d’Avignon can be seen as a modernist take on 19th century works that explored female sexuality, sexual availability, the male gaze and the female nude, in some cases in “exotic” settings, such as Manet’s Olympia or Ingres’s Grande Odalisque.

· Picasso's interest in archaic/prehistoric and non-Western art was also founded in his imagining of colonized cultures both as “primitive” and as spiritually charged, unfettered or free.

· Picasso’s fascination with new ways of depicting women that were influenced by African or other non-Western cultures was also tied to his fascination with prostitution, venereal disease, and moral degradation through his belief that these cultures were more sexually free or primal.

· The presence in a preparatory sketch of a memento mori skull held by a figure (a medical student) who is often understood as a stand in for Picasso further underlines the potential danger presented in the eroticized and exoticized bodies of the women. The threatening element of their sexuality suggests Picasso’s complex and potentially problematic views of women and female sexuality.

· Picasso’s interest in Iberian art was tied to his interest in his own ties to Spain as his homeland or source of inspiration.

· France was a major colonial power with multiple colonial possessions in Africa at this time. Colonial exploitation is in part what made African works of art accessible to Picasso in Paris.

· Picasso shared an interest in African art with other contemporary European artists such as Matisse. Modernist artists responded particularly to formal qualities of abstraction of the human figure they saw in works of African art.

Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

· Gauguin ties together the palette of bright colors derived from his tropical surroundings, textiles, etc., with the idea of a gold background that would have been part of a Christian icon or spiritual painting.

· His palette is derived from both non-Western and older European cultural references, tied into his conception of a more “pure” spirituality.

· Gauguin ties together imagery of women and the life cycle derived from his tropical surroundings with spiritual metaphors tied to Christian belief . His use of three stages is derived from the Christian trinity, but he then hints at Polynesian themes with the animal and human imagery and gestures.

· Gauguin’s failure as a stock broker and/or his failed marriage in France were part of his motivation to reject European social norms and explore Tahitian culture and sexual relationships, which were also depicted in his paintings.

· Gauguin sent the work back to Paris shortly after it was completed, together with detailed instructions for its framing and exhibition, indicating his continued awareness of and desire to participate in the Parisian art world.

· Gauguin was aware of his reputation in France as an avant-garde artist, and he fostered this image and moved from being a weekend painter to a professional painter by emphasizing his spiritual exploration in Tahiti (including his attempted suicide).

· Gauguin’s depictions of Tahiti include elements of fantasy and stereotyping. Gauguin reported being disappointed by the Tahiti he encountered, which was not the tropical paradise untouched by European influence he had imagined.

· Gauguin’s representations of Tahiti and Tahitian women and girls have been problematized by contemporary critics as representing a sexist, patriarchal and colonialist mindset.

o.d: The response DOES demonstrate a complex understanding of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify a claim that addresses the prompt.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Coiffure

· The development of the technology of photography and particularly ethnographic photography provided additional exposure to non-Western cultural traditions.

· Breaking away from the Salon and challenging painting as the highest art form was spurred by the display of prints in private clubs and exhibitions. The domestic setting of Cassatt’s prints and use of Japanese conventions fit with displays in these intimate interiors.

· Cassatt’s interest in Japanese art was part of a broader cultural context of European interest in/exoticizing of Japanese art/culture during the mid-late 19th century that occurred in the wake of the opening of Japanese markets and ports in the 1850s and the 1853-4 expedition of Commodore Perry.

· A major exhibition of Ukiyo-e prints at the École des Beaux Arts in 1890 influenced Cassatt and other artists. The exhibit included numerous works by Kitagawa Utamaro whose depictions of women in intimate settings were a particular inspiration to Cassatt.

· Cassatt was fascinated by the new visual qualities that she saw in Japanese prints and other Japanese artworks because she was exploring her place as a woman and/or American in the French art world and used the “otherness” of the Japanese subject as a parallel.

· Other 19th century European artists who were particularly interested in Japanese art, design and material culture include Manet, Whistler and Van Gogh. Their responses to this influence could take different visual forms from Cassatt. Some artists incorporated specific examples of Japanese material culture into their works (eg. textiles, folding screens) whereas other artists made direct copies of Japanese prints in painted form.

· Cassatt’s work both invites the male gaze with an invitation to view the woman’s exposed form in a private moment yet seemingly negates sexualization through a focus on formal elements rather than overt eroticism.

Les Demoiselles d’Avignon

· Adopting elements of the stylistic “otherness” of African and other non-European art was also a way for Picasso to reject the Salon and prior established Western artistic traditions.

· Les Demoiselles d’Avignon can be seen as a modernist take on 19th century works that explored female sexuality, sexual availability, the male gaze and the female nude, in some cases in “exotic” settings, such as Manet’s Olympia or Ingres’s Grande Odalisque.

· Picasso shared an interest in African art with other contemporary European artists such as Matisse. Modernist artists responded particularly to formal qualities of abstraction of the human figure they saw in works of African art.

Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

· Gauguin ties together imagery of women and the life cycle derived from his tropical surroundings with spiritual metaphors tied to Christian belief . His use of three stages is derived from the Christian trinity, but he then hints at Polynesian themes with the animal and human imagery and gestures.

· The figures are connected by the serpentine forms that wrap around each of the bodies.

· The nude figures have highly detailed bodies with an emphasis on anatomical realism and idealism.

· The drapery accompanying each figure is flowing and naturalistic.

· The central figure is clearly a mature, adult male who is larger in size than the two side figures, who are smaller and appear younger.

VR189193_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explains how artistic decisions shape the form, style, materials, or content.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific VISUAL evidence to explain how the visual characteristics contribute to a sense of drama.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The figures are twisting and contorting in space.

· Expressions on faces feature contorted brows and gaping mouths, showing intense emotional states.

· The poses have dramatic dynamism enhanced by diagonal lines that dominate the composition: from the top of the central figure’s upraised arm through his opposite foot; with the tilted heads of the figures; with the central figure’s lower arm and the serpent parallel to his left leg and with the diagonal created by the body of the left figure.

· The bodies of the snakes twist and writhe around the figures, showing an emotional moment in the struggle.

· Tensed muscles, particularly on the central figure, indicate the force of the struggle with the serpents.

· Similarly, the postures of the figures show the extremity of the attack and the figures’ efforts to get free.

VR189193_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Accurately explains how a specific work of art demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR189193_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: The response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific evidence to explain how Laocoön departs from earlier Greek sculptural traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Laocoön’s complex composition of three struggling figures contrasts greatly with earlier Classical ideas of restraint and physical balance in works such as Polykleitos’s Doryphoros (Spear Bearer).

· The Laocoön depicts a range of human expressions in a naturalistic way that differs from the stylized expression found in Archaic and Classical work, such as the Archaic smile.

· The emphasis on diagonal lines and motion, with forms that project out into space, contrast greatly with the simplicity of the restrained contrapposto of earlier Classical works such as the Doryphoros (Spear Bearer), or the even more restrained, rigid upright frontal stance of the Archaic Kouros.

· The highly modeled forms of the Laocoön create a strong play of light and shadow that contrasts greatly with the more evenly illuminated surfaces of Classical sculpture.

· Whether an original marble work or a copy, the Laocoön differs from the Greek Classical tradition of using bronze for major sculptural monuments.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific CONTEXTUAL evidence to describe a historical event depicted in the Bayeux Tapestry.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Harold of Wessex swears an oath to support William, Duke of Normandy (also known as William the Conqueror).

· Harold breaks the oath to William and has himself crowned as the king of England after the death of Edward the Confessor.

· Upon hearing of Harold’s betrayal, William and his half-brother Bishop Odo make battle preparations to invade England.

· After arriving on the south coast of England, the Normans defeat the English in the Battle of Hastings of 1066; Harold is killed in the combat.

· William becomes King of England. (William’s coronation may have been depicted in the missing last section of the embroidery.)

VR189201_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explains how context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content and/or function.
VR189201_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use specific evidence to explain one example of how a political point of view is shown through the depiction of the events.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include the following:

· The embroidery functions as a work of propaganda by presenting details of the Battle of Hastings from the perspective of the Norman victors.

· The embroidery emphasizes William’s leadership, ingenuity, and even generosity through his strategic planning and extensive preparation for battle.

· The embroidery favorably distinguishes the Normans from the English by highlighting how the Norman cavalry dominated the Anglo-Saxon foot soldiers.

· The depiction of a star (thought by scholars to have been Halley’s Comet) could be read as an omen or sign of divine disapproval of Harold’s usurpation of the throne and the breaking of his oath.

· In addition to identifying key figures who play a political role in the drama, the Latin text arguably provides a running narrative from the perspective of the victors.

· Images in the margins on the top and bottom of the piece could be interpreted as having meaning that informs the main narrative in the center of the work or bolsters the victors’ point of view.

· The depiction of a banquet could be interpreted as conveying a political point of view in the context of preparing for battle or in depicting feudal hierarchies.

VR189201_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how an art historical interpretation of a work of art is derived from an analysis of its form, style, materials, content, function, context, reception, or meaning.
VR189201_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain how the Bayeux Tapestry reflects the point of view of its patron.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include the following:

· By depicting the narrative from a Norman point of view, the patron of The Bayeux Tapestry sought to validate William’s right to rule as king, being as he was divinely approved and thoroughly qualified to rule England.

· Most agree that the patron was William’s half-brother, Bishop Odo of Bayeux, and was therefore motivated to win William’s favor by depicting the events from a perspective that represented the Norman conquest of England in a positive light.

· In the embroidery, Bishop Odo is identified multiple times by name and portrayed as a loyal participant in the Norman campaign, thereby highlighting his role in the events that led to William’s coronation as King of England.

· The long, portable embroidery was likely meant to be hung in a vast interior space, such as that of a cathedral or great hall, providing large audiences with an impressive and propagandistic visual narrative of the Norman victory.

VR189202_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain how the possible intent, purpose, and/or function shape the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VR189202_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT use specific contextual evidence to explain the function of this type of work.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include the following:

· Nkisi n’kondi are carved by an artist, activated by the nganga (spiritual practitioner or trained priest), and its spiritual forces were activated by the nganga for clients or the community.

· Nkisi n’kondi is owned/kept/activated by a nganga to resolve disputes, to avenge a wrong, in healing, in oath taking, or as a guardian against malevolent forces.

· Nkisi n’kondi were often displaced, purchased or stolen away from their original settings and became collectable objects bought and sold as objects of curiosity and study by Western ethnographers and artists. This is a changed function from the original, but still a function in the history of the object.

· Nkisi n’kondi from the Kongo were inspirations and sources for similar objects in Afro-Atlantic religions (Vodun, Palo Monte, acumba, Santería), as well as contemporary art.

VR189202_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how and/or why context influences artistic decisions about form, style, materials, content, and/or function in the creation or meaning of a work of art.
VR189202_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain how the function influenced either the form or the content of this type of work.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include the following:

· In order to activate spiritual forces residing in/connected with the sculpture, spikes, nails, or pegs were inserted into the sculpture by the nganga (spiritual practitioner or trained priest). A particularly effective nkisi n’kondi will have many insertions as this one does.

· Belief structures that include an “other world”/spiritual world/world of the dead are referenced in the sculpture shown through reflective (mirrors) or white (kaolin) material that represents vision into the world beyond ours.

· The nganga’s role as an intermediary between the realms of living and

· the dead is represented by the presents of the kaolin/white eyes.

· The sculpture’s role in human affairs, such as oath taking, avenging, or acting as a guardian is reflected by its depiction in human form.

· The sculpture’s function/purpose to combat malevolent forces as a protector or avenger is communicated by its active gesture (with raised arm) and facial expression (wide-open eyes and open mouth).

· The sculpture’s ability to access the “other world” or spiritual world is conveyed by the inclusion of reflective material and white pigments.

· The objects that would have been held in the medicinal cavity represent the power of the nkisi n’kondi and would have been activated through the insertions of metal objects into the sculpture.

· The confiscation of nkisi n’kondi by colonial forces or missionaries meant that parts of the sculpture were often removed or lost; the item shown, for example, is lacking an object in the raised hand.

· the dead is represented by the presents of the kaolin/white eyes.

· The sculpture’s role in human affairs, such as oath taking, avenging, or acting as a guardian is reflected by its depiction in human form.

· The sculpture’s function/purpose to combat malevolent forces as a protector or avenger is communicated by its active gesture (with raised arm) and facial expression (wide-open eyes and open mouth).

· The sculpture’s ability to access the “other world” or spiritual world is conveyed by the inclusion of reflective material and white pigments.

· The objects that would have been held in the medicinal cavity represent the power of the nkisi n’kondi and would have been activated through the insertions of metal objects into the sculpture.

· The confiscation of nkisi n’kondi by colonial forces or missionaries meant that parts of the sculpture were often removed or lost; the item shown, for example, is lacking an object in the raised hand.

VR189204_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Using specific evidence, explains how a specific work of art (or group of related works) demonstrates continuity within an artistic tradition, style, or practice OR using specific evidence, explains how a specific work of art (or group of related works) demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or prac
VR189204_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use specific visual evidence to explain how the design of the structure or the organization of the interior space references OR departs from a related earlier architectural tradition.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include the following:

References to earlier traditions

· Concrete was a central building material in Rome, for example in the Pantheon and Colosseum.

· Columns are a primary structural element, similar to many architectural traditions. Particularly relevant references include colonnades such as the Piazza of St. Peter’s by Bernini or columns used by Le Corbusier in modernist structures like Villa Savoye. Other examples include Greek temples like the Parthenon, Egyptian structures such as the Hypostyle Hall in Karnak, or Persian structures such as Audience Hall (apadana) of Darius and Xerxes.

Ribbon windows stretch across the façade, similar to those used in Villa Savoye.

· The building’s minimalist, unornamented façade recalls modernist works such as Villa Savoye and the Seagram Building.

· Cantilevered structures blur the boundaries between interior and exterior space, similar to Frank Lloyd Wright’s Falling Water.

· According to Hadid, the winding pathways that are used throughout were inspired by Islamic architecture such as the minaret of the Great Mosque at Samarra.

· Deep shadows are used either for dramatic effect as in Baroque buildings like the Cornaro Chapel, or to produce a sense of weightlessness, as in modernist works such as Villa Savoye or the Seagram Building.

· Overlapping pathways and curvilinear forms provide a sense of movement and reflect the fluid and dynamic elements found in Baroque architecture like San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane.

· Hadid’s use of dynamic and irregular geometric forms recalls the work of the Russian Avant-garde in the 1920s and 30s (Constructivism and Suprematism).

· The unornamented façade, the use of concrete, and the blockish form of the squared corner and cantilevered observation deck are reminiscent of Brutalism.

· The use of asymmetry, curving walls, and organic forms found in the MAXXI reflect elements of earlier Deconstructivist architecture as Frank Gehry’s Guggenheim in Bilbao.

Departure from earlier traditions

Various features of the building’s plan and design depart from more traditional museum architecture:

· The museum’s overall plan is not symmetrical and instead has a curving L-shaped layout, whereas the plans of most traditional museum spaces are generally rectilinear and symmetrical.

· The interior walls and exterior façade of the MAXXI are made of unornamented exposed concrete, while older museums generally had an ornamented exterior and would be made of a more traditional material, such as stone or brick.

· The MAXXI contains a network of intertwining corridors and stairs which pass through the central space of the museum, in contrast to more traditional museum buildings, where such features are generally placed in corners or along the edges of the space, defining a prescribed path for visitors.

· Instead of having permanent rooms like more traditional museum buildings, the galleries of the MAXXI contain temporary, movable walls.

· While more traditional museum buildings are marked by a series of separate and distinct individual rooms, the floor plan of the MAXXI is free flowing and incorporates long, winding hallways that are used to exhibit art.

Hadid does not directly replicate traditional architectural forms in her building. Instead, they are referenced in an abstracted manner:

· Unlike the large marble or stone columns used elsewhere in Rome, the MAXXI’s columns are thin, metal, and unornamented.

· Columns on the MAXXI also often appear on a slant unlike traditional columns.

· The façade does not contain actual arches, but the U-shaped bends in the building’s façade recall the shape of an arch.

VR189204_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain the meaning or significance of continuity and/or change between works of art within a related artistic tradition, style and/or practice.
VR189204_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use specific contextual evidence to explain an effect Hadid intended to achieve through her choice to either reference or depart from a related, earlier architectural tradition.
o.af:
Examples of acceptable responses include:

As the first national museum of contemporary art in Italy, the MAXXI reflects life in contemporary Rome as well as its history. While the building is notably modern, considering its materials, techniques and overall style, it also makes references to Rome’s architectural history. In doing so the MAXXI museum remains in dialogue with the city’s architectural past and present. As part of this point students could discuss:

· Architectural styles that are referenced in the museum’s design reflect the style of older buildings within the city of Rome/in the area directly surrounding the museum (such as ancient Roman, Baroque, Modernist).

· The ribbon windows provide visitors with views over Rome and provide a connection to the surrounding urban environment.

· The use of cantilevering, as well as the Museum’s sprawling and irregular plan, allowed for sections of the MAXXI to incorporate pre-existing structures from the military barracks on the site of the museum.

· The layers of references to different architectural materials and styles present in the building correspond with its function as a space to display contemporary art, which often includes complex historical references and layers of meaning.

· The construction of the MAXXI was intended to revitalize the particular urban neighborhood where it is located. Building on the site of an old military barracks, Hadid wanted her project to bring new energy, positive attention and economic impact to the area of the city.

· Hadid intended the MAXXI to be a “campus for art” in which visitors were able to move freely among flowing interior and exterior spaces, experiencing the museum and its contents from multiple vantage points.

· Hadid created the MAXXI’s emphatically-unregimented, free form design as an appropriate companion to the museum’s contemporary art collection, reflecting and encouraging the experimentation, creativity and individualism of the artists represented.

· Hadid believed that the MAXXI’s series of continuous spaces would challenge curators to develop new ways of organizing art. The movable walls and open spaces allow for complete flexibility and for ongoing experimentation with installations, performances, or other types of projects.

VR217471_rubric_category_0.ti: Task 1: Explain how a work demonstrates continuity within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR217471_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific VISUAL evidence to explain HOW Georges Braque’s The Portuguese references established artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The somewhat centralized composition is reminiscent of traditional portraiture.

· The suggestion of a triangular composition references geometric order in the compositions of earlier Western painters.

· Oil paint on canvas was the prevalent medium for painting in the early twentieth century.

· The proportions of the canvas (vertically oriented) also allude to portraiture.

· The use of light and dark to model form references traditional techniques for rendering volumes and mass in European painting and print/drawing.

VR217471_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Explain how a work demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR217471_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific VISUAL evidence to explain HOW Georges Braque’s The Portuguese deviates from established artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Forms, including the implied figure, are fragmented and flattened.

· Forms are shown simultaneously from different vantage points.

· Braque uses no traditional perspective to create a sense of deep space.

· As result of the fragmented forms, there is no clear sense of figure and ground.

· The incorporation of text fragments in the painting as part of the composition is innovative.

· The color palette is neutral and nearly monochromatic.

VR217471_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Explain why a work of art demonstrates change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
VR217471_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. Each point is earned independently.

o.d: The response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific CONTEXTUAL evidence to explain WHY Georges Braque deviated from established traditions in portraiture.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Cubist painters like Braque searched for new ways of seeing and representing reality/subject matter that would fit ideas/views/life of early 20th century modernism:

· Cubist style in line with other modernist artistic movements that challenged traditional notions about the role of illusionism in painting/art.

· The breaking and fracturing form forces the eye to move across the canvas – there is no strong focal point.

· The desire to incorporate views from “all sides” of the subject created a new way of seeing a subject.

· The incorporation of a range of views implicitly associates the idea of time associated with viewing an object; reflects interest in contemporary scientific ideas/physics.

· Cubists like Braque were influenced by philosophies exploring the nature of human perception.

· The style resulted in part from a desire to extend the innovations of Cezanne, acknowledging that a canvas is not actually a “window” but rather, a flat surface.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific VISUAL evidence to explain HOW Paul Cézanne’s Mont Sainte-Victoire references established artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· Landscape is a traditional genre in Western painting, especially in the 18th and 19th centuries.

· The viewpoint of the artist, above the scene painted, references earlier landscape tradition.

· Another landscape convention is the focus on the mountain in the distance, rising over the plains and valley in the middle ground and foreground.

· The color palette adheres to colors that would have been seen in the subject.

· Although the brushstrokes are visible, they are organized to depict the subject.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use any examples of specific VISUAL evidence to explain HOW Paul Cézanne’s Mont Sainte-Victoire demonstrates change from established artistic traditions.
o.af:
Examples of responses that would earn credit might include:

· The forms of the landscape are fractured to create the landscape represented.

· Underlying geometric forms in the landscape are emphasized.

· Blocks of color flatten pictorial space, while other hues suggest depth and set up a tension between flatness and spatial recession.

· Contrasting colors placed next to each other create vibrancy.

· Gradations within blocks of brushstrokes suggest form and mass.
