VR255289_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255289_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

The Oath of the Horatii

· The painting was commissioned by Louis VXI to emphasize ideal moral qualities for citizens of duty and honor to the king.

· The painting depicts a story from ancient Roman history, in which three brothers are chosen to represent their city of Rome to fight to the death against the champions of an enemy town in order to end a long war between the two cities.

· The depiction of a patriotic story from Roman history was intended to promote the moral values of loyalty and patriotism, important during the Neoclassical/Enlightenment period in France.

· The emphasis on the father, who is depicted as the central figure and receives the oath made by the brothers, as well as the association of the depicted men as active and strong in contrast to the women, reflects the patriarchal values of French society.

· The Oath of the Horatii is a history painting, which was the most valued genre of painting in 18th and 19th century Europe, characterized by execution in large/monumental scale and moralistic subject matter referencing important historical of mythological events, which were considered to be of moral and educational value.

· Although the work was originally commissioned by the French King, it was later reinterpreted by proponents of the French Revolution as a symbol of revolution and citizens’ loyalty to the country instead of the monarch.

Theodora panel

· The Theodora mosaic is placed on the side wall of the sanctuary of the church of San Vitale, opposite of a matching mosaic showing her husband, Emperor Justinian

· The mosaic is diagonally below a mosaic depicting Christ, suggesting that Justinian and Theodora are Christ’s representatives on earth.

· Theodora is holding the chalice intended to hold the wine for the Eucharist (while her husband is shown holding the plate to hold the bread intended for the same ritual), which would be brought to the altar to be consecrated for the Eucharist. The three figures on her hem refer to the three Magi, drawing a parallel between presentation of gifts to the infant Christ by the Magi and the royal couple’s presentation of items in the church.

· The wine and bread presented by the royal couple would have been understood toe turned into the flesh and blood of Christ during the Eucharist ritual on the altar below the Theodora and Justinian panels.

· The halo behind Theodora’s head implies her sanctity and religious authority.

· Theodora was an unusually influential Byzantine empress who wielded considerable power and influence during Justinian’s reign; her depiction in the most sacred part of the church almost as an equal to her husband emphasizes her status of authority.

VR255290_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255290_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the wall plaque from Oba’s place.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Wall plaque, from Oba’s palace

· The Oba’s societal role is emphasized through insignias of royal status, such as the headdress, choker, and the presence of his attendants.

· The Oba wears coral, which only he could wear or deem others worthy of wearing; the horse he is riding on is also a sign of wealth and elite status.

· The Oba is depicted with military attributes; such as the sword his page is carrying, the shields his attendants are holding, and the armor of his attendants, emphasizing his role as military leader.

· The Benin plaque is made from brass, a highly valued material/medium in Benin art reserved for and associated with royalty.

VR255290_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255290_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Arnolfini Portrait

· Both members of the Arnolfini couple are dressed in rich textiles, fur and fashionable clothing, which showcase their wealth and high social status.

· The furnishings and objects depicted, such as the draped bed, the carpet and the oranges also convey their wealth.

· According to one interpretation, the gestures made by the couple indicate that the woman is receiving authority to act on her husband’s behalf in business matters.

· Van Eyck was a master of the new medium of oil painting and able to achieve unprecedented levels of illusionism through his painting technique. His works were highly sought after by wealthy patrons.

· Details, such as such as the images of the Passion around the mirror indicate the piety of the Arnolfini couple.

· Although the domestic setting of the couple showcases significant wealth, the objects and details of the interior indicate that they are members of the merchant class rather than royalty.

· The couple in the Arnolfini portrait appear to be alone, although on closer observation two small figures entering the room are visible in the mirror.

· Although the woman in the Arnolfini portrait is depicted as youthful and attractive, the man is shown with unidealized features and signs of aging.

· Van Eyck uses optical naturalism to create a detailed depiction of the rich textures and luxurious as well as symbolic objects that convey the status of the Arnolfini couple.
Seated Scribe

· Following conventions for portraits of non-royal individuals of Old Kingdom Egypt, the scribe is depicted in an unidealized way that includes signs of aging.

· The scribe is depicted with a soft body and protruding belly, which likely indicated access to plenty of food and a comfortable life.

· The skillful execution of the statue of the scribe and detailed naturalism indicates that the scribe must have been of high enough rank to become the subject of a statue.

· The statue is made out of painted limestone with eyes inlaid with two different minerals. This parallels materials used in some statues of other elite individuals in the Old Kingdom.

· The scribe is depicted in the act of writing on a piece of papyrus as a sign of his profession.

· The scribe does not have the idealized body of a Pharaoh but rather features such as sagging features and some body fat that convey aging and a more sedentary lifestyle.

· The artists who created the statue of the scribe took meticulous care to represent even small details of the body in lifelike naturalism such as the nipples, which are made from wooden dowels, and the eyes, which are inlaid with two different types of stone; the surface painting adds additional sense of naturalism.

· Both works emphasize social status through the use of media/material and highly skilled execution.

· Both depict gestures emphasizing the hands as markers of status.

Seated Scribe

· Both works follow established conventions for the depiction of a particular level of status/position.

· Both works depict signs of wealth to emphasize status.

· Both works depict signs of the individual’s role/position in society.

· Both works emphasize social status through the use of media/material and highly skilled execution.

VR255290_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are different in how they convey meaning.
VR255290_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain a difference in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Arnolfini Portrait

· The Oba’s social status is emphasized through insignias of power and rulership and by comparison to the other figures in the image, while the social statue of the Arnolfini couple is emphasized through the display of material wealth and signs of class.

· The Oba is depicted in an idealized manner to emphasize his social status while the man in the Arnolfini portrait is shown in an unidealized way.

· The Plaque emphasizes social status within a stylized representation; the Arnolfini portrait emphasizes status through detailed naturalism.

Seated Scribe

· While the Oba is depicted in an idealized manner to emphasize his royal status, the scribe is depicted in an unidealized way to convey his social status as lower than the pharaoh.

· The Plaque emphasizes high status within a stylized representation; the seated scribe emphasizes non-royal status through detailed naturalism.

VR255290_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255290_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the wall plaque from Oba’s palace and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Arnolfini Portrait

Similarities

· Both objects show that the societies in which they were created connected status with wealth and material objects, often acquired through trade.

· Both objects reflect social hierarchies within their societies.

· Both objects affirm the importance of spiritual life/the divine.

· Both objects artworks were made to be displayed in a dwelling (palace or home) to affirm the status of the person portrayed.

Differences

· The Oba plaque references Benin ideas of spirituality and the divinity of rulers; the Arnolfini portrait showcases the values, aspirations and new social significance of the emerging merchant class.

· Artistic patronage in the Kingdom of Benin was linked to royalty; in northern Europe, the merchant class played an important role in artistic patronage.

· The Oba plaque depicts status through conventional and stable forms of representation; the Arnolfini portrait reflects societal changes during the time of its creation.

Seated Scribe

Similarities

· Both objects express value their society placed in knowledge and intellect.

· Both objects enforce social hierarchies of their societies.

· Both objects express a sense of permanence and stability valued in their societies.

· Both objects may represent the importance of servants to elite individual in their society.

Differences

· The seated scribe expresses Egyptian beliefs about a continued existence in the afterlife, while the Benin plaque focuses on the status of the ruler in the worldly realm.

· The seated scribe expresses the importance of the act of written record keeping for Egyptian society, while the Benin plaque expresses the importance of visual record keeping.

VR255290_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255290_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the wall plaque from Oba’s palace to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· As central authority in the Benin Kingdom, the Oba also controlled trade, including for brass/bronze that the plaque is made from.

· The wealth of the Oba is emphasized through coral and by the horse, which were both acquired through trade and only owned by individuals of elite status.

· The medium, brass, was a trade item acquired principally through trade with Portugal. It was reserved for use in royal art of Benin to reflect wealth and status of the ruler, which emphasizes the importance of trade.

· Objects from bronze/brass were principally reserved for art of royal patronage, and items would be created by skilled artisans and artists in workshops associated with the royal court.

· The rosettes decorating the background of the plaque might also be influenced by Portuguese trade items and also emphasize connection between trade and royal status.

· Benin society was highly stratified; the Oba serves as king and central political, military, and spiritual leader who ruled for life.

· The maintenance of social order and stability was considered to be important in Benin society for ensuring the wellbeing of society.

· The Oba’s legitimacy was connected to his ancestral descendance from a lineage of divine rulers.

· The plaque was originally mounted to decorate Oba’s palace together with similar reliefs featuring kings or other important individuals, events, or scenes of courtly life connected to the Benin Kingdom and intended to convey the legitimacy of the King.

· The placement of the plaque at the Benin royal palace complex among other plaques represented the Oba’s divine lineage and descent from Oranmiyan, the founder of the royal lineage of Benin.

· The plaque was part of a palace display that served as a device through which oral histories were recounted and preserved.

· The Oba had a spiritual, as well as political, leadership role in Benin society.

· The spiritual power of the Oba / importance of knowledge and intellect is emphasized through his large head, which was considered to be the seat of intellectual and spiritual power and will.

· Like other depictions of royal/elite individuals, the Benin wall plaque follows strict conventions intended to emphasize the status and authority of the ruler and reinforce the order of society.

· The hierarchy of perspective and frontal depiction provide clarity and reinforce the Oba’s divine leadership through conventions used for centuries.

· The inclusion of attendants and servants in the plaque, and the emphasis of their servant role (for example by shading the ruler, supporting his hands, carrying his sword, drumming his arrival) emphasize the status of the Oba as well as the importance of the support of his servants and others for his ability to rule.

Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255290_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

The Arnolfini Portrait

· 15th century Flanders was a prosperous trading hub, and the Arnolfini were part of a rising merchant class who had obtained wealth and status through international trade.

· Several of the objects in the painting would have been acquired through long distance trade, for example the oranges and the carpet.

· Panel painting was an emerging medium that was favored by members of the merchant class to express their wealth, taste and newly acquired status.

· The ability of Arnolfini to commission his portrait from a well-regarded court painter was a demonstration of his wealth and status.

· The innovative use of oil paint to depict precision and optical realism was mastered by Van Eyck and highly valued by Flemish patrons.

· The Arnolfini Portrait includes symbols that underscore the couple’s merchant class status, including textiles, the room depicted, and objects acquired through trade.

· The Arnolfini portrait includes several references to the couple’s piety, such the circular images of the passion of Christ around the mirror, and the figure of a saint on one of the bedposts.

· The portrait would have been displayed in the couple’s interior as an affirmation of their social status.

· The interest in naturalism is reflected in the detailed attention paid to the depiction of secular subject matter such as the domestic setting of the Arnolfini portrait.

· While earlier Medieval European art is predominantly religious, the rise of urban centers and the emergence of a wealthy merchant class led to an increase in privately commissioned and secular art, such as portraiture.

· Portraiture featuring non-royal, non-aristocratic individuals was a new genre at this time.

· Within their wealthy setting, the couple is presented in a way that was intended to show individualistic features.

· The probable self-portrait that van Eyck painted in the mirror, as well as the inscription attest to the artist’s self-confidence, and value being placed on individual accomplishments.

Seated Scribe

· Ancient Egyptian society was highly stratified, with the god-like pharaoh on the top of the hierarchy.

· The maintenance of social order and stability was considered to be important in ancient Egyptian society for ensuring the wellbeing of society.

· Egyptian culture valued writing and record keeping.

· Only a limited number of people in Old Kingdom Egypt were able to read and write, and scribes were therefore valued for their skill.

· The profession of scribe was usually only open to members of a certain social class whose members had a privileged position.

· Like much of other Egyptian sculpture, the statue of the seated scribe conveys as visual sense of permanence and stability that seems to mirror values of Egyptian society.

· The discovery of the statue of the seated scribe associated with a tomb indicates the value/importance placed in his profession (although the precise context or purpose of the work is unknown).

· The depiction of the scribe in the act of writing was unusual; it seems to emphasize the importance of intellect and literary skill in the particular statue.

· The unusual depiction of a scribe in the act of writing might also indicate that the statue was intended to ensure the continued availability of the services of the scribe to an elite individual in the afterlife.

· The emphasize placed on the lively appearance of the face, and particularly the eyes of the scribe, emphasize his appearance of intelligence.

· Ancient Egyptians believed in the continued existence of the soul in the afterlife and ensuring safe passage/preparing for a comfortable existence in the afterlife played an important role in ancient Egyptian society.

· In ancient Egyptian burial contexts, depictions of people, animals, or goods were used to represent real servants or property that would be available to the deceased person in the afterlife.

· The discovery of the statue of the seated scribe associated with a tomb indicates the value/importance placed in his profession (although the precise context or purpose of the work is unknown).

VR255291_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255291_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the wall plaque from Oba’s place.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Wall plaque, from Oba’s palace

· The Benin plaque uses a near symmetrical composition that conveys balance and stability; the figures are shown frontally, with calm, stable poses and expressions.

· The Benin plaque is a cast brass relief sculpture that is relatively small in scale.

· The Oba is the central figure in an approximately symmetrical composition; because of hierarchical scale, he is notably larger than the figures that flank him.

· The Oba’s head is emphasized as being at the apex of a pyramidal composition.

· The depiction of the Oba follows idealized conventions of portraying royal individuals; he is shown with idealized features in the prime of middle age, including an enlarged head to emphasize spiritual/intellectual strength.

· The Oba is shown in a procession on horseback with his many attendants, whose feet are shown in line as if standing.

· The Oba’s importance is emphasized through insignias of royal status and wealth, such as the headdress, choker, coral necklace, horse on which he is riding, as well as the presence of his attendants.

· The Oba’s sword is carried by a nearby attendant, while other attendants are carrying weapons.

· Shields and figures frame the figure of the Oba to draw a viewer’s eye to him.

VR255291_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255291_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· Washington is depicted wearing an 18th century military uniform and his sword is hanging from the bundle of rods that he is leaning on.

· While Washington is shown with his sword, he is not holding it; it appears set aside and hanging on the bundle of rods. He is leaning on a walking stick, and a plow is placed behind him.

· Washington is depicted in marble, a valued material associated with Greco-Roman classical ideals and used for depictions of important/heroic subject matter.

· Washington is depicted in a contrapposto stance that conveys a sense of balance and harmony; he is framed by the bundle of rods and the walking stick, adding a sense of near symmetry and balance to the composition.

· Washington is depicted life-size. The statue is displayed on a pedestal, which elevates it above the level of the viewer so the viewer looks up at the figure.

· Washington is the sole figure in the statue; the fasces and walking stick frame him.

· The verticality of the statue emphasizes the figure of Washington.

· Washington is shown in a realistic/not physically idealized manner with signs of aging visible in his face and body, which suggest that his authority derives from wisdom/intellectual strength.

· Washington is depicted in contemporary rather than classical Greco-Roman attire and a button on his uniform is missing to show his lack of pretention.
King Menkaura and queen

· The statue of King Menkaura and queen is close to life size, sculpted almost in the round from a single massive block of greywacke, a highly durable stone.

· King Menkaura and queen/female companion are shown next to each other with similar height, stable posture, and calm facial expressions.

· Following the tradition of royal Old Kingdom portraiture, King Menkaura is shown striding forward with his left leg extended, while his weight is resting on his right.

· King Menkaura wears the traditional headdress, kilt, and ceremonial beard of an Ancient Egyptian King.

· King Menkaura is depicted with a flawless, youthful, masculine body, while his female companion/queen is depicted in a similar idealized fashion following Ancient Egyptian ideals for depicting the female body.

· The depiction of King Menkaura’s female companion (who many scholars believe is his queen or possibly his mother) is depicted with a protective gesture of laying one hand around the king’s waist and the other on his arm.

VR255291_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar in how they convey meaning.
VR255291_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain a similarity in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· Both works depict military attributes related to the role of the leaders.

· Both works depict the leader in a way that emphasizes intellect/wisdom and confidence.

· Both use historically valuable materials.

· Both works convey a sense of balance through composition and pose.

· Both works use composition to emphasize the primary figure and convey authority.

King Menkaura and queen

· Both works convey a sense of permanence and stability through a balanced composition and pose.

· Both use enduring, valuable media to convey the importance of the depicted individuals.

· Both convey active authority by suggesting measured forward movement.

· Both are depicted with insignia of rank and authority to emphasize their role as rulers.

· Both rulers are shown in an idealized fashion to emphasize their power.

o.d: Response accurately uses VISUAL evidence from both works to explain ONE similarity in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

· Both works depict military attributes related to the role of the leaders.

· Both works depict the leader in a way that emphasizes intellect/wisdom and confidence.

· Both use historically valuable materials.

· Both works convey a sense of balance through composition and pose.

· Both works use composition to emphasize the primary figure and convey authority.

King Menkaura and queen

· Both works convey a sense of permanence and stability through a balanced composition and pose.

· Both use enduring, valuable media to convey the importance of the depicted individuals.

· Both convey active authority by suggesting measured forward movement.

· Both are depicted with insignia of rank and authority to emphasize their role as rulers.

· Both rulers are shown in an idealized fashion to emphasize their power.

VR255291_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are different in how they convey meaning.
VR255291_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain a difference in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
George Washington

· While Houdon uses large scale and height to emphasize Washington’s importance/authority, the Oba plaque uses hierarchical scale to emphasize the Oba’s authority.

· While the Benin plaque stresses the authority of the Oba by emphasizing signs of rank/status, Houdon’s statue foregrounds Washington’s identity as private/ordinary citizen.

· While the authority of the Oba is visually emphasized through his elevated position among his attendants, Washington is depicted by himself.

King Menkaura and queen

· While the authority of the Oba is visually emphasized through his central place in the composition of the plaque, King Menkaura is depicted together with a female companion who is depicted on equal level with the King.

· While the statue of King Menkaura uses size to emphasize the King’s authority; the Oba plaque uses hierarchical scale to emphasize the Oba’s authority.

King Menkaura and queen

· While the statue of King Menkaura uses size to emphasize the King’s authority; the Oba plaque uses hierarchical scale to emphasize the Oba’s authority.

VR255291_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255291_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the wall plaque from Oba’s palace and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

George Washington

Similarities

· Both objects underscore the military role of rulers in their societies.

· Both objects represent ideas about ideal government and authority specific to their respective culture.

· Both objects emphasize the reliance of leaders on the support of others.

Differences

· While the Oba plaque expresses the ideas of government characteristic of a monarchy, the statue of George Washington expresses republican/democratic ideas of government.

· While the Oba plaque expresses the legitimacy of a ruler with significant political and spiritual power, the statue of George Washington emphasizes the limits that must be placed power held by any individual leader.

· While the Oba plaque emphasizes the importance of lineage for the legitimacy of a ruler, the statue of Washington emphasizes the importance of elections/public support for the legitimacy of a leader.

King Menkaura and queen

Similarities

· Both objects convey the influence and power of the ruler in highly stratified societies.

· Both objects commemorate the leaders as part of a royal lineage with divine connections.

Differences

· The statue of King Menkaura expresses Ancient Egyptian beliefs in the afterlife and the immortality of the pharaoh, while the Benin plaque does not focus on the Oba’s existence in the afterlife.

· While the plaque of the Oba primarily emphasizes the authority of the ruler in a secular/worldly context, the statue of King Menkaura primarily emphasizes the connection of the ruler with the spiritual realm.

VR255291_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255291_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the wall plaque from Oba’s palace to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The Oba ruled for life, serving as king and central political, military, and spiritual leader.

· The portrait of the Oba was placed on the palace façade to represent his divine lineage and descent from Oranmiyan, the founder of the royal lineage of Benin.

· The Oba’s legitimacy was connected to his descent from a lineage of divine rulers.

· The Oba’s head is shown as about 1/3 of the body to emphasize the importance of the head as the seat of the spirit and will.

· The plaque uses recognizable symbols like the swords and the coral regalia that are associated with Benin royalty.

· Bronze was a trade item and is used frequently in royal art of Benin to reflect status of the ruler.

· The depiction of the Oba surrounded by several attendants to serve him emphasizes his status and power.

· Two of the attendants depicted hold shields above the Oba’s head as a sign of respect reserved for the Oba.

· The Oba is surrounded by attendants that bear weapons, and page to his right is carrying his sword, suggesting a military connection or procession that included the display of military power.

· The horse that the Oba is riding and the coral are both trade items that signify the wealth of the Oba.

· The presence of the attendants flanking the Oba can also be interpreted as a reminder that because of the heavy burden of his royal obligations, the king relies on the support of others.

VR255291_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255291_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

George Washington

· Washington’s statue was commissioned for public display by the United States government to honor an important citizen and express values of the young/emerging republic; it was placed in the Virginia State Capitol, a site that would remind citizens of their leader.

· Washington’s portrait was created during a period of political change in which the North American British colonies gained independence from the rule of the British monarchy and founded a new American republic.

· As commander of the Continental Army Washington was an important contributor to the success of the American Revolutionary War that led to independence of the North American British colonies.

· Washington was honored in the United States for his refusal to take on extended powers of rulership after the end of the Revolutionary War, since this enabled the creation of the American republic and a transition to democratic principles of leadership.

· The use of marble and the depiction of Washington in a classical contrapposto pose carried associations of Athenian democracy and Republican Rome because of its use in antiquity.

· The bundle of 13 rods are an ancient Roman symbol of authority, called “fasces”, which also symbolize the 13 original states that formed the new American republic.

· The 13 rods that represent the colonies can also be seen as symbol for strength in unity/through mutual support.

· The sword that is hanging on the fasces alludes to Washington’s role as military commander during the war of independence - the fact that he is not holding it, shows that he has resumed his civil life.

· The plow that placed behind Washington and the badge of the Order of Cincinnati he is wearing both draw a parallel between Washington and the Roman commander Cincinnatus, who was given significant temporary powers as “dictator” during a time of war, but peacefully returned this power to the republic once the war was over.

· The depiction of Washington in a realistic, rather than in an idealized manner, signifies his humanity, humility, and individually earned role in history.

King Menkaura and queen

· The statue of King Menkaura was in one of the Valley Temples that belong to the larger mortuary complex of Giza where King Menkaura was buried in one of the three royal pyramids.

· The statue shows the deceased king and would have been worshipped in his mortuary temple as part of rituals to ensure the safe passage of the king into the afterlife and immortal existence.

· Egyptian kings were considered semi-divine through their lineage and to have a close connection to powerful Egyptian gods, especially the Sun God Re; after their death a king was believed to ascend to heaven as divine being/god.

· The identity of the female companion figure is unknown; some scholars theorize that she might represent the queen mother, who was a powerful figure through her direct ancestral connection to the king/kings.

· Some scholars theorize that the female companion represents the goddess Hathor, which would be in line with other sculptures of Menkaura from his temple that show him with the powerful goddess, emphasizing the connection of the king to the divine.

VR255292_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255292_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of lintel 25.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Lintel 25

· Lady Xoc appears close up and is the only human figure in the image. The sculptor draws attention to her by having the rising serpent, which fills most of the composition, intersect with her extended arm, and by having the figure that emerges from the serpent’s mouth point a spear at her head.

· Lintel 25 depicts Lady Xoc kneeling before a large serpent with a warrior-like figure emerging from its mouth, representing a vision experienced by Lady Xoc with the divine presence; the warrior figure is pointing a spear at Lady Xoc, suggesting a direct interaction.

· Lady Xoc appears calm/serene in pose and facial expression as she bends her head back to face the armed warrior figure that emerges from the spirit serpent’s mouth; her head is tilted backwards and her eyes are closed, suggesting a meditative trance.

· Lady Xoc’s position is closed and inward as she focuses on her hallucination/vision and the ritual she is performing.

· The bravery of Lady Xoc’s action is suggested by her offering the gods a bowl containing blood-soaked paper, which attests to her ritual bloodletting and sacrificial action.

· The sculptor who created lintel 25 took special care to emphasize Lady’s Xoc’s rich clothing and jewelry showing her to be a royal person (headdress, elaborate jewelry including a necklace presumably made of precious jade).

· Lady Xoc is the only figure shown engaged in the ritual of the blood sacrifice; her agency is emphasized through the bowl she holds with bloodstained paper and sacrificial implements, as well as through her meditative pose and expression.

· Lintel 25 is one of three lintels that depict different stages of Lady Xoc’s bloodletting ritual; lintel 25 depicts the central moment that is part of a larger narrative.

· Carved glyphs are included as part of the composition of lintel 25 to provide a narrative account to accompany the visual imagery.

· Lady Xoc’s success is indicated by the blood-soaked paper she is burning/presenting as an offering to the gods and by the presence of the spiritual being/vision serpent shown, which indicates a vision resulting from the successful bloodletting.

VR255292_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255292_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Burghers of Calais

· The Burghers of Calais are depicted on their way to sacrifice their lives. This is conveyed by the ropes around their necks, the sack cloth draped over their bodies, and their bare feet, all signaling their humility/sacrifice.

· Rodin focuses attention on the intense emotional reactions of the Burghers to their decision to sacrifice themselves and their inevitable fate by heightening the emotional expressiveness of the work through exaggerated poses and facial expressions.

· Rodin emphasizes the despair and resignation of the Burghers through their bodily poses and facial expressions that include sorrow, anxiety, and resolve.

· Rodin exaggerates certain body parts such as the elongated arms and large hands that stretch downward, contributing to their somber appearance.

· Rodin creates long deep folds in the drapery, suggesting the heaviness of the clothing that seems to drag the men down and slow their movement toward their sacrifice.

· Rodin depicts his Burghers of Calais in an unheroic way that defies convention: he placed the group of the Burghers on a low pedestal, so that they are almost on level with the viewer; he also depicts them dressed in simple clothing and walking barefoot, as well as displaying very human/relatable emotions in the face of expected death.

· Rodin’s sculpture is completely focused on the Burghers and their emotional reactions; he does not include any representations of divine presence.

· The Burghers of Calais is a group portrait that includes men from young to old, who react to the action they are taking with a range of emotions; Rodin emphasizes the collective nature of their action by arranging them in a circle and having them share similar despairing expressions and downtrodden postures as well as creating them all at similar height.

· The Burghers of Calais was created as an individual sculpture for public display in the city; it was not associated with other sculptures telling other parts of the same narrative.
David

· David is shown resting one foot on the head of the slain Goliath, while resting the sword he is holding in his right hand on the ground.

· Donatello focuses on David as the only full figure shown, with the head of the slain Goliath lying under David’s foot and shield near the bottom of the composition.

· The vertical orientation and graceful contrapposto lines of the figure and angled sword pull the viewer’s eye down David’s body toward Goliath’s head, calling attention to his act of killing the giant.

· David’s bravery is emphasized by his youthful, slender appearance and nudity, which contrast with the size of his slain, armored opponent.

· Donatello depicts David in a calm contemplative pose in the aftermath of a frightening encounter, shown by the severed head of his opponent and the sword David leans on.

· David’s success is shown by his foot that rests on Goliath’s head.

· The sword in his right hand and the victory wreath he is standing on also allude to his victory.

· David’s casual, open stance, as well as his facial expression, seem to express contentment/satisfaction at the completed task of killing Goliath.

· David’s lack of protective armor and nudity/youthful appearance indicate his young age and lower social status.

· David is a free-standing sculpture that was displayed by itself and was not associated with other sculptures telling more of this Biblical narrative.

VR255292_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

David

· Both works depict the figures as brave and fearless/calm in the face of dramatic/potentially frightening circumstances.

· Both works show the figures as successful in their respective endeavors.

VR255292_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are different in how they convey meaning.
VR255292_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain a difference in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Burghers of Calais

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the significance of Lady Xoc’s sacrifice by depicting her as strong and calm, while Rodin emphasizes the significance of the Burghers’ sacrifice by representing emotions of despair and resignation.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the significance of Lady Xoc’s actions by drawing attention to her elevated status, while Rodin emphasizes the significance of the Burghers’ actions by depicting them as ordinary men that the viewer can relate to.

· Lintel 25 depicts Lady Xoc interacting with the divine to emphasize the significance of her actions, while Rodin does not depict any sign of divine presence in his Burghers.

· The Burghers of Calais shows a group of men who are collectively taking this action; Lady Xoc is shown as a sole actor.

· Rodin chose to depict/emphasize a specific moment taken from larger narrative, while lintel 25 is part of a series of carved lintels at Yaxchilan that communicate a multi-part narrative.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes Lady Xoc’s success/positive outcome of her sacrifice, while the Burghers emphasizes the act of sacrifice itself without depicting the final outcome.

David

· Donatello depicts the aftermath of the accomplishment, not the battle itself, while Lady Xoc is depicted during the climax of the bloodletting ritual.

· David is depicted as a simple young man who did something admirable; Lady Xoc is shown as a royal figure who did something admirable, as a requirement.

· David was created as an individual sculpture that communicates a single moment in a story/narrative; lintel 25 is part of a series of carved lintels at Yaxchilan that communicate a multi-part narrative.

o.d: Response accurately uses VISUAL evidence from both works to explain ONE difference in how both works emphasize the significance of the accomplishments or actions of the individuals depicted.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Burghers of Calais

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the significance of Lady Xoc’s sacrifice by depicting her as strong and calm, while Rodin emphasizes the significance of the Burghers’ sacrifice by representing emotions of despair and resignation.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the significance of Lady Xoc’s actions by drawing attention to her elevated status, while Rodin emphasizes the significance of the Burghers’ actions by depicting them as ordinary men that the viewer can relate to.

· Lintel 25 depicts Lady Xoc interacting with the divine to emphasize the significance of her actions, while Rodin does not depict any sign of divine presence in his Burghers.

· The Burghers of Calais shows a group of men who are collectively taking this action; Lady Xoc is shown as a sole actor.

· Rodin chose to depict/emphasize a specific moment taken from larger narrative, while lintel 25 is part of a series of carved lintels at Yaxchilan that communicate a multi-part narrative.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes Lady Xoc’s success/positive outcome of her sacrifice, while the Burghers emphasizes the act of sacrifice itself without depicting the final outcome.

David

· Donatello depicts the aftermath of the accomplishment, not the battle itself, while Lady Xoc is depicted during the climax of the bloodletting ritual.

· David is depicted as a simple young man who did something admirable; Lady Xoc is shown as a royal figure who did something admirable, as a requirement.

· David was created as an individual sculpture that communicates a single moment in a story/narrative; lintel 25 is part of a series of carved lintels at Yaxchilan that communicate a multi-part narrative.

VR255292_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255292_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how lintel 25 and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

The Burghers of Calais

Similarities

· Each work was created in a society that valued personal sacrifice for the good of the whole community.

· Both works express values of a hierarchical social order, as both depict individuals of elevated social rank performing a sacrifice, suggesting that those of higher status/prominence had higher responsibilities for the wellbeing of society and that their sacrifices were deemed more valuable.

Differences

· The Burghers of Calais are making a sacrifice that is considered extraordinary in a time of war and desperation; Lady Xoc is shown engaged in a sacrificial ritual that high-ranking individuals in Maya society were expected to make at regular intervals.

· Although both Lady Xoc and the Burghers of Calais are of prominent/elevated status within their communities, Rodin emphasizes the “ordinary” nature of his burghers, while lintel 25 emphasizes the elevated position of Lady Xoc.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the privileged status and authority of Lady Xoc; Rodin chose to emphasize the ordinary human qualities of his Burghers and the value of collective action/collective support.

David

Similarities

· Both works express values that honor individual sacrifice for the good of society.

· Both works express the importance of shared religious beliefs for the societies in which they were created.

· Both works connect religious subject matter with political messages/symbolism.

· Both works affirm existing forms of government/relationships of power in their societies.

Differences

· David is a commoner who did something extraordinary; Lady Xoc was royal and therefore expected to make this sacrifice.

· Donatello’s statue emphasizes the religious significance of characters/events from ancient history/mythology for Italian Renaissance culture, while lintel 25 emphasizes the spiritual connection/religious role of contemporary rulers in Maya society.

· Donatello’s statue of David can be interpreted as a symbolic representation of Florentine independence, while lintel 25 emphasizes the importance of the Maya ruling elite.

VR255292_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255292_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about lintel 25 to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· Lintel 25 depicts Lady Xoc experiencing a vision as part of a painful ordeal in which she pulled a rope with thorns through her tongue. Blood-soaked paper is burned as an offering to the gods.

· The Maya considered bloodletting rituals necessary to maintain the society’s harmonious relationship with the gods; only elite (in this case, royal) Maya could engage in this ritual.

· The bloodletting ritual resulted in visions/hallucinations which facilitated a spiritual experience/connection between the person performing the ritual and the spiritual world represented by the vision serpent and the figure emerging from its mouth, who might be a member of her royal lineage.

· Lady Xoc was the principal wife of the powerful Maya ruler Shield Jaguar who ruled over the city state of Yaxchilan and who commissioned the building that lintel 25 belonged to; she is dressed in elaborate robes and Sun God ornaments, indicating her royal status.

· The hieroglyphic text included in the relief records information related to Lady Xoc’s legitimacy and the historical context of the creation of the relief, including the date of ascension of her husband to the throne.

· The depiction of Lady Xoc performing an important ritual exclusively performed by individuals that belonged to the ruling elite/royalty emphasizes her social status (as well as that of her husband) and her role in ensuring the wellbeing of her people.

· Lintel 25 was one of several lintels originally installed at the royal complex of Yaxchilan, further emphasizing the connection between the religious ritual depicted and the leadership role of Maya royalty.

VR255292_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255292_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

The Burghers of Calais

· The Burghers of Calais commemorates a 14th-century event during the 100 Years War: six prominent citizens agreed to give up their lives to save Calais after a long siege.

· Rodin created the work as a commission for the city; the work was intended for prominent display.

· Although the lives of the Burghers would eventually be spared, Rodin chose to depict the particular moment when they are giving themselves up to their enemies to focus on their sacrifice.

· The Burghers of Calais shows men simply dressed, emphasizing that these are relatively ordinary people taking extraordinary actions.

· Like other artists of the late 19th century, Rodin challenged academic tradition to present heroic ideals in public sculpture. He focuses more on the human emotion of the individuals memorialized.

David

· Donatello’s David references Classical Greco-Roman art in various ways: freestanding statue cast in bronze, nudity of the subject/hero depicted, contrapposto pose.

· While the statue references antique Greco-Roman sculptural traditions, the subject matter is Judeo-Christian, emphasizing the importance of Christian religion for Renaissance culture/art.

· The choice of biblical subject matter for the statue emphasizes the importance of Christian religion for Renaissance culture/art.

· The statue is based on the Old Testament story of David, a young shepherd who was the only person brave enough to face the giant Goliath.

· By killing Goliath, David saved his people from presumed enslavement and destruction.

· David wears (almost) no armor or indications of status.

· The sculpture is thought to have been intended for display in the courtyard of a palace of the powerful Florentine Medici family.

· The figure of David was a popular subject in Renaissance art created in Florence, since the city of Florence associated themselves with the biblical hero, whom they regarded as a symbol of Florentine independence.

· By commissioning a statue of David for their private residence, the Medici family would have expressed their identification/connection with the city of Florence.

VR255293_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255293_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of lintel 25.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Lintel 25

· Lintel 25 is one of three lintels that depict different stages of Lady Xoc’s ritual interactions with gods and family members, here experiencing a vision represented including a serpent.

· Lintel 25 depicts a scene where both hieroglyphic text and a vision serpent appearing to Lady Xoc are carved in deep relief from limestone.

· Lintel 25 depicts a narrative from Lady Xoc’s life, including her interactions with spirits during an episode of ritual bloodletting during which she experienced a hallucinatory vision.

· Glyphs are included across the top and upper left side of the frame.

· Lintel 25 depicts Lady Xoc engaged in a blood-letting ritual; it shows her with implements used for bloodletting, indicating that she has completed the part of the ritual that includes sacrificing/letting her own blood flow.

· Lady Xoc is depicted holding a bowl in her left hand containing blood-stained paper and displaying a second bowl on the ground before her that also contains a blood sacrifice.

· The lines created by the vision serpent and the emerging spiritual warrior/ancestor figure and the spear he is holding lead to a focus on Lady Xoc and suggesting a direct interaction.

· Lady Xoc’s face is calm /serene, her eyes are closed, and her head is turned upwards towards the face of the warrior/ancestral spirit, emphasizing the connection between the two figures.

· The sculptor took special care to emphasize the rich clothing and jewelry Lady Xoc is wearing (her headdress, pectoral, huipil, and jewelry made of precious jade), showing that she is a royal person.

· Most of the upper and left part of the carving of lintel 25 is taken up with the depiction of the spirit serpent and the warrior-like figure emerging from its mouth, while Lady Xoc is depicted kneeling below the serpent in the lower right part of the relief and tilting her head backwards to point her face towards the warrior-like figure who looks down at her.

· While lintel 25 depicts a moment from a ritual, no audience is depicted; Lady Xoc is the only human individual present.

VR255293_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255293_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

· The Akhenaten relief shows the king and queen playing with and caressing their young children.

· The royal status of Akhenaten and his wife Nefertiti is emphasized through the headdresses/crowns they are wearing, and the symbols included on queen Nefertiti’s throne.

· In the Akhenaten relief, the god Aten is depicted as a sun disk in the upper center of the relief between King Akhenaten and Queen Nefertiti; the rays of the sun disk end in hands which are holding ankh symbols, emphasizing the couples’ connection with the divine.

· While the Akhenaten relief centers around the intimate and informal scene of the king and queen playing with their children, the god Aten is represented as a circular disk at the top of the panel to underscore his divine presence, watching over the king and his family.

· Egyptian hieroglyphic text is included throughout the work.
Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· The sculpture depicting the ecstasy of Saint Teresa is part of a complex work that merges architecture, sculpture, and painting.

· The figures of the saint and the angel are sculptures in the round carved from marble set on an architectural stage that frames the sculpture; metal is used for the rays of light above the figures; real light is filtered through a hidden glass window above it; marble relief carvings depict the audience watching from balconies, and stucco and painting are used to show angels floating near the ceiling.

· Bernini created sculptural representations of two balconies flanking the central sculptural group, where sculptures of the Cornaro family are shown watching the main event of the vision.

· The moment depicted comes from a vision Teresa had experienced, in which she was stabbed with a flame-tipped arrow, seen here in the hand of the angel.

· The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa shows the precise moment after the angel has plunged the flame-tipped spear into her side, leaving Teresa “utterly consumed by the great love of God,” and does not rely on any other works outside of the piece to contribute to the narrative.

· The rays of light, the angel’s gaze and posture, and arrow that the angel points at St. Teresa all lead to the focus on the figure of Saint Teresa.

· The saint’s face is pointed slightly upwards, creating a connection with the face of the angel.

· The architectural/theatrical/stagelike setting of the sculpture of St. Teresa is illuminated by a hidden window that lets light fall onto the sculpture, creating the impression that the saint is touched by divine light.

· St. Teresa is depicted as though in a trance; her body appears limp; her head is tilted slightly backwards with eyes closed.

· Bernini conveys Teresa’s spiritual revelation/experience through physical/bodily reactions that may be associated with sexual pleasure.

· As a nun and member of the Carmelite order, Saint Teresa is wearing the heavy woolen nun’s habit and has bare feet, both distinctive characteristics of the order.

VR255293_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VR255293_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain ONE similarity in how both works depict an interaction between an individual or individuals and the divine.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

· Both works depict elite/royal individuals interacting with the divine.

· Both works include a physical representation of a divine entity or spiritual concept.

· Both works place the representation of the divine above the depiction of the human individuals to emphasize its spiritual/divine nature.

· The main figures in both works wear dress or adornments that show their status/worthiness to interact with the divine.

· Both works incorporate text as a visual element.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· The compositions of both works emphasize the connection between the depicted individual and a representation of the divine.

· The figures’ expressions are concentrated and turned inward/meditative to convey an intense internal spiritual experience.

· Both works depict an individual experiencing a divine vision, which is expressed in the work as physical interaction/presence.

· The main figures depicted in both works wear dress or adornments that show their status/worthiness to interact with the divine.

· Both works show a distinct moment in time from a larger narrative event in which a figure is directly interacting with the divine.

VR255293_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are similar and/or different in how they convey meaning.
VR255293_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately use VISUAL evidence from both works to explain ONE difference in how both works depict an interaction between an individual or individuals and the divine.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

· The royal family in the Akhenaten relief is shown in an informal and intimate scene, while Lady Xoc is depicted performing a formal sacrificial ritual.

· The Akhenaten relief shows the royal couple and their children receiving something from a god, while lintel 25 shows Lady Xoc giving an offering to the gods.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· Lintel 25 belongs to a series of carvings that together create a narrative, while The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa depicts a specific moment from a narrative in a stand-alone work.

· Lintel 25 is a relief carving with traces of paint while The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa is a three-dimensional work that includes several different media throughout the broader architectural space.

· While The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa includes the depiction of an audience that witnesses the spiritual interaction, lintel 25 does not include physical references to an audience.

VR255293_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255293_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how lintel 25 and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

Similarities

· Both works express the belief that individuals of elite status/rulers have special access to the divine.

· Both works emphasize the legitimacy of rulers/royal individuals by depicting them in an exclusive interaction with the divine.

· Both works emphasize the role of rulers as representatives of their people in interactions with the divine.

· Both works highlight that the women have status and access to the divine within a hierarchical and patriarchal culture through their association to male rulers.

Differences

· While lintel 25 emphasizes the importance of religious rituals in accessing the divine, the Akhenaten relief expresses the belief that the pharaoh and his queen enjoy a privileged connection with the divine that exists beyond special rituals.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the importance of sacrifice made by humans to the gods in Maya society/religious belief and practice, while the Akhenaten relief emphasizes the life-giving power of the divine freely given in Amarna period religion.

· During this period of the Maya empire, religion and the worship of a pantheon of gods were well established and of high importance for order to be maintained, while in the Amarna period under the rule of Akhenaton, there was a major shift to a monotheistic system shown here with the single god Aten.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

Similarities

· Both works were created in societies that highly valued a connection between the human and divine realms.

· Both works demonstrate a belief in visionary experience as a means to communicate with the divine/find spiritual knowledge or enlightenment.

Differences

· In Maya society, only elite people could directly communicate with the gods; with Catholic Christians, any person had the possibility of such revelation/spiritual experience.

· In Maya society, communication with the gods was part of established rituals; the visions of Saint Teresa were miraculous revelations from God.

· In Maya culture, members of the royal family were expected to perform bloodletting rituals to ensure the well-being of society, while Christian culture believed in the sacrifice of Jesus for humanity.

· During the period of the Maya empire, the polytheistic pantheon of gods including Tlaloc and their worship structures continued, whereas the structure of the Catholic church during the Baroque period was being challenged and altered, and the call to bring people back to the faith is therefore more evident.

o.d: Response accurately explains ONE similarity OR difference in how lintel 25 and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

Similarities

· Both works express the belief that individuals of elite status/rulers have special access to the divine.

· Both works emphasize the legitimacy of rulers/royal individuals by depicting them in an exclusive interaction with the divine.

· Both works emphasize the role of rulers as representatives of their people in interactions with the divine.

· Both works highlight that the women have status and access to the divine within a hierarchical and patriarchal culture through their association to male rulers.

Differences

· While lintel 25 emphasizes the importance of religious rituals in accessing the divine, the Akhenaten relief expresses the belief that the pharaoh and his queen enjoy a privileged connection with the divine that exists beyond special rituals.

· Lintel 25 emphasizes the importance of sacrifice made by humans to the gods in Maya society/religious belief and practice, while the Akhenaten relief emphasizes the life giving power of the divine freely given in Amarna period religion.

· During this period of the Maya empire, religion and the worship of a pantheon of gods was well established and of high importance for order to be maintained, while in the Amarna period under the rule of Akhenaton, there was a major shift to a monotheistic system shown here with the single god Aten.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

Similarities

· Both works were created in societies that highly valued a connection between the human and divine realms.

· Both works demonstrate a belief in visionary experience as a means to communicate with the divine/find spiritual knowledge or enlightenment.

Differences

· In Maya society, only elite people could directly communicate with the gods; with Catholic Christians, any person had the possibility of such revelation/spiritual experience.

· In Maya society, communication with the gods was part of established rituals; the visions of Saint Teresa were miraculous revelations from God.

· In Maya culture, members of the royal family were expected to perform bloodletting rituals to ensure the well-being of society, while Christian culture believed in the sacrifice of Jesus for humanity.

· During the period of the Maya empire, the polytheistic pantheon of gods including Tlaloc and their worship structures continued, whereas the structure of the Catholic church during the Baroque period was being challenged and altered, and the call to bring people back to the faith is therefore more evident.

· Lintel 25 was one of several lintels originally installed at the royal complex of Yaxchilán, further emphasizing the connection between the religious ritual depicted and the leadership role of Maya royalty.

VR255293_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255293_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Akhenaten, Nefertiti, and three daughters

· Akhenaten revolutionized Egyptian religion not only by proclaiming monotheism but also by asserting himself as the only earthly representative and prophet of the Sun God Aten.

· Akhenaten broke with religious and political traditional by establishing his new capital city at Amarna, and began the worship of a single god, Aten.

· The relief of Akhenaten, Nefertiti and three daughters was originally part of a private shrine, emphasizing the belief that Egyptians relied on the intercession of the pharaoh and his wife for access to the divine.

· The sun disk and rays of light symbolize Aten; the rays falling on the family symbolize their elevated status/privileged connection with the divine.

· The ankh symbols that Aten is extending towards Akhenaten and Nefertiti symbolize the life-giving force of the Sun and the privileged position awarded to the King and Queen by the God.

· While Akhenaten’s authority as a male ruler was typical in the patriarchal culture of Ancient Egypt, Nefertiti, his chief wife, was considered nearly his equal. This is demonstrated through her placement on the platform at the same level as Akhenaten and the ankh reaching to her; however, her smaller scale to Akhenaten still shows she is not fully his equal.

Ecstasy of Saint Teresa

· During the Counter-Reformation, one of the major purposes of art was to strengthen the connection between individuals and the divine to inspire firmer faith in the Catholic Church.

· The angel is seen as an emissary of God appearing directly to Saint Teresa; the spear is a reference to Teresa’s experience of being pierced with divine love.

· Teresa was revered because of the visions she reported in her writing that were intensely religious in nature.

· The theatrical staging of the work is in line with Jesuit teachings calling for more sensual/emotional religious art that would involve the viewer on a more direct and emotional level.

· The size and central placement of the work in the family chapel of Cardinal Cornaro reflect the importance of the message it communicated.

· Saint Teresa was an ordinary nun when she had her visions; they caused her canonization.

· The miracle of her visions led to Bernini’s lavish, extraordinary, “theatrical” expression of a vision.

· Members of the Catholic faith are redeemed through the sacrifice Jesus made by being crucified to the cross for the sins of humanity, and spiritual visions such as those experienced by Saint Teresa help to confirm her holiness as she takes part in this miraculous event.

VR255294_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255294_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of lintel 25.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Lintel 25

· In lintel 25 relief, Lady Xoc is shown close up, and is the only human figure.

· Lady Xoc is shown in the act of presenting the results of her blood sacrifice as an offering to the gods, indicated by the bowl she is holding, which contains paper soaked with her blood; the serpent that fills most of the relief composition represents Lady Xoc’s hallucinations/vision and the establishing of a connection between her and the spiritual realm as a result of her sacrifice.

· Lady Xoc is kneeling before the vision serpent and warrior-like spirit figure emerging from its mouth; the bowl with bloodstained paper she is holding references the blood ritual through which she has conjured the vision.

· The direct interaction between Lady Xoc and the spirit figure is shown by Lady Xoc’s head/face, which tilts upwards to face the warrior-like figure; in return the warrior-figure points a spear at Lady Xoc.

· The sculptor visually emphasizes the connection between the vision serpent and Lady Xoc through the implied line formed by Lady Xoc’s extended arm, intersecting with the body of the rising serpent, which then leads the viewer’s eye to the warrior-like figure, emerging from the serpents mouth to point a spear down toward Lady Xoc’s head, drawing the attention back to the figure in the lower part of the composition.

· Lady Xoc’s painful sacrifice and ability to invoke the vision serpent signify her physical and moral strength.

· The sculptor who created lintel 25 took special care to emphasize Lady Xoc’s status by depicting fine decorative details and textures of her rich clothing and jewelry.

· Lady Xoc wears a headdress and elaborate jewelry including a necklace presumably made of precious jade that indicates her royal status; she is depicted dressed in richly decorated huipil/tunic, a garment worn by women in Maya society.

· Lintel 25 was originally placed above the central doorway of Structure 23 of the royal acropolis/palace district of Yaxchilán where it would have been visible to anybody approaching or entering the building.

· Lintel 25 displays skill in carving not only the figures but also the intricate details throughout, and in the elegance of the style and masterful composition.

VR255294_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255294_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Kneeling statue of Hatshepsut

· Hatshepsut is depicted kneeling and holding two jars, which she presents as an offering to the god Amen-Re.

· Hatshepsut is depicted wearing the regalia of an Egyptian pharaoh, including a royal headdress and kilt and the ceremonial/false beard of a pharaoh.

· Hatshepsut is shown with masculine features such as broad shoulders and a flatter chest to signify her royal status and authority as the female ruler of Egypt, and she is wearing the ceremonialfalse beard of a pharaoh.

· Hatshepsut’s reverential kneeling posture and the offering jar she holds imply that she is interacting with a god; however, the god Amun-Re is not directly depicted.
Theodora panel

· The Theodora panel shows her in royal purple robes, wearing a crown and elaborate jewelry.

· Theodora is carrying a golden chalice intended for the Eucharist, suggesting that she is about to participate in the ritual of a Christian mass.

· Theodora is depicted standing with her entourage outside a doorway to the church, which she is about to enter.

· Theodora is emphasized through the elaborate crown she is wearing (which also makes her appear taller than the other figures), as well as the halo placed behind her head and the golden chalice she is holding.

· Theodora is the only figure who is not partially covered by other figures whose bodies overlap.

· The artist visually distinguished Theodora from the attendants who accompany her by placing her under a decorative canopy.

· The Theodora panel was prominently displayed in the most sacred area of the church of San Vitale normally reserved for religious imagery and a place that normally only clergy would be able to enter.

· The Theodora panel flanks the apse mosaic showing the Second Coming of Christ along with the panel of her husband Justinian on the opposing wall.

· The Theodora panel is a large wall mosaic created from small tesserae made of various materials, such as glass/gold, stone, mother of pearl; creating it would have required the collaborative effort of highly skilled artists and artisans in creating the design and actualizing the final work.
