VR255294_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255294_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how lintel 25 and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Kneeling statue of Hatshepsut

Similarities

· Both works express the role of royal/elite individuals as intermediaries with the divine.

· Both works demonstrate the need for rulers to convey the legitimacy of their status/authority.

· Both works express the belief that rulers/elite individuals have the obligation to protect/act for their people.

· Both works connect religious subject matter with political meaning.

Differences

· Hatshepsut as a pharaoh gains her royal authority by divine appointment through Egyptian gods while Lady Xoc’s authority is linked to the status of her husband and family.

· Lintel 25 expresses Maya belief in the importance of sacrifices performed by rulers/ elite individuals, while the statue of Hatshepsut expresses New Kingdom Egyptian belief that the pharaoh’s role was to uphold divine order and justice.

Theodora panel

Similarities

· Both works emphasize the religious role/responsibilities of ruling/elite individuals.

· Both works suggest a privileged connection of rulers/elite individuals with the divine.

· Both works emphasize the importance of religious piety for the ruling elite.

· Both works emphasize the importance of religious rituals to their societies.

· Both works are part of a larger iconographical program in their respective sites.

· Both works depict royal women engaged in rituals that have a spiritual connection to the idea of sacrifice/human redemption through sacrifice.

· Both works express the belief of their societies in the existence of a spiritual realm/world that is separate from the earthly realm.

· Both works utilize religious subject matter with political meaning.

Differences

· In the Byzantine era, religious authority, though shared by political leaders, resided primarily in the Church; for the Maya, royal figures/elite individuals had a privileged connection/kinship with the gods.

· While lintel 25 depicts a powerful woman leading/being the main actor in an important religious ritual, Theodora is depicted supporting a ritual shared by a religious congregation.

· In Maya society, members of the royal family were expected to perform bloodletting rituals to ensure the well-being of their people, while Byzantine/Christian culture believed in the sacrifice Jesus made for the sake of humanity.

· Lintel 25 depicts an important bloodletting ritual that resulted in Lady Xoc’svisions/hallucinations, which enabled a connection with/experience of the spiritual world, represented by the serpent and warrior.

· The Maya considered bloodletting rituals necessary to maintain the society’s harmonious relationship with the gods; only elite individuals like Lady Xoc were able to engage in this ritual, thus ensuring the well-being of her people.

· The depiction of Lady Xocin an important ritual exclusively performed by individuals who belonged to the ruling elite/royalty emphasizes her social status (as well as that of her husband) and her role in ensuring the well-being of her people.

· The depiction of Lady Xoc conjuring the presence of the spirit/vision serpent by offering her royal blood as a sacrifice emphasizes her privileged connection to the divine.

· Lady Xoc, herself from a powerful local lineage, was the principal wife of Shield Jaguar, a powerful Maya ruler/ king who ruled over the city state of Yaxchilán and who commissioned the building that lintel 25 belonged to.

· Lintel 25 was one of several lintels originally installed at the royal complex of Yaxchilán, further emphasizing the connection between the religious ritual depicted and the leadership role of Maya royalty.

· The hieroglyphic text included in the relief records information related to Lady Xoc’s legitimacy, including the date of ascension of her husband to the throne.

· Lady Xoc was a leader of her people, as evident by her making blood sacrifices to the gods and the fact that the work itself is placed inside of the royal complex at Yaxchilán.

VR255294_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255294_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Kneeling statue of Hatshepsut

· In New Kingdom Egypt, the pharaoh was considered godlike; the depiction of Hatshepsut interacting as intermediary for her people with the god Amun-Re also underscored her claim of legitimacy and authority.

· It was unusual for a woman to rule as pharaoh, and the statue of Hatshepsut therefore gives additional emphasis to her legitimacy as ruler.

· Because of the historical predominance of male rulers in Egypt, Hatshepsut’s authority is affirmed by depicting her with male attributes as well as performing the role of a good ruler (upholder of law and order).

· The two offering jars Hatshepsut is holding are thought to represent the concept of maat (truth, balance, justice, and order), reinforcing her role/responsibility as pharaoh to uphold divine justice and order within her earthly kingdom.

· The kneeling statue of Hatshepsut was placed alongside a processional route leading to Hatshepsut’s mortuary temple, which also served as a temple of the god Amun-Re; during an annual ritual a statue of the god would have been carried along this route, and the statue of Hatshepsut expressed human reverence for the passing god.

· The depiction of Hatshepsut interacting as intermediary for her people with the god Amun-Re also underscored her claim of legitimacy and authority.

Theodora panel

· Theodora is holding the chalice intended to hold the wine for the Eucharist (while her husband is shown holding the paten/plate for the bread intended for the same ritual), which would be shared by the congregation during Communion. In this way, Theodora is a witness to the self-sacrifice of Christ to his followers.

· The halo behind Theodora’s head implies saint-like status/special piety/religious authority.

· Theodora was an unusually powerful/influential Byzantine empress; her depiction in the most sacred part of the church flanking Christ and almost as an equal to her husband emphasizes her status of authority.

· The Theodora mosaic is placed on the side wall choir/apse in the sanctuary of the church of San Vitale, opposite of a matching mosaic showing her husband, Emperor Justinian.

· Theodora is shown outside of the church and about the enter the sanctuary, while her husband is shown already inside standing next to the Bishop, emphasizing her high rank and importance as a female ruler while still being subordinate to her husband.

· Both wine and bread presented by the royal couple would have been turned into the (representation of the) flesh and blood of Christ during the Eucharist ritual performed by a priest or the Bishop during Sunday mass on the altar below the Theodora and Justinian panels.

· Justinian and Theodora constructed San Vitale to represent their earthly power. Their choice of having themselves depicted inside the Church can be seen as a visual reference to depictions of Christ and Mary and the spiritual power of the Byzantine rulers.

· Theodora likely never visited San Vitale, so the scene implies the symbolic, rather than actual presence/participation of the empress in the depicted ritual.

· The spatial flatness/lack of deep space and use of gold for the background suggests an otherworldly/spiritual space.

o.d: Response accurately describes ONE example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.

o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Transformation mask

· The transformation mask has an outer and inner part; the outer part is a bird’s head that opens in the middle, revealing a human face representing a clan ancestor who formed a spiritual connection with the animal depicted and who is able to transform into the animal depicted.

· The mask is constructed with movable parts connected through hinges and contains strings that can be pulled by the wearer in order open and close the mask during performances.

· The mask is made of cedar, which is considered a sacred material to the Kwakwaka’wakw.

· The transformation mask is portable and meant to be part of a dancer’s costume, to be worn over the head.

Power figure (N’kisi n’kondi)

· The Nkisi n’kondi is a sculpture carved in the shape of a human figure; it was activated in by a ritual specialist during rituals that included the insertion of metal objects into the sculpture’s surface.

· The Nkisi n’kondi figure has recessed areas (head, neck, stomach) to receive mixtures of medicinal/sacred materials.

· The figure is made of wood, which allows for the insertion of sharp metal objects into the surface to activate the spirit residing within the statue/rouse the spirit into action.

Reliquary of Sainte-Foy

· The reliquary of Saint-Foy is a container for the relics/physical remains of a saint in the form of a seated figure representing the saint.

· The exterior of the wooden statue is covered in gold and silver and adorned with precious stones symbolically associating divine status with reflective light and precious materials. These sacred materials emphasize the sacred nature of the relics contained within.

VR255295_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255295_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the transformation mask and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Power figure (N’kisi n’kondi)

Similarities

· Both works reference a larger culturally specific cosmology that includes belief in the existence of an accessible spiritual world as well as a real world.

· Both works reference a belief in the ability of an object to convey supernatural meaning and to connect with world of ancestors and spirits.

· Both function as connections to the spirit world in their ritual contexts.

· The materials and basic form of both is traditional and stylistic conventions are consistent through time.

Differences

· While a high-status individual wears the transformation mask to convey wealth and ancestry to an audience, the Nkisi n’kondi is under the care of a spiritual specialist, kept in a shrine.

· While the transformation mask reinforces the different clan identities within Kwakwaka’wakw society, the Nkisi n’kondi is associated with actions such as healing of physical/spiritual/ social ailments, divine protection, or dispute resolution of community members.

· While transformation masks are handed down to other members of a clan and are meant to be handled and worn, Nkisi n’kondi are sacred figures that serve as spiritual/physical/social doctor and judge and are cared for by ritual/spiritual practitioners.

Reliquary of Sainte-Foy

Similarities

· Both express veneration of an important historical/mythical individual who has performed significant acts in the past and has gained spiritual power/significance/influence

· Both express the idea of spiritual transformation experienced by an important member of society.

Differences

· The importance of a connection between the human and the animal worlds is expressed in the transformation mask but not in the reliquary.

· The symbolism, use, and significance of the transformation mask is linked to members of the same clan who share the same lineage, while the reliquary was venerated/connected with all members a certain religion (Catholic Christians).

· The reliquary expresses the belief of Medieval European Christians in the power of physical relics, while the transformation mask facilitates a spiritual connection through a performance.

VR255295_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255295_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Power figure (N’kisi n’kondi)

· The Nkisi n’kondi is considered a sacred object and integral part of the society, serving as a presiding authority over health, laws and governance when activated through the actions of a spiritual specialist for clients or the community.

· Nkisi n’kondi are activated by the nganga to resolve disputes, to avenge a wrong, in healing, in oath taking, or as a guardian against malevolent forces.

· The figure serves as an intermediary, a bridge between the real and spiritual world, activated in order to solve problems facing the community or its members.

· The objects that would have been held in the medicinal cavity represent the power of the nkisi n’kondi, and would have been activated by the nganga through the insertion of metal objects into the sculpture.

Reliquary of Sainte-Foy

· Veneration of saints (martyrs who died for their faith, or individuals who performed extraordinary acts for their faith) was an important part of the beliefs and religious practices of Medieval Christians in Europe.

· Physical remains of the body of saints or objects connected with a saint were treasured by Medieval Christians as objects of supreme value; the elaborate nature of reliquaries that contained them (like the Saint-Foy reliquary) reflects this.

· The physical relics were considered to have a spiritual connection with the saint/to have spiritual power; being in the presence of a relic enabled worshipers to form a closer spiritual connection with the saint the relics belonged to.

· Medieval Christians undertook pilgrimages to visit important relics to gain spiritual and physical renewal and to improve their prospects for the afterlife.

· Saints were considered to be able to intercede on behalf of those who prayed to them; pilgrims undertook pilgrimages to sites of important relics to demonstrate their devotion/faith.

VR255296_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255296_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe specific VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Aka elephant mask

· The shape of the Aka elephant mask resembles the stylized head and body of an elephant (but also resembles some human features, such as nose); its surface is decorated with multi-colored glass beads that form geometric patterns that reference leopard skin.

· The Aka elephant mask is made of fiber/cloth is worn over the head by a dancer who performs the mask during special ceremonial occasions.

· The shape of the Aka elephant mask resembles the stylized head and body of an elephant (but also resembles some human features, such as nose).

· The surface of the Aka elephant mask is decorated with multi-colored glass beads that form geometric patterns that reference leopard skin.

· The dominant pattern of the isosceles triangle references the leopard, which was an animal associated with leadership/kingship

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

· The lamassu are colossal powerful figures that combine the bearded head of a man, the muscular body of a bull (or lion), the wings of an eagle, and the horned headdress of a god, which signal its connection with the divine/spiritual world.

· The pair of lamassu are each carved from a single block of stone in high relief. At almost 14 feet high, they were designed to stand flanking the gate to a citadel as protective guardians.

· Seen from the front, the lamassu appear to be standing still, while from the side, they appear to be walking; the sculptor achieved this effect by depicting the creature with five legs.

· Highly detailed carving in the legs and body of the lamassu is used to depict large defined muscles and bulging veins, bones, and tendons that show its strength.

· Inscriptions in cuneiform on the lamassu assert the king’s power and curse those who would threaten the citadel.

· The imposing size of lamassu and rendition in stone, combined with the imagery of hybrid being combining features of different powerful creatures, convey power and stability.

· Size, material, and mass reflect the lamassu’s function as weight-bearing support for arched citadel entryways.

VR255296_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Aka elephant mask

· While the elephant mask combines features of different creatures in the same being, the transformation mask contains of an outer and an inner part each of which represents a different being.

· While the transformation mask has movable parts and expresses ideas of transformation between animals and humans, the elephant mask uses animal symbolism to express ideas about human power and leadership.

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

· The lamassu combine features of different creatures in the same being, while the transformation mask contains an outer and an inner part each of which represents a different being.

· The imagery of the transformation mask communicates family clan status through the depiction of an animal and ancestor associated with a specific clan, while the lamassu are guardian figures that protect the king’s city (citadel) and communicate his power.

· The lamassu were integral, immovable parts of the archway they flanked, while the transformation mask has movable parts and is intended to be performed.

VR255296_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255296_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the transformation mask and the selected work express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Aka elephant mask

Similarities

· Both works express principles of social structure/social order governing their societies.

· Both works express aspects of identity important to their societies.

· Both works reveal that each society had a deep/spiritual connection to animal in habiting their region.

Differences

· The elephant mask expresses the importance of social hierarchies/structure in Bamileke society/ the power of the Bamileke ruler, while the transformation mask expresses the importance of clan identity based on ancestral lineage.

· The transformation mask expresses the idea that humans and animals are spiritually connected, while the elephant mask reinforces the importance of social hierarchies/structure for Bamileke society.

· While the iconography of the elephant mask references/affirms the power and status of the king/social hierarchy, the transformation mask references/affirms common ancestral lineage/clan identity.

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

Similarities

· Both works express belief in spiritual beings/ spiritual worlds.

· Both works express elevated social status of certain members of the community.

Differences

· The works express different power structures of their societies: while the lamassu express the supreme authority of the Assyrian king, the transformation mask expresses the more community oriented structure of Kwakwaka’wakw society, which was organized around clan and family identity.

· The transformation mask expresses the idea that humans and animals are spiritually connected and can transform into each other, while the lamassu are divine creatures, whose supernatural status is expressed through their mix of human and animal features.

· The Lamassu express the idea of permanence and stability, while the Transformation mask expresses ideas of transformation and connectedness/fluidity.

VR255296_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255296_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the transformation mask to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· Like other Indigenous American cultures, Kwakwaka’wakw religious/spiritual beliefs are centered around ideas such as interconnectedness/connection of humans with the natural world, and reciprocity.

· The Kwakwaka’wakw are divided into four clans, who each trace their origins to a common mythical ancestor with connection to/ability to transform into a specific animal.

· Transformation masks were/are worn/performed at potlatch ceremonies, which were hosted/sponsored by a prominent member of the community and included gift giving and ceremonial performances. They also appeared at other important ceremonial events.

· Traditional Kwakwaka’wakw society was stratified, with status being determined by family of birth; to host a potlatch ceremony or being able to wear/dance a transformation masks was a sign of high social rank.

· Transformation mask symbolically represents a specific clan /mythical ancestor and, as part of a performance, shows wealth and status.

· Transformation mask is made of cedar, which is a sacred material to the Kwakwaka’wakw that emphasizes the importance of ancestral relationships

· The eagle represents a specific clan as well as a possible alignment with the thunderbird, a mythical ancestor.

· Anthropomorphic aspect of the form could reference myths of the trickster to its audience.

VR255296_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255296_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual OR iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity or difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Aka elephant mask

· Bamileke culture emphasizes the importance of maintaining social hierarchy/order for the well-being of society.

· The Kuosi performance was a context that affirmed kingship.

· Kuosi is the only society allowed to perform in the Bamileke king’s court. It is an acknowledgement of the need for support of the king in a context where questioning or disguise is not normally tolerated.

· For the Bamileke the elephant, leopard skin, color symbolism all are culturally specific references to societal roles, especially royalty and leadership.

· In Bamileke culture, the Fon was a divine king who could transform into the elephant and the leopard was thought to be an animal that could transform into a human, suggesting a close connection between divine leadership and the spirit of these powerful animals.

· The multi-colored glass beads that decorate the surface of the elephant mask were costly trade items and therefore signified wealth and power.

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

· Assyria was an empire during the time that the lamassu were created, ruled by powerful kings, who had spread their influence through military conquest.

· Assyrian kings like Sargon II built heavily fortified places/citadels to guard themselves against attacks; the presence of lamassu both expressed the king’s power, as well as intimidating/protecting against enemies.

· In Mesopotamian mythology, lamassu are mythical/divine beings/minor deities who act as guardians. Their depiction as guardians of palaces or fortresses of rulers underscores the idea of the power and authority of the rulers.

· The lamassu is a guardian spirit/deity that was often depicted in gateways of palaces/fortresses of rulers and emphasizes the power of rulers.

· Massive stone sculptures like the lamassu would have been difficult/ time consuming to carve, as well as challenging to move, and demonstrated the king’s control over resources.

VR255297_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255297_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the byeri.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Byeri

· The byeri is an abstracted human form combining the large head of an infant with the powerful muscular body of an adult to suggest an ideal balance between opposites.

· The byeri’s cylindrical body and bent-kneed pose reflect its original placement as a guardian sitting on top of a cylindrical bark reliquary holding the skulls, bones, and relics of important ancestors or community members.

· The byeri is made of carved wood with some decorative details (such as an elaborate hairstyle); the surface would have been oiled, cleaned, and polished, and possibly adorned with feathers, beads, and clothing.

· The byeri’s tense, muscular form seems poised for powerful action.

· The powerful muscular body and set facial expression demonstrate the authority and confidence necessary for a protective role.

· The figure’s closed eyes and calm facial expression suggest contemplation and patience, which demand that he be approached with respect.

· The abstracted form of the body conveys that the figure is a spiritual and/or conceptual ideal, rather than a real person.

· The byeri’s herniated navel recalls the connection between life and death, reinforcing its role of guarding the remains of the dead, who are waiting to be reborn.

· The byeri has an elaborate hairstyle associated with people of higher status and social rank in the community.

· The byeri’s small scale communicates that its power comes from the balance between physical strength and calm spiritual resolve.

· The byeri ‘s small scale allowed for its portability when the nomadic society moved the remains it guarded.

VR255297_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255297_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

· The Lamassu are colossal powerful figures combining the bearded head of a man, the muscular body of a bull (or lion), the wings of an eagle, and the horned headdress of a god, signaling the connection with the divine/spiritual world.

· The Lamassu stood in pairs flanking a large stone gateway that anyone entering the citadel would have to pass between.

· The massive scale of the Lamassu reinforces their physical power by looming over the smaller humans passing between them.

· Viewed from the front, a Lamassu appears stationary, while from the side, an “extra” leg suggests the figure is walking, heightening the sense of its power and ability to protect the buildings and king inside.

· Highly detailed carving in the legs and body of the Lamassu is used to depict the large defined muscles and bulging veins, bones, and tendons that show its strength.

· Inscriptions in cuneiform on the Lamassu assert the king's power and curse those who would threaten the citadel.
Tutankhamun’s tomb, innermost coffin

· Tutankhamun’s innermost coffin conformed to the shape and likeness of the mummified pharaoh inside to protect his body in the afterlife.

· Tutankhamun’s innermost coffin depicts a crown, beard, and necklace, as well as the crook and flail, symbols of the pharaoh in Egypt and his power and authority.

· The coffin also depicts Egyptian goddesses in the form of a vulture and a cobra stretched across Tutankhamun's torso, further protecting his body.

· Tutankhamun’s innermost coffin is an idealized likeness of the pharaoh, intended for his spirit to inhabit forever in the afterlife.

· The image of Tutankhamun is idealized to represent a god, believed to have skin of gold, bones of silver, and hair made from lapis lazuli.

· Tutankhamun’s innermost coffin was contained within a set of outer nesting coffins, which in turn were protected in the inner chamber of the tomb.

· The image of Tutankhamun is idealized to represent a god, believed to have skin of gold, bones of silver, and hair made from lapis lazuli.

· Tutankhamun’s innermost coffin was contained within a set of outer nesting coffins, which in turn were protected in the inner chamber of the tomb.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the byeri to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The Fang preserved the bones and other relics belonging to important members of society and important ancestors, which were consulted when important decisions were necessary.

· The Fang derived a sense of continuity and community by honoring their ancestors.

· The Fang’s history of migration and nomadic movement led them to create cylindrical bark reliquaries for the bones of important members of the society, so that they could be transported as the community moved.

· The reliquary figures were used as puppets to educate young men about ancestral lineage, cultural history, and ideals of social behavior, represented by the figure’s balance between stillness and action and strength and restraint.

· The reliquary figure, by sitting atop and guarding the reliquary, shows the connection maintained between the human world and the world of ancestral spirits.

· The reliquary figure’s combination of forms and characteristics reinforces the culture’s desire to maintain balance and harmony between opposing forces.

VR255297_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255297_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Lamassu from the citadel of Sargon II

· The Assyrians represented divine and spiritual power through hybrid beings that combined and often exaggerated the natural features of animals and humans to convey traits that were valued in the culture, such as courage, physical strength, and cunning.

· The Lamassu were part of the massive fortifications surrounding the king’s citadel, which included carved reliefs of other supernatural/divine beings. This architectural and sculptural program functioned symbolically and politically to assert the king’s authority and support coming from the gods.

· The combination of human, animal, and godlike elements in the Lamassu reveals the culture’s belief in divine hybrid beings that possess both the physical strength and power of the world around them and the supernatural powers of the gods.

· The Lamassu’s emphasis on overwhelming power and physical strength suggests that the culture valued military power, reinforcing Sargon’s authority by communicating that he could protect his people and maintain control.

· As prominent features in the massive gate and stone walls surrounding the palace complex, the Lamassu reflect both the need for fortifications protecting the city and the king and concerns about enemy attacks.

Tutankhamun’s tomb, innermost coffin

· The early unification of Egypt created centralized rule and guaranteed agricultural production in the fertile Nile Valley, which led to a stable and permanent culture with centuries of continued traditions in art, religious beliefs, and cultural practices.

· The Egyptians created monumental pyramids and funerary complexes grouped together in cities of the dead on the west side of the Nile. Tutankhamun's tomb was located in the Valley of the Kings, where many of the most powerful Egyptian kings, queens, and high-ranking officials were buried.

· The extraordinary resources and time spent preparing for the king’s death reflects the belief in an afterlife and the extraordinary emphasis on funerary practices in Egypt.

· Religious belief was deeply embedded in the political leadership of ancient Egypt, and the king was believed to be divine or semi-divine at different points in the culture’s history. This understanding of the king’s power blends the ruler’s responsibilities to ensure the well-being of the people with the need to venerate and respect the power of the gods. Egyptians developed elaborate funerary customs to protect the ka (spirit/life force) which lived on in an eternal afterlife after the mortal body died.

· Special attention was given to ensuring the king’s ka would be comfortable in the afterlife, in order that he could continue to ensure the well-being of Egypt.

· This coffin, which protected the pharaoh’s mummified remains, was the innermost of three elaborate containers buried in a hidden chamber in an elaborate funerary complex in the Valley of the Kings.

VR255298_rubric_category_1.ti: Task 2: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art
VR255298_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of byeri.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Byeri

· The composition of the byeri is characterized by lateral symmetry; its position suggests rest and a lack of movement.

· The size of the byeri’s head is exaggerated compared to the size of its body; the size of its navel is also exaggerated, while its arms and legs are relatively short in relationship to the length of the torso.

· The byeri is carved as a seated figure since it was to be seated on a reliquary box; the lack of any specific environment around it is appropriate since its interaction was with the spiritual world.

· The byeri depicts a balance of contrasting features through the combination of infant-like features (large head, shortened limbs) with mature adult qualities (refined hair, defined muscles).

· The byeri shows idealized proportions that combine infant-like proportions (large head, shortened limbs) with mature adult qualities (refined hair, defined muscles) to convey ideal human characteristics.

· The byeri’s short arms and legs and its relatively large head (infant-like) combine with its mature hair and developed muscles to reflect its embodiment of the cycle of life.

· The byeri shows strength through bulging muscles (e.g., the shoulders) and tense muscles (particularly apparent in the pressure between the hands).

· The byeri shows a nude male figure (however it may have been adorned with jewelry/feathers).

· The byeri’s large navel links it to the spiritual world, as does its relatively large head.

VR255298_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255298_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Adam and Eve

· Adam and Eve shows ideal proportions of the adult male and female figures based on mathematical principles that are drawn from classical Greco-Roman sources.

· Adam and Eve depicts a detailed wooded environment with an imagined combination of both German and exotic plants and animals that places them—the ideal first humans—in the Paradise described in the Bible.

· The figures of Adam and Eve are depicted with strong, youthful, healthy bodies to depict the idea of perfect/archetypical humans.

· The figures of Adam and Eve are depicted (almost) nude (except for their covered genitals) to depict the idea of physical perfection.

· Dürer depicts balance by depicting both figures in contrapposto stance, which creates an interplay of contrasting/opposing movements/positions of body parts and a resulting S-curve.

· Adam and Eve is a copper engraving, a printing technique designed to be able to create numerous virtually identical reproductions of a detailed image.

· Neither the composition nor the depictions of Adam and Eve are symmetrical and the contrapposto of each figure creates a balanced asymmetry and movement in the S-curve.
Doryphoros (Spear Bearer)

· The Doryphoros was created by Polykleitos in part to demonstrate his system of mathematically calculated ideal proportions of the adult male, referred to as a “canon.”

· The Doryphoros depicts strength and vitality through clearly defined muscles and contrapposto and a youthful appearance.

· The Doryphoros depicts a nude male figure to depict the idea of physical perfection.

· The bodily proportions of the Doryphoros reflect the naturalistic proportions of an idealized human body and are intended to represent ideal beauty.

· The Doryphoros depicts balance through an interplay of contrasting/opposing movements/positions of body parts as they appear in its contrapposto stance and the resulting S-curve.

· The Doryphoros uses contrapposto to depict the motion of taking a step and to create a balanced asymmetry and movement in the S-curve.

· The byeri is a stylized representation of the human form, while the Doryphoros is based on naturalism.

VR255298_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255298_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the wall plaque from Oba’s palace and one comparison object express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Adam and Eve

Similarities

· Both works were used as instructional tools meant to convey ideals about moral behavior in their societies.

· Both works depict the importance of ancestral beings and their connection to the spiritual world.

· Both works express the importance of continuity with prior generations or traditions.

· Both works express a connection between religious/spiritual ideas and concepts about human ideals in their society.

· Both works express cultural ideas that connect physical beauty with ideal human character.

Differences

· The works express the different concepts of ideal beauty in their respective cultures/societies.

· While the byeri represents a model of what constitutes a perfect human being, Adam and Eve expresses the idea that while humans were originally created to be perfect, they have become inherently flawed and are in need of redemption.

· Adam and Eve emphasizes the relationship between humans and the natural world, while the byeri only focuses on the depiction of a human being.

Doryphoros (Spear Bearer)

Similarities

· Both works express cultural ideas that connect physical beauty with ideal human character.

· Both works were intended as instructional tools or models to convey concepts about human ideals.

· Both works express archetypical human qualities in their societies.

· Both works are connected to ideas about the cultural identity of their societies.

Differences

· The two works reflect the differing world views of their societies.

· While the byeri expresses spiritual concepts about rebirth and the afterlife, the Doryphoros expresses ideas about ideal forms found in nature/related to the earthly/worldly realm.

· The two works express the different concepts of ideal beauty of their respective cultures.

· While both works have symbolic functions, the byeri was created for a specific practical purpose and the Doryphoros was not.

VR255298_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about byeri to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· The Fang preserved the bones and other relics belonging to important members of society and important ancestors, which were consulted in times when a great decision had to be made.

· The Fang derived a sense of continuity and community through honoring their ancestors.

· The byeri was used to underscore the importance of ancestors and prior generations.

· The reliquary figure in its role to guard and sit atop the reliquaries shows the connection maintained between the human world and the world of ancestral spirits.

· The byeri guardian figure is a single body that conveys a balance of tensions valued by the Fang peoples, such as the childlike and adult, the baby-like and the muscular.

· The byeri’s exaggerated baby-like proportions and herniated navel are all references to the ancestral ties to the spiritual world.

· The byeri’s combined references to infancy and adulthood reflect its connection to the idea of a cycle of life from birth to death.

· The Fang’s history of migration and nomadic movement led them to create reliquaries (bark containers) for the remains of important members of the society, which could be moved as the community moved to preserved societal values and histories.

· The byeri served as a reliquary guardian but was also removed at times to instruct young male initiates through its use in puppetry about ancestral lineage, cultural history, and ideals of social behavior, represented by the figure’s balance between power/calm, strength/restraint.

· The byeri was small enough to be removed from the container on which it usually sat in order to serve a second function as a pedagogical tool; its calm demeanor and the wisdom it expressed also served that role.

· The byeri was positioned on top of a reliquary box and was moved when the community in order to preserve societal values.

· One of the primary functions of the byeri was to serve as the guardian of ancestors’ bones; not only its strength but also its seated posture refer specifically to that role.

· The byeri was made of wood and rubbed with palm-oil to honor the guardian and the dead.

· The artist who created the byeri would not be identified or honored in the context of use, which focused more on the guardian figures’ role with the reliquary and the importance of initiated members who protected the relics.

VR255298_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255298_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Adam and Eve

· In Renaissance art, engravings were valued because they could be reproduced to spread religious as well as secular ideas and narratives.

· Adam and Eve would have been reproduced as part of biblical instruction or scholarly study; however, it would have also been appreciated as art.

· Dürer’s print represents a biblical story that would have been familiar to virtually all viewers; its production as a print made it possible for many people who might have seen related images in sacred contexts to have it in their homes.

· The print is part of a context of scholarly study and increased interest in print culture and study of the Italian Renaissance and Greco-Roman Classical ideals.

· The print combines religious ideas about the flawed nature of earthly humanity and the importance of spirituality with humanist ideas about an earthly human ideal that can be expressed in physical form.

· Adam and Eve, as the original Biblical couple, were created by God in his likeness and are therefore both examples of perfect humans, as well as being connected to the spiritual world.

· The story of Adam and Eve was important for Christians, since it recounts both the origin of humans and the original sin they committed, which led to the expulsion of humans from paradise and shaped the fate of all later generations to the present.

· The print depicts the story of Adam and Eve right before committing the original sin of eating the forbidden apple; their idealized appearance can be interpreted as representing original perfection not tainted by sinful behavior.

· The representation of Adam and Eve reflects naturalistic proportions of an idealized human body that were deeply influenced by humanism.

· Dürer’s print includes a set of complex symbols around the figures to reference balances in the body and morality: the elk, ox, rabbit, and cat represent the four humors; the apple, fig trees, and snake represent temptation and sin; the parrot represents false wisdom or alternatively, the Ave Maria prayer and, thus, purity.

Doryphoros (Spear Bearer)

· The Doryphoros embodies the Greek interest in mathematics (for example, the ratios determined by Pythagoras) and the idea that perfect beauty can be found in archetypical forms and proportions found in the natural world.

· The Doryphoros, based on Polykleitos’s canon, reflected Greek preference for rationality and the importance of reason as opposed to emotion.

· The Doryphoros expresses the Classical Greek idea that the ideal of human beauty would approximate the beauty of the gods.

· Classical Greek culture held a connection between physical beauty and the expression of moral strength/beauty of character.

· As a model of the principles of the canon, the Doryphoros displays a contrapposto pose in which all body parts are balanced and have the proportions described by Polykleitos.

· Polykleitos intended for the (original) statue of Doryphoros to be a teaching tool that would demonstrate his ideas/theories about how to create a perfect image of human beauty.

· Ancient Greeks, especially in Classical Greece, connected art, such as sculpture, with their unique cultural identity; the desire to develop a unique Greek style/unique expression of beauty more independent from other Mediterranean influences can be seen in this context.

· Doryphoros also served the secular function of expressing an athletic ideal of male beauty, which was tied to the ability of Greek men to serve as soldiers.

· The Doryphoros may have been displayed in a palestra where athletes trained, but regardless of its context of display, it represented bodily ideals to a society that valued athletic training.and strength.

VR255299_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255299_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Spiral Jetty

· Spiral Jetty depicts a spiral, which is a shape that is found in nature in many different contexts (in physical shapes of organisms, etc, but also in the way that many organisms grow/processes happen).

· Smithson designed Spiral Jetty as an earthwork extending into the Great Salt Lake, subject to natural changes in the environment and by geological change over time.

· It was made by bulldozing tons of earth/pebbles/rock into the spiral shape in a remote/not very accessible location.

· The large scale of Spiral Jetty recalls the monumental scale of natural wonders in the landscape (canyons, mountains, rock formations, etc.).

· Smithson chose a shape and materials for his work that would create a natural unity with the site.

· Spiral Jetty was submerged under the lake for many years; the rocks are covered in salt crystals from rising water.
The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel

· The Valley of Mexico is a highly detailed landscape painting, including identifiable portrayals of plants, buildings, and landscape features.

· The Valley of Mexico is a landscape painting executed in oil paint on a large/monumental scale comparable to that of history paintings.

· The Valley of Mexico depicts a landscape with special significance for Mexican culture, including a bird’s eye view of Mexico City in the middle ground, identifiable local plants in the foreground, and identifiable mountain ranges in the background.

· The Valley of Mexico depicts a sweeping birds-eye view of a landscape that includes a view of Mexico City; however, signs of human culture and progress are dwarfed by the landscape features.

· The Valley of Mexico uses established techniques of illusionistic perspective to create a naturalistic view of the Mexican landscape.

· A group of figures in the foreground suggest a human desire to return to nature.

VR255299_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255299_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the maize cobs and one comparison object express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Spiral Jetty

Similarities

· Both works depict natural forms that carry spiritual meaning for the culture in which they were created.

· Both works create a connection with specific geographic/natural environments in order to convey meaning.

Differences

· While the maize cobs express the importance of agricultural crops for the Inka/control of the Inka/humans over the natural environment, Spiral Jetty engages with the meaning of larger natural processes and phenomena that are not under human control.

· While the maize cobs are a form from nature used to symbolize the power of Inka state religion and empirical rule, Spiral Jetty expresses the power/significance of nature itself.

· While Smithson produced extensive documentation about the creation and intent of Spiral Jetty, the Inka did not keep records about the creation or intent of their artworks.

· While the materials contribute to the artistic/cultural value of the maize cobs, Spiral Jetty employs ordinary materials that have little intrinsic artistic or cultural value.

· While Spiral Jetty expresses an interest in and values the concept of the ephemeral, the maize cobs express an interest in and place value on the idea of permanence in Inka culture.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel

Similarities

· Both works depict natural features/elements that carry spiritual/political meaning for the culture in which they were created.

· Both works emphasize a connection to specific landscapes/ geographic/natural environments with cultural significance.

Differences

· While The Valley of Mexico is intended to express/represent a sense of Mexican cultural and national identity and unity, the maize cobs express Inka religious beliefs.

· While the maize cobs express the need to consolidate power/authority/supremacy over the different parts of the empire, The Valley of Mexico appeals to a sense of cultural and national unity based on a shared culture and history.

· The Valley of Mexico demonstrates the synthesis of European artistic tradition with nationalist Mexican iconography, while the Maize cobs draw on traditional metallurgical and artistic practices from throughout the Inka empire.

VR255299_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255299_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the maize cobs to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· Maize/corn was an important agricultural product for the Inka, which held spiritual/political/cultural significance for its ritual use and symbolic meaning.

· Maize/corn was an important food crop for the Inka and in the Americas in general; it was also used to create a drink consumed by the Inka elite and given as tribute.

· Corn/maize could only be grown in certain geographic regions of the Inka Empire and therefore represented crops/tributes of certain regions of the empire; its use as tribute therefore affirmed the central control and superiority of the Inka rulers.

· The use of precious materials and highly skilled/specialized labor to create the maize cobs also expresses the control held by the elite in the Inka empire over resources.

· Representations of corn/maize, like the one shown, were given as religious offerings by the Inka.

· Depictions of maize were made to ask deities for abundant harvests.

· Maize cobs similar to the ones shown are reported to have been part of the lost garden created for the Inka main temple of the Sun in Cusco, Quorikancha, which is thought to have been a symbolic representation of the Inka Empire and served as religious offering to the God Inti with whom the Inka Emperors associated themselves.

· Gold/silver were precious materials whose use was restricted to the Inka nobility.

· The Inka connected silver and gold with cosmological/divine symbolism; silver symbolized the Moon, while gold symbolized the Sun; objects made from silver and gold were often used in religious contexts.

· The maize sculptures held both religious and political meaning since the Inka rulers connected themselves with the gods/with celestial deities; for example, the Inka Emperors associated themselves with the Sun God Inti.

VR255299_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Spiral Jetty

· Smithson was a pioneer of environmental art, and his art expresses rising concerns in the 1960s and 1970s about the damage that humans were doing to the environment.

· Smithson chose the shape of the spiral because of its connection with ideas of growth, the life cycle, and evolutionary forces of nature/universal forces that predate humanity.

· The spiral holds spiritual meaning in many cultures. The form is often seen in ancient and indigenous artworks that Smithson would have known.

· The location of Spiral Jetty in a salt lake in a remote part of Utah reinforces its connection with nature that is apart from/not conquered by human civilization.

· Spiral Jetty changes in appearance depending on outside factors such as the amount of rain.

· The remote location of Spiral Jetty reinforces its spiritual associations because it requires viewers to seek it out, similar to a pilgrimage journey.

· Smithson was interested in concepts of entropy and geologic time as expressions of the transcendent/universal forces in life and experience.

· Smithson’s work characterizes the conceptual nature of much art in the early 1970s through its use of ordinary materials, documentation of his ideas and working process, and his rejection of art as an object for purchase and display.

· Smithson created numerous preliminary sketches, wrote extensively about his artistic interests and goals, and created a film that documented the creation of Spiral Jetty.

The Valley of Mexico from the Hillside of Santa Isabel

· Development of nationalist landscape painting in Mexico emerges after the 1821 war of independence from Spain.

· Velasco was part of a national Mexican art movement supported by the state to develop a new type of historical and landscape painting that emphasizes/celebrates Mexican identity.

· The Mexican academy of art was rooted in the European tradition of romantic landscape painting, but Velasco expands tradition by including references to pre-colonial mythology and cultural knowledge of the land.

· Velasco’s landscapes were used to promote an ideal of Mexican identity through exhibition abroad in World’s Fairs.

· The landscape depicted represents multiple layers of Mexican identity, since it includes important cultural and natural features of the Aztec/ precolonial Mexican past, colonial Mexica, as well as modern, independent Mexico, including:

· Mountains Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl in the background, which were considered sacred mountains by the Aztec and play important roles in ancient mythologies as well as popular legends.

· Lake Texcoco, the site of Mexico City—the modern capital—as well

as the Aztec capital, Tenochtitlan.

· Hill of Tepeyac, site of the miraculous appearance of the Virgin of Guadalupe.

· Plants and landscape features specific to Mexican geography and botany.

· Buildings connected to Mexican history as well as signs of industrialization that was gradually transforming the landscape.

VR255300_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the maize cobs.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: Maize cobs

· The maize cobs are intended as a representation of the corn, which exists in nature and was a valuable agricultural crop of the Inka.

· The maize cobs are realistically depicted to look like a ripe ear of corn, which has burst out of the husk, and is ready to be harvested.

· The artist crafted the metal to show varied textures and naturalistic features, to suggest the different parts of the corn—the cob covered with rows of kernels, the husk, leaves, and stem.

· The maize cobs are detailed, hollow sculptures created in repoussé technique from sheets of silver-gold metal alloys/silver and gold, which only highly skilled artists/artisans would have been able to create.

· Silver and gold used in the creation of the maize cobs were materials with cosmological/sacred symbolism in Inka culture.

· Format would have made it well suited as offering; the maize cobs might have been part of a larger installation that served as a religious offering/or might have served as religious offering by themselves.

· The maize cobs are life-sized and might have been part of a larger installation that served as a religious offering/or might have served as religious offering by themselves.

VR255300_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255300_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel, including Lamentation

· The walls of the Arena Chapel are decorated with a cycle of paintings showing the life of the Madonna, the life of Christ and the Passion and Last Judgment, and would have taken years to complete.

· Some of the colors in the Arena Chapel (gold and blue) were expensive and not easy to obtain.

· The Arena Chapel frescoes include figures with a convincing illusion of three-dimensionality and natural gestures.

· The donor, Enrico Scrovegni, is shown in the lower left corner of the fresco of the Last Judgment among those blessed by Christ; he is presenting the chapel as a gift to God.
Statues of votive figures from the Square Temple at Eshnunna

· The statues are male and female standing figures that have large eyes, are carefully carved, and have detailed hair/beard.

· The figures are placed on round bases, which enabled them to be stood upright inside a temple to face an image or the presence of a deity.

· The enlarged eyes of the figures, which are emphasized through inlay technique, likely signal attentiveness and adoration/devotion/spiritual presence.

· The figures hold small vessels, possibly representing religious offerings/libations.

· The statues are thought to represent people worshiping a deity, as suggested by their enlarged eyes and their pose with upturned faces and clasped hands, which suggest prayer/devotion.

· The figures are carved from gypsum and their eyes are inlaid with shell and black limestone; these materials, which would have made the works more valuable (time consuming to carve) as well as durable, fit their intended function as offerings that should withstand time.

VR255300_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel, including Lamentation

· The Arena chapel frescoes convey meaning through religious narratives, while the maize cobs communicate meaning through symbolism of material and subject matter.

· The Arena chapel includes a depiction of the donor, representing the chapel as an offering to God, while the maize cobs do not include a physical depiction of the donor.

· The Arena chapel is a religious building/place for religious worship that was commissioned to express religious devotion, while the maize cobs are a portable object/not architectural sculpture that was likely presented/deposited at a sacred site as an offering.

Statues of votive figures from the Square Temple at Eshnunna

· The statues express religious meaning through their representation/votive action, whereas the maize cobs are recognizable symbols that express religious meaning.

· The figures reflect their religious function through their pose and expression, while the maize cobs express their religious function through their choice of material and subject matter.

VR255300_rubric_category_5.ti: Task 6: Articulate a defensible claim that explains the meaning or significance of similarities or differences between two works of art.
VR255300_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately explain a similarity OR difference in how the wall plaque from Oba’s palace and one comparison object express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel, including Lamentation

Similarities

· Both express belief in the importance of demonstrating religious devotion to deities through tangible objects/works of art.

· Both works emphasize a connection between social elites and religious functions.

Differences

· While the maize cobs emphasize the power of the Inka empire/ruling elite and their connections to the gods, the Arena chapel emphasizes the need for the ruling elite to be humble before God.

· While the maize cobs express the value the Inka society placed on certain agricultural crops/products, the Arena Chapel expresses the value placed in the documentation/recording of religious narratives in European societies.

Statues of votive figures from the Square Temple at Eshnunna

Similarities

· Both works express a belief in the importance of offerings to be made to deities to express religious devotion.

· Both works were created in societies with strong social stratification/hierarchies and both express ideas about social or political hierarchies.

Differences

· The votive figures express the status of individual donors, while maize cobs (also) express the power of the Inka empire/state.

· The votive figures were intended to express the connection of individual donors to a deity, while the maize cobs were intended to express the connection of the Inka empire/emperor/state to gods.

VR255300_rubric_category_6.ti: Task 7: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255300_rubric_category_6.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about maize cobs to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

· Maize/corn was an important agricultural product and held spiritual/political/cultural significance for its ritual use and symbolic meaning.

· The Inka Empire was a highly stratified society; the emperor ruled over different regions, which were required to give tribute to the empire.

· Corn/maize could only be grown in certain geographic regions of the Inka empire and therefore represented crops/tributes of certain regions/parts of the empire.

· While maize/corn was an important food crop for the Inka and in the Americas in general, it was also used to create a drink consumed by the Inka elite and given as tribute.

· The use of precious materials and access to highly skilled/specialized labor/artists to create the maize cobs also expresses the control held by the elite in the Inka Empire over resources.

· Representations of corn/maize, like the one shown, were given as religious offerings by the Inka.

· Depictions of maize were made to ask deities for abundant harvests.

· The Inka connected silver and gold with cosmological/divine symbolism; the silver that the maize cobs were made of symbolized the Moon.

· Religious offerings of maize sculptures also had a political connection, since the Inka rulers connected themselves with the gods.

· Maize cobs similar to the ones shown are reported to have been part of the lost garden created for the Inka main temple of the Sun in Cusco, Quorikancha, which is thought to have been a symbolic representation of the Inka Empire and served as religious offering to the God Inti with whom the Inka Emperors associated themselves.

VR255300_rubric_category_7.ti: Task 8: Explain how the evidence justifies the claim.
VR255300_rubric_category_7.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe an example of contextual or iconographical evidence about the selected work to support the explanation of a similarity OR difference in how both works express the values or beliefs of the society in which each work was created.
o.af:
Examples that would earn this point might include the following:

Arena (Scrovegni) Chapel, including Lamentation

· Enrico Scrovegni commissioned the chapel as a sign of his religious devotion/Christian faith and possibly as penance for his father’s usury.

· Medieval Christians believed in the importance of making generous offerings/gifts to the church to demonstrate one’s religious faith/humility, in particular for those who were wealthy.

· The Arena Chapel was built as part of the palace/home of the Scrovegni family and therefore linked with the family.

· The Arena Chapel was private and was used almost exclusively by the Scrovegni family, so it was only they who saw frescoes that both implicitly and explicitly express the need for humility.

· The depiction of Enrico Scrovegni explicitly shows him presenting the chapel to the Madonna.

· The interior of the Arena Chapel is richly decorated with frescoes that tell important biblical narratives.

· The choice of subject matter of the frescoes expresses the importance of recording and communicating religious narratives for the Christian faith, which were recorded in written word as well as frequently depicted in image form in Catholic European culture.

· The frescoes, such as the Lamentation, include divine characters such as angels who share in the emotions of the human scene.

Statues of votive figures from the Square Temple at Eshnunna

· Ancient Sumerians believed in a pantheon of different deities; individual city states worshiped particular deities as their city’s protector/patron deity; the votive figures are from the temple of the god Abu of the city state of Eshnunna.

· Sumerians built temples for their gods, which were considered places that the gods inhabited/where they appeared to priests; Sumerians brought votive offerings of crops and other items to these temples, such as the votive statues.

· The two votive figures were found together with other, similar figures buried underneath the Square Temple at Eshnunna; they are thought to have originally been placed inside the temple, possibly lined up against the inner walls.

· The vessels that are held by the statues might symbolize sacrificial liquid offerings/libations and represent real religious practices that were carried out.

· The male figure has also been interpreted as a statue of the god Abu himself, whom the temple was dedicated to (based on size and carvings on base).

· Temples were not intended for congregational use and access was restricted to priests and possibly other privileged individuals; votive statues might have been intended as a way for other community members to access the god’s presence.

· Sumerian city states were highly stratified societies with a high degree of division of labor; rulers were considered to be representatives of the gods on earth and acted as their intermediaries.

· The votive figures are thought to represent private donors/patrons and to have been intended to offer eternal, uninterrupted devotion/adoration to the deity on behalf of the patrons (attested by inscriptions on some of the statues).

· The donors would likely have been individuals of elevated social status who could afford to commission such statues.

VR255301_rubric_category_1.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of maize cobs.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object shown: maize cobs

· The maize cobs are realistically depicted to look like a ripe ear of corn, which has burst out of the husk, and is ready to be harvested.

· The maize cobs are an extremely naturalistic, life-size depiction of actual corn cobs, including careful depictions of individual kernels and the texture of the leaves, but created entirely from metal.

· The artist crafted the metal to show varied textures and naturalistic features, to suggest the different parts of the corn—the cob covered with rows of kernels, the husk, leaves, and stem.

· The maize cobs are detailed, hollow sculptures created in repoussé technique from sheets of silver alloys/silver and gold, which only highly skilled artists/artisans would have been able to create.

· The maize cobs are intended as a representation of the corn, which exists in nature and was a valuable agricultural crop of the Inka.

· Silver and gold used in the creation of the maize cobs were materials with cosmological/sacred symbolism in Inka culture.

o.d: Response accurately describes ONE VISUAL characteristic of maize cobs.

VR255301_rubric_category_2.ti: Task 3: Describe visual characteristics of a work of art.
VR255301_rubric_category_2.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT accurately describe VISUAL characteristics of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object (Le Déjeuner enfourrure)

· All surfaces of the cup, saucer, and spoon are covered in animal/gazelle fur.

· The small scale of the cup, saucer, and spoon demonstrates this is a functional object covered in fur.

Pyxis of al-Mughira

· The pyxis was carved from ivory (from a section of an elephant tusk), a valuable luxury/trade material, by hollowing out a section of an elephant tusk to make it into a container, and with a lid added.

· Pyxis was shaped as a container with a lid and was intended to hold incense or other precious/luxury substances used at court by the Umayyad elite.

· The surface of the pyxis was carved with intricate reliefs by highly skilled artists (court workshop); the reliefs include medallions that depict courtly scenes (including musicians, references to garden, hunting), and plant and animal motifs.

o.d: Response accurately describes ONE VISUAL characteristic of the selected work.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Pyxis of al-Mughira

· Pyxis was shaped as a container with a lid and was intended to hold incense or other precious/luxury substances used at court by the Umayyad elite.

VR255301_rubric_category_3.ti: Task 4: Explain how two or more works of art are similar in how they convey meaning.
VR255301_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT use accurately use specific visual evidence from both works to explain a similarity in how both works elevate an ordinary object or objects to a higher level of meaning.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object (Le Déjeuner enfourrure)

· The shape of both works closely resembles the objects they are depicting/representing, but the surface texture/material differs markedly from the original.

· Both works create connections between organic and inorganic objects/materials.

· Both works creatively use materials to transform everyday items related to sustenance/food/drink into something that serves no utilitarian purpose. By covering the cup in fur, Oppenheim takes away the object’s function as a drinking vessel, while the corn is made not edible by being made out of metal.

Pyxis of al-Mughira

· The pyxis is a container, an object with an ordinary function, that has been elevated to a luxury object, while the maize cob depicts an ordinary and ephemeral agricultural crop that has been elevated to a precious object without practical function.

· Both works are made from valuable materials featuring intricate details and were created by highly skilled artists/artisans, which emphasizes their material value.

o.d: Response accurately uses visual evidence from both works to explain ONE similarity in how both works elevate an ordinary object or objects to a higher level of meaning.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

By covering the cup in fur, Oppenheim takes away the object’s function as a drinking vessel, while the corn is made not edible by being made out of metal.

Pyxis of al-Mughira

· The pyxis is a container, an object with an ordinary function, that has been elevated to a luxury object, while the maize cob depicts an ordinary and ephemeral agricultural crop that has been elevated to a precious object without practical function.

· Both works are made from valuable materials featuring intricate details and were created by highly skilled artists/artisans, which emphasizes their material value.

VR255301_rubric_category_4.ti: Task 5: Explain how two or more works of art are different in how they convey meaning.
VR255301_rubric_category_4.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: Response does NOT use accurately use specific visual evidence from both works to explain a difference in how both works elevate an ordinary object or objects to a higher level of meaning.
o.af:
Examples that might earn this point include the following:

Object (Le Déjeuner enfourrure)

· Object combines commonly found materials/objects to create an unexpected juxtaposition, while the maize cobs use precious materials and resources to create a precious/luxurious object in the shape of a plant/corn.

· Oppenheim used the soft texture of the fur in contrast to the hard porcelain teacup to evoke various or conflicting associations/feelings in viewers with Object, while the artists who created the maize cobs intended to create a precious object that would be deemed worthy of an offering.

Pyxis of al-Mughira

· The pyxis is a functional object that has luxury/artistic value, whereas the maize cobs serve no practical function beyond their artistic/symbolic role. The intricate decorative carving and precious ivory material contribute to the object’s role as a symbol of status and value; likewise the use of precious metals to create the maize cobs underscores corn’s sacred meaning.

· The lavish decorations of the pyxis are integral to its role as a luxury object with connections to court culture, while the maize cob communicates symbolic meaning through its use of subject matter and material.

o.d: Response accurately uses visual evidence from both works to explain ONE difference in how both works elevate an ordinary object or objects to a higher level of meaning.
